description: On 4 November 1989, exploratory talks between representatives of the EPRDF and the Government of Ethiopia opened in Rome. Alberto Solerathe, the Italian ambassador to China and former ambassador to Ethiopia, chaired these talks. During the talks, that were supposed to be of a procedural kind to make way for future negotiations, the TPLF presented a peace plan adopted at its congress in March the same year. The plan called for a broad based provisional government including representatives from all political organisations. The Government, in turn, accused the rebel factions of wishing to secede, leading to “national disunity”. The talks were adjourned on 11 November and were scheduled to be reopened on 12 December, but instead of continued talks, the fighting intensified in December.

Between 20 and 29 March 1990, talks between the EPRDF and the Government of Ethiopia were held in Rome, under chairmanship of Alberto Solerathe, but no substantial progress was made. The negotiations again ended in a stalemate due to disagreement about what the focus of the talks should be. While the Government of Ethiopia solely wanted to discus local issues related to the area in which the EPRDF was operating, the EPRDF demanded that the discussions would focus on national issues.

In early May 1991, the conflict parties agreed to negotiations in London scheduled on 27 May, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would act as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneously to the negotiations, on 27 May, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year.

It was not until 1989 that the Government of Ethiopia and the EPLF accepted a third party to mediate. In the first half of 1989, former US President Jimmy Carter tried to mediate between the two parties in order to bring peace talks about.

Between 7 and 19 September 1989, preliminary peace talks took place in Atlanta, Georgia, where Carter obtained his mandate to mediate talks without conditions and with the talks publicly and officially announced.

The talks resumed in Nairobi on 20 November 1989, again led by Carter, and the two sides decided to hold formal negotiations in early 1990. Jimmy Carter mediated between the conflict parties in Nairobi in November 1989. On 20 November 1989, at the end of the talks in Nairobi, the two sides decided to hold formal negotiations in early 1990, but these negotiations never came about. Although the Government of Ethiopia frequently expressed it was willing to resume negotiations mediated by Carter, the EPLF was reluctant to renew the Carter initiative.

In early May 1991, the conflict parties agreed to negotiations in London scheduled on 27 May, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would act as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneously to the negotiations, on 27 May, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year.

From February to May 1997, South Africa undertook various attempts to initiate negotiations between President Mobutu Sese Seko and AFDL leader Laurent-Désiré Kabila. However, the AFDL had the upper hand in the fighting and therefore initially rejected formal talks. On 19 February 1997, South African President Nelson Mandela announced that he had invited Laurent-Désiré Kabila, chairman of the ADFL, to visit South Africa and to engage in peace talks with Mobuto. On 26 February, it was announced that Mandela had persuaded Kabila to negotiate. On 4 May 1997, Mandela mediated the first direct negotiations between Kabila and Mobutu aboard a South African naval vessel. The talks did not lead to an agreement. Mobutu proposed to set up a mutually acceptable transitional government prior to open elections in which everyone could participate, while Kabila demanded Mobutu to step down and hand over power to the AFDL. In the meantime, the AFDL moved steadily from the east to the west. They met with little resistance on their way to Kinshasa with the exception of troops from the former Rwandan army and from the Angolan rebel group UNITA under Jonas Savimbi. In mid-May President Mobutu was defeated by the AFDL and its allies. AFDL leader Kabila claimed victory and subsequently assumed power on 16 May 1997.

In early 1999, a consultative meeting with the states in the region was held in Lusaka under the auspices of Zambian President Frederick Jacob Titus Chiluba, who had been mandated as the chief mediator in October 1998. Libyan President al-Gaddafi continued his mediating efforts between Kabila and Museveni in Sirte on 18 April 1999, but none of the rebel factions were involved in these talks. Nevertheless, progress was made. President Kabila promised to start negotiations with Congolese rebels, while President Museveni promised to withdraw Uganda’s troops. Consequently, the Government of the DRC and the three rebel groups – the RCD, the RCD-ML, and the MLC – as well as Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe met in Lusaka in July, which led to the signing of the Lusaka Accord by the regional states on 10 July 1999, but RCD and MLC initially refuse to sign. The MLC signed the agreement on 1 August. On 31 August, after intense diplomatic pressure, all 50 founding members of the fractious RCD signed. Rebel leader Emile Ilunga and 41 of his deputies signed on behalf of the RCD. This was a compromise following dispute between the two RCD factions about which group had the right to sign.

Several preparatory meetings were held in early 2000. On 8 April 2000, the parties to the Lusaka agreement accepted a disengagement plan in Kampala in which they agreed to retreat their forces 15 km behind the frontlines.

On 4 May 2000, the three Congolese insurgent parties renewed their commitment to the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. The preparatory committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue subsequently continued to work on finding consensus on how the peace talks would proceed. After it was decided which parties should participate in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, the Government of the DRC suggested that the dialogue should be held in Kinshasa, but this suggestion was rejected by Masire. The Government became increasingly critical toward Masire, which eventually led to a declaration in which they stated to have lost their confidence in the Organization of African Unity mediator. Kabila considered him persona non grata and reportedly closed his offices in Kinshasa.  As a result, the Government boycotted a round of consultations organized by Masire in Benin in June 2000.

Nevertheless, by August, the parties had managed to agree on an agenda, the structure, the rules, the place, and the dates of the dialogue.  In mid-October 2000, a regional summit was held in Mozambique hosted by Mozambican President, Joaquim Chissano, where the agreement that all fighters should withdraw 15 km from their positions was reiterated. Within the same month, South African President Thabo Mbeki managed to secure agreement to this withdrawal plan from all the rebel parties.

On 15 February 2001, all parties to the conflict met in Lusaka and agreed once again to disengage to positions occupied by their forces in May 2000. However, no timetable for the withdrawal was set. Moreover, Uganda and Rwanda insisted on maintaining a presence in the DRC until the ADF and Hutu militias were removed, while Kabila’s foreign allies refused to withdraw until Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi had moved out their troops from the DRC. When Laurent Kabila was assassinated on 16 January 2001, his son succeeded. He had a more welcoming attitude towards Masire. In early March 2001, Joseph Kabila invited Masire to Kinshasa and  promised to resume discussions with the mediator in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.
On the initiative of South Africa, the conflict parties (including the Mayi-Mayi militias) met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.
On 4 May 2001, representatives of the DRC Government and the principal rebel factions signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka.

In late August 2001, the parties met in Botswana and agreed that the official Inter-Congolese dialogue was to commence in mid-October in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. Attempting to outline areas of agreement, the Congolese government and RCD along with Mouvement pour la Liberation du Congo (MLC) signed the Acte d’Engagement in Gaborone on 24 August with Botswanan president Ketumile Masire acting as the lead mediator.

A subsequent preparatory meeting was held in Abuja in September before the dialogue opened in Addis Ababa on October 15, 2001. However, Kabila and MLC leader Bemba failed to attend the October meeting in Ethiopia. Furthermore, RCD boycotted the opening ceremony. Consequently, the talks at Addis Ababa only lasted for five days instead of the proposed 45 days.  The mediation effort was also plagued by financial problems. Donors had pledged $5 million for Masire’s office, but only $250,000 had been forthcoming for the Addis Ababa meeting. This forced the mediation team to ask the conflict parties to reduce their delegations at the very last minute.
In 2002, the Inter-Congolese Dialogue continued. Talks started in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February, but these broke down after one day, when the MLC boycotted the meeting.
third_party: Switzerland; South Africa; Zambia; Nigeria; Malawi; OAU; UN

description: Talks resumed on 5 March, although accusations of ceasefire violations in Moliro overshadowed the talks. The 362 delegates in Sun City split into five different committees to negotiate on political and legal matter; security and defense; social, cultural, and humanitarian affairs; economy and finance; and finally, peace and reconciliation.
third_party: Switzerland; South Africa; Zambia; Nigeria; Malawi; OAU; UN

description: On 17 March, RCD unilaterally declared a ceasefire, providing an incentive for the Congolese government to continue participation in the talks. On 9 April 2002, the talks moved forward, among other due to MLC accepting Joseph Kabila as the President during the interim period, which was the result of bilateral talks between the two parties. On 19 April, a partial peace agreement was signed between the rebel factions and Kabila, referred to as the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC or “Sun City Accord”, which was supported by more than 70 per cent of the delegates. Yet, the Rwandan-supported RCD wing rejected the agreement insisting that they deserved the position of the prime minister, which the agreement had been accorded to MLC leader Bemba.
third_party: Switzerland; South Africa; Zambia; Nigeria; Malawi; OAU; UN

description: To move the peace process forward, the UN Secretary-General mandated Moustapha Niasse as his Special Envoy to the DRC to mediate a comprehensive peace agreement. Niasse conducted three missions in the region between June and October during which he consulted with the main rebel leaders and the government officials. Importantly, on 30 July 2002, Rwandan and Congolese presidents, Kagame and Kabila signed an accord in Pretoria under Mbeki’s watch. Kabila pledged to disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing. Moreover, on 6 September 2002, Uganda and the DRC signed the Luanda agreement hosted by President Dos Santos, which decided on the withdrawal of Ugandan forces from the Congolese territory within three months. In November, another round of talks began, resulting in the conclusion of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo in Pretoria on 17 December 2002. In addition to the conflict parties, the political opposition and civil society, with the latter referred to as the forces vives, participated in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.
third_party: Switzerland; South Africa; Zambia; Nigeria; Malawi; OAU; UN
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: On 2 August 1998, in a radio broadcast, Sylvain Mbuchi, the commander of the 10th battalion of the national Congolese army, rejected President Kabila’s authority and called for his departure, urging all Congolese citizens to rise up against Kabila. Mbuchi subsequently announced the formation of the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie (RCD) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy). The political wing behind the movement involved a group of people discontented with Kabila, including former Mobutists, former AFDL rebels, as well as opposition politicians. Both Rwanda and Uganda supported the creation of the movement. In response to the outbreak of this armed conflict, Nelson Mandela, as the chairman of SADC, tried to broker peace talks at an emergency summit of SADC leaders that was convened in Pretoria on 23 August 1998, but without success. President Kabila stated that he doubted whether Mandela was neutral.

On 7 and 8 September 1998, the Presidents of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, and the DRC met in Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, to discuss how to resolve the conflict. They actors present agreed on a ceasefire between Rwanda, Uganda, and the DRC. Zambian President Frederick Jacob Titus Chiluba was mandated as mediator at this meeting, after which he was formally authorized to act as mediator in the conflict at the annual SADC meeting on 15 September 1998. The RCD was not invited to participate in the talks at Victoria Falls. As a consequence, the RCD leadership immediately rejected the ceasefire agreed in Victoria Falls. The RCD was not invited to peace talks organized in Addis Ababa on 10 September by the Organization of African Unity either. Yet, a few weeks later, Libyan head of state al-Gaddafi, acting on his own, mediated talks in Libya between President Kabila and RCD officials. Ugandan President Museveni also participated in these talks. However, no real progress was made, as Kabila continued to insist on the withdrawal of Ugandan and Rwandan troops before he would consider signing a ceasefire. On 27 October 1998, Chiluba was officially mandated to further press on with a peace initiative to end the war after consultations between regional foreign and defence ministers.

In early 1999, a consultative meeting with the states in the region was held in Lusaka under the auspices of Zambian President Frederick Jacob Titus Chiluba, who had been mandated as the chief mediator in October 1998. Libyan President al-Gaddafi continued his mediating efforts between Kabila and Museveni in Sirte on 18 April 1999, but none of the rebel factions were involved in these talks. Nevertheless, progress was made. President Kabila promised to start negotiations with Congolese rebels, while President Museveni promised to withdraw Uganda’s troops. Consequently, the Government of the DRC and the three rebel groups – the RCD, the RCD-ML, and the MLC – as well as Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe met in Lusaka in July, which led to the signing of the Lusaka Accord by the regional states on 10 July 1999, but RCD and MLC initially refuse to sign. The MLC signed the agreement on 1 August. On 31 August, after intense diplomatic pressure, all 50 founding members of the fractious RCD signed. Rebel leader Emile Ilunga and 41 of his deputies signed on behalf of the RCD. This was a compromise following dispute between the two RCD factions about which group had the right to sign.

Several preparatory meetings were held in early 2000. On 8 April 2000, the parties to the Lusaka agreement accepted a disengagement plan in Kampala in which they agreed to retreat their forces 15 km behind the frontlines.

On 4 May 2000, the three Congolese insurgent parties renewed their commitment to the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. The preparatory committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue subsequently continued to work on finding consensus on how the peace talks would proceed. After it was decided which parties should participate in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, the Government of the DRC suggested that the dialogue should be held in Kinshasa, but this suggestion was rejected by Masire. The Government became increasingly critical toward Masire, which eventually led to a declaration in which they stated to have lost their confidence in the Organization of African Unity mediator. Kabila considered him persona non grata and reportedly closed his offices in Kinshasa.
As a result, the Government boycotted a round of consultations organized by Masire in Benin in June.

By August, the parties had managed to agree on an agenda, the structure, the rules, the place, and the dates of the dialogue. In mid-October 2000, a regional summit was held in Mozambique hosted by Mozambican President, Joaquim Chissano, where the agreement that all fighters should withdraw 15 km from their positions was reiterated. Within the same month, South African President Thabo Mbeki managed to secure agreement to this withdrawal plan from all the rebel parties.

On 6 December 2000, RCD and the Congolese government both committed to a ceasefire agreement, the so-called Harare disengagement plan. In it, they reiterated the observation of the ceasefire, the retreat of troops 15 km behind the frontlines, the deployment of a peacekeeping force, and the withdrawal of foreign troops. This allowed the UN Security Council to adopt resolution 1332.

On 15 February 2001, all parties to the conflict met in Lusaka and agreed once again to disengage to positions occupied by their forces in May 2000. However, no timetable for the withdrawal was set. Moreover, Uganda and Rwanda insisted on maintaining a presence in the DRC until the ADF and Hutu militias were removed, while Kabila’s foreign allies refused to withdraw until Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi had moved out their troops from the DRC. When Laurent Kabila was assassinated on 16 January 2001, his son succeeded. He had a more welcoming attitude towards Masire. In early March 2001, Joseph Kabila invited Masire to Kinshasa and  promised to resume discussions with the mediator in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.
On the initiative of South Africa, the conflict parties (including the Mayi-Mayi militias) met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.
On 4 May 2001, representatives of the DRC Government and the principal rebel factions signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka.

In late August 2001, the parties met in Botswana and agreed that the official Inter-Congolese dialogue was to commence in mid-October in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. Attempting to outline areas of agreement, the Congolese government and RCD along with Mouvement pour la Liberation du Congo (MLC) signed the Acte d’Engagement in Gaborone on 24 August with Botswanan president Ketumile Masire acting as the lead mediator.

A subsequent preparatory meeting was held in Abuja in September before the dialogue opened in Addis Ababa on October 15, 2001. However, Kabila and MLC leader Bemba failed to attend the October meeting in Ethiopia. Furthermore, RCD boycotted the opening ceremony. Consequently, the talks at Addis Ababa only lasted for five days instead of the proposed 45 days.  The mediation effort was also plagued by financial problems. Donors had pledged $5 million for Masire’s office, but only $250,000 had been forthcoming for the Addis Ababa meeting. This forced the mediation team to ask the conflict parties to reduce their delegations at the very last minute.
In 2002, the Inter-Congolese Dialogue continued. Talks started in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February, but these broke down after one day, when the MLC boycotted the meeting.

The 362 delegates in Sun City split into five different committees to negotiate on political and legal matter; security and defense; social, cultural, and humanitarian affairs; economy and finance; and finally, peace and reconciliation. Niasse conducted three missions in the region between June and October during which he consulted with the main rebel leaders and the government officials. Importantly, on 30 July 2002, Rwandan and Congolese presidents, Kagame and Kabila signed an accord in Pretoria under Mbeki’s watch. description: In 2003, South Africa hosted continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks.
On 6 March, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted.
In late March, talks were held on integrating rebels into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period.
On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act.
agreement_name: Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act

description: In August 2004, the RCD left the Government of DRC for a short period after the Gatumba massacre of Congolese Tutsi refugees in Burundi in August 2004. On 1 September, they joined the Government again after South African President Thabo Mbeki held crisis talks with all parties.

The Congrès National pour la Défense du Peuple (CNDP) (English: National Congress for People’s Defense) led by General Laurent Nkunda Mihigo, a Kiynarwanda-speaking Tutsi from North Kivu, took up arms against the Government of the DRC in January 2006. Nkunda had been part of the RCD-Goma, but joined the national army after the peace process in 2003. Yet, rejecting the authority of the government, he defected and occupied Bukavu in May 2004. The UN negotiated his withdrawal from South Kivu, but in 2005, he called for overthrowing Kabila and quickly gathered support from RCD-Goma soldiers that defected from the national army. His troops clashed with the national army in January and August 2006. It was not until November 2006 that the conflict escalated beyond 25 battle-related deaths when CNDP attacked the DRC army in Sake (North Kivu). The UN called for talks between CNDP and the DRC government. The latter sent his interior minister, General Denis Kalume, to start the talks.  On 29 December 2006, the United Nations mission negotiated a ceasefire between the two sides.

On 1 January 2007, Rwanda mediated talks in Kigali between Laurent Nkunda representing CNDP and General Denis Kalume Numbi representing the Government of the DRC. The talks led to an informal agreement to integrate Nkunda’s fighters into the government forces located in North Kivu to carry out operations against the Forces démocratiques de libération du Rwanda (FDLR) (English: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda). They had agreed that Nkunda’s troops would be integrated into the national army with the system of Brassage, meaning that troops loyal to him would be mixed with troops loyal to the central government. However, rather than diluting Nkunda’s influence, this deal extended his influence beyond his original sphere of influence. It was agreed that if the FDLR would be defeated, the Banyamulenge refugees would be able to return to the DRC and Nkunda would go into exile. Yet, with armed violence escalating throughout the first half of 2007, the UN took a firmer stance and publically called the CNDP as “the single most serious threat to stability in the DR Congo” in July 2007.

The United Nations Organization Mission in the DR Congo (Zaire) (MONUC) mediated a new ceasefire on 6 September, which prevented CNDP to take control over Sake. However, fighting resumed on 24 September, when the Government of the DRC launched an operation against the CNDP involving more than 20,000 soldiers after it became apparent that the CNDP had failed to meet the deadline to disarm and integrate its fighters into the national army. Nevertheless, on 23 October, only 200 CNDP soldiers were sent to assembly points for integration, which spurred renewed negotiations. It was agreed that a peace conference, involving most armed groups in the region, was to be held at the end of the year. However, the conference was rescheduled to take place in January 2008.  On 15 October and 26 December 2007, CNDP declared unilateral ceasefires in anticipation of the peace talks. The UN had imposed sanctions as early as 2003. UN Security Council Resolution 1493 imposed an arms embargo to all armed parties in the DR Congo that had not been a party to The Final Act Peace Agreement concluded in April 2003, whereas Resolution 1596 imposed targeted travel and financial measures on individuals spoiling the peace process.

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held in Goma in January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abbé Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference, the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference was produced. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The FDLR or the Rwandan government did not participate in the talks. The role of the UN representatives was twofold. First, they served as observers in order to ensure the neutrality of the talks. Second, in addition to participating in the plenary meetings, the UN representatives held secret bilateral meetings with Government of the DRC and the CNDP leadership. The conference led to the conclusion of an immediate ceasefire under the Act d’Engagement, Nord Kivu on 23 January 2008, as well a promise by the CNDP to withdraw all of its fighters from the North Kivu province, and impunity for Nkunda’s forces. The agreement also enlisted the DRC government to remove FDLR forces from North Kivu, yet the CNDP remained dissatisfied with the results and they declared war on the FDLR. Consequently, the ceasefire did not hold and intense fighting took place throughout the rest of the year. Civilians blamed the UN, claiming that MONUC had done nothing to prevent the CNDP from advancing. The UN then prevented CNDP fighters from advancing on Goma. On 28 October 2008, fighting took place between CNDP and government-MONUC joined troops. The CNDP declared a unilateral ceasefire on 29 October. Yet, they broke it and advanced further.

Prior to the DNDP advance on Goma, on 8 May 2008, the Congolese government had agreed to negotiate with CNDP at the behest of Olusegun Obasanjo, the UN Secretary-General’s Special Envoy on the Great Lakes Region. Negotiations began in Nairobi in 8 December of this same year. This round proved unsuccessful as it was suspended on 21 December.

Negotiations between the Government of the DRC and CNDP began in Nairobi on 7 January 2009. Olusegun Obasanjo and Benjamin William Mkapa, former President of Tanzania and representing the AU, acted as the joint chief mediators. Obasanjo had been mandated by the UN Secretary-General on 8 December 2008, following a request by the Security Council on 29 October to appoint as Special Envoy to facilitate dialogue between the leaders of Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda and assist the Governments of the sub-region to address the challenges to peace and security posed by the continued presence and activities of armed groups in the eastern DR Congo (Zaire). On 16 January, a faction form CNDP signed a ceasefire agreement with the government.

The ongoing negotiations led to the conclusion of the Ihussi Accord on 23 March 2009. Dr. Désiré Kamanzi, Chairman of CNDP, signed the agreement on behalf of the CNDP and Raymond Tshibanda signed on behalf of the Government of the DRC.

Nyerere’s mediation efforts concentrated on making the government accept negotiations without conditions. However, Nyerere appeared to lose credibility and confidence among the conflict parties, mainly due to the ineffectiveness of his initiative to impose economic sanctions on Burundi after the 1996 coup as an instrument for bringing the parties closer to agreement. Prenegotiations between the conflict, mediated by Nyerere, took place in Arusha in August 1997, but the Government withdrew from discussions when it was clear that the embargo towards Burundi would not be completely revoked. Nyerere was also accused of being pro-Hutu. As a response, Nyerere offered to resign if the regional leaders decided that this efforts were impeding the peace process. In spite of some dissatisfaction with Nyerere as a mediator, the regional heads of state decided that Nyerere should continue to mediate at a summit in Arusha on 4 September 1997. The Organization of African Unity Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, attended the meetings that Nyerere held with the Government. The UN also organised joint conferences, which were aimed at supporting a dialogue between the warring parties.
Between March and April 1998, Nyerere held separate talks with all the conflict parties to prepare for comprehensive peace talks.

Accordingly, comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in Arusha, Tanzania, in June 1998. Although the parties which participated announced on 20 June 1998 their agreement to suspend the hostilities by 20 July and begin peace talks, the Government almost immediately distanced itself from the agreement.
In October 1998, a new round of talks were held in Arusha.

In January 1999, the sanctions imposed against Burundi by the countries in the region were lifted. This created some momentum and the Arusha commissions continued their work in mid-March 1999. In early July 1999, a fifth round of negotiations took place. However, little progress was made. In September, Nyerere health worsened and the Arusha process was suspended. However, the main negotiating parties met in the Tanzanian capital the same month, and good progress was reported. A degree of consensus on the integration of rebel forces into the military and on Buyoya’s transition programme was reached. Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eight Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Furthermore, the Regional Summit underscored the importance of urgently concluding the negotiations and called upon all the parties to “accelerate the momentum of the Burundi Peace Negotiations until the conclusion of a final peace agreement that will ensure lasting peace, genuine democracy and security for all.” Mandela adopted a more urgent and outspoken approach from the outset.
From early 2000 onwards, simultaneously to the Arusha talks, South African Deputy President Jacob Zuma engaged in shuttle diplomacy with the objective to secure a ceasefire, but without success.

The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations on 21 February. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system, and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.
third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

To increase the pressure, Mandela invited a number of Heads of State, including the US President Bill Clinton, and other senior international political figures to the August discussions. On the 28 August 2000, a peace agreement was signed: the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi.
third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: On 27 and 28 February 2001, a further round of discussions arranged by Mandela, were held in Arusha. The aim was to resolve the main remaining issues of disagreement. The regional Heads of States were attending the meeting.
third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: Discussions with political parties were held in Mwanza, Tanzania, in April, June, and August 1996, with Nyerere as mediator.  However, the Government objected to the possible participation of the CNDD. The CNDD for its part, set a number of conditions for participating in negotiations, including the return to barracks of Government troops. As a result, negotiations between the Government of Burundi and CNDD did not take place at Mwanza. Nyerere continued to try initiate negotiations been the conflict parties without conditions. However, Nyerere appeared to lose credibility and confidence among the warring parties, mainly due to the ineffectiveness of his initiative to impose economic sanctions on Burundi after the 1996 coup as an instrument for bringing the parties closer to agreement. The CNDD leadership participated in a round of talks mediated by the Sant’Egidio Community in Rome on 10 May 1997.

Prenegotiations between the conflict, mediated by Nyerere, took place in Arusha in August 1997, but the Government withdrew from discussions when it was clear that the embargo towards Burundi would not be completely revoked.  Nyerere was also accused of being pro-Hutu. The Organization of African Unity Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, attended meetings which Nyerere held with the Government. The UN also organised joint conferences, which were aimed at supporting a dialogue between the warring parties.
Between March and April 1998, Nyerere held separate talks with all the conflict parties to prepare for comprehensive peace talks. All parties agreed to negotiations without conditions by May.

Accordingly, comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in Arusha, Tanzania, in June 1998. Although the parties which participated announced on 20 June 1998 their agreement to suspend the hostilities by 20 July and begin peace talks, the Government almost immediately distanced itself from the agreement.
In October 1998, a new round of talks were held in Arusha.

In January 1999, the sanctions imposed against Burundi by the countries in the region were lifted. This created some momentum and the Arusha commissions continued their work in mid-March 1999. In early July 1999, a fifth round took place. However, little progress was made. In September, Nyerere health worsened and the Arusha process was suspended.

The main negotiating parties met in the Tanzanian capital the same month, and good progress was reported. A degree of consensus on the integration of rebel forces into the military and on Buyoya’s transition programme was reached. Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eight Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Furthermore, the Regional Summit underscored the importance of urgently concluding the negotiations and called upon all the parties to “accelerate the momentum of the Burundi Peace Negotiations until the conclusion of a final peace agreement that will ensure lasting peace, genuine democracy and security for all.” Mandela adopted a more urgent and outspoken approach from the outset.

In early 2000, simultaneously to the Arusha talks, South African Deputy President Jacob Zuma engaged in shuttle diplomacy between in the Government of Burundi and the CNDD with the objective to secure a ceasefire, but without success.

The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations in February 2000. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.
third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: The two sides met again on 2 December 2002 to sign a ceasefire that would begin on 30 December that same year.

Frolina conducted several minor attacks from the early 1990s onwards, but it was not until 21 November 1997 that the conflict between Frolina and the Government of Burundi escalated beyond 25 battle-related-deaths per year. Prenegotiations between the conflict, mediated by Nyerere, took place in Arusha in August 1997, but the Government withdrew from discussions when it was clear that the embargo towards Burundi would not be completely revoked.
Between March and April 1998, Nyerere held separate talks with all the conflict parties to prepare for comprehensive peace talks.

Accordingly, comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in Arusha, Tanzania, in June 1998. Although the parties which participated announced on 20 June 1998 their agreement to suspend the hostilities by 20 July and begin peace talks, the Government almost immediately distanced itself from the agreement.
In October 1998, a new round of talks were held in Arusha.

In January 1999, the sanctions imposed against Burundi by the countries in the region were lifted. This created some momentum and the Arusha commissions continued their work in mid-March 1999. In early July 1999, another round of negotiations took place. However, little progress was made. In September, Nyerere health worsened and the Arusha process was suspended.

However, the main negotiating parties met in the Tanzanian capital the same month, and good progress was reported. A degree of consensus on the integration of rebel forces into the military and on Buyoya’s transition programme was reached. Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eight Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Furthermore, the Regional Summit underscored the importance of urgently concluding the negotiations and called upon all the parties to “accelerate the momentum of the Burundi Peace Negotiations until the conclusion of a final peace agreement that will ensure lasting peace, genuine democracy and security for all.” Mandela adopted a more urgent and outspoken approach from the outset.
From early 2000 onwards, simultaneously to the Arusha talks, South African Deputy President Jacob Zuma engaged in shuttle diplomacy with the objective to secure a ceasefire, but without success.

The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations in February. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.

description: Comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in June 1998, but the Palipehutu-FNL was not invited to participate.The CNDD-FDD and the Palipehutu-FNL were invited for the first time to participate in negotiations in 2000, when Mandela became the chief mediator of the peace process. In March 2000, the rebel leaders told Mandela that they would join the Arusha talks, but eventually they refused to do so. Palipehutu-FNL thus did not sign the peace agreement on the 28 August 2000. On 20 September, Mandela arranged a meeting between the armed opposition groups, the Government of Burundi, and regional Heads of State. Palipehutu-FNL leader, Kossan Kabura, also attended this meeting, although he was only prepared to enter into discussions with the regional Heads of State.
third_party: Nelson Mandela; South Africa; UN; OAU; Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: President Buyoya met with CNDD-FDD leader Ndayikengurukiye in Gabon in January and in April 2001, but the Palipehutu-FNL leadership was not present. A framework for future negotiations was subsequently drafted at this meeting, but without any reference to Palipehutu-FNL.  In 2002, Jacob Zuma, the Deputy President of South Africa, mediated negotiations between the Burundian Government, the CNDD-FDD and a smaller faction within the Palipehutu-FNL, which led to the signing of a ceasefire on 7 October 2002.

In 2004, negotiations between the government and Palipehutu-FNL-Rwasa faction started in Netherlands on 8-21 January. The talks ended with a joint declaration calling for an end to violence in Burundi, but this ceasefire was soon broken. No new negotiations were held between the Government and Palipehutu-FNL in 2004. Palipehutu-FNL refused to negotiate with the Government if they did not stop their military action against them and the government refused to cease the military action until FNL agreed to negotiate. Although a unilateral ceasefire was declared by Palipehutu-FNL in April, it was broken within 24 hours. In August 2004, Palipehutu-FNL offered a ceasefire on the condition that refugees in Bujumbura Rural were allowed to return home and the agreement was implemented, but the Government did not accept this offer.

A round of negotiations between the Palipehutu-FNL and the Government of Burundi, mediated by South Africa, led to the signing of a ceasefire with the Government on 15 May 2005, but this ceasefire was broken by both the Government and the rebels. After an electoral victory of the former Hutu rebel group CNDD-FDD, prospects for successful negotiations seemed to have improved, yet repeated promises by Palipehutu-FNL to negotiate with the Government came to nothing.

Another round of negotiations between Palipehutu-FNL and the newly installed Burundian Government started on 29 May 2006. These talks were mediated by South Africa and took place in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Charles Nqakula, the Minister of Safety and Security of South Africa, acted as the chief mediator. Nqakula was mandated by South African President Thabo Mbeki, following a request from the leadership of the East African region of the African Union for South Africa to continue with mediation efforts in Burundi.

On 18 June 2006, the parties signed the Dar-Es- Salaam Agreement of Principles Towards Lasting Peace, Security and Stability in Burundi, in which the parties agreed on a two week ceasefire to negotiate a permanent ceasefire.  After this agreement talks primarily focused on Palipehutu-FNL’s wish to disband the Burundian armed forces and police and reconstruct them from scratch. The government instead wanted FNL integration into the existing structures, in line with earlier peace agreements in Burundi.
agreement_name: Dar-Es- Salaam Agreement of Principles Towards Lasting Peace, Security and Stability in Burundi

description: Palipehutu-FNL subsequently walked out of negotiations in mid-July.

The government and the Palipehutu-FNL signed the Comprehensive Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Burundi and the Palipehutu-FNL on 7 September 2006, which stipulated, among others, the cantonment of Palipehutu-FNL forces for demobilization or integration into the armed forces. Political power sharing and the transformation of Palipehutu-FNL into a political party were, however, not addressed. A joint verification and monitoring mechanism (JVMM) for the peace agreement, in which the AU and ONUB participated, was launched in October, after which some cantonment began. Temporary immunity was granted to ex-combatants in November. However, disputes over details of a final agreement continued. The AU was also involved in mediation through its establishment and participation in the monitoring and verification mechanism.
agreement_name: Comprehensive Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Burundi and the Palipehutu-FNL

description: After many postponements, the conflict parties met in February 2007 to discuss the implementation of the 2006 peace agreements. On 26 March 2007, Palipehutu-FNL suspended its participation in the JVMM after the Government refused to negotiate political issues and to release political prisoners.

On 17 June, face to face talks were held between Rwasa and President Nkurunziza, they again committed themselves to the peace process and the government agreed to release Palipehutu-FNL prisoners. As a result, the JVMM again began its work in July, but the Palipehutu-FNL again left the talks.
Negotiations between the government and Palipehutu-FNL led to a ceasefire agreement on 9 July, but this agreement was breached by both conflict parties.

After an unsuccessful offensive in April – and under strong international pressure – the Palipehutu-FNL returned to the negotiating table. A ceasefire was signed on 25 May, reaffirming the parties’ commitment to the 2006 agreement.
Further progress was made in Magaliesburg, South Africa, on 10 June 2008 where implementation was further discussed and agreed to in the Magaliesburg Declaration on the Burundian Peace Process.
In August 2008, face-to-face talks were held between rebel leader Agathon Rwasa and President Nkurunziza.

In October 2008, to mediate the final issues, South African Defence Minister Charles Nqakula, who had mediated between the parties, on behalf of the South African Facilitation, requested the help of the Regional Peace Initiative headed by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni presided over a one-day summit in December 2008 in Bujumbura, Burundi. The stated goal of this summit was “to break the stalemate which has struck the Peace Process in Burundi with the objective of finding a lasting solution.” When the final issues were resolved and a peace agreement signed, removing the final obstacles for the transformation of Palipehutu-FNL into a political party. The Government agreed to integrate Palipehutu-FNL into the political process and to grant government positions to 33 of its senior members.  President Nkurunziza and Palipehutu-FNL leader Agathon Rwasa subsequently met in Bujumbura on 8 December 2008 to sign the Declaration of the Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the Great Lakes region on the Burundi Peace Process.
agreement_name: Declaration of the Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the Great Lakes region on the Burundi Peace Process

description: Prior to the official split the CNDD-FDD leadership had engaged in secret peace talks with the Government of Burundi. The Community of Sant’Egidio mediated the talks, which were initiated in Rome in September 1996. These negotiations were not intended to complement the regional initiative, rather to substitute it. Father Matteo Zuppi of the Community of Sant’Egidio acted as the chief mediator at these talks. During another round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio in February 1997, both delegations agreed on an agenda for further talks. However, it became apparent during negotiations in Rome that while the CNDD-FDD demanded the reinstatement of the 1992 constitution, the Government wanted to draft a new one.
The Sant'Egidio talks broke down following another round of negotiations in May 1997.

The Conseil national pour la défense de la démocratie-Forces pour la défense de la démocratie (CNDD-FDD) (English: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy) officially split from the CNDD in May 1998, just before the Arusha peace negotiations mediated by Julius Nyerere were about to start. The CNDD-FDD did not participate in the Arusha negotiations between 1998 and 1999. One of the reasons for this is that CNDD-FDD leader Ndayikengurukiye protested against Nyerere’s endorsement of Nyangoma as the leader of CNDD. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1998. The CNDD-FDD was invited for the first time to participate in negotiations in 2000, when Mandela became the chief mediator of the peace process. In March 2000, the rebel leaders told Mandela that they would join the Arusha talks, but eventually they refused to do so. However, Mandela conducted talks with the leadership of CNDD-FDD and the Palipehutu-FNL. He also met with senior army commanders. On 20 September, Mandela arranged a meeting between the militia leadership, the Burundi government and regional Heads of State, but CNDD-FDD leader Ndayingengurukiye did not attend this meeting. In January 2001, President Buyoya met with CNDD-FDD leader Ndayingengurukiye in Gabon for peace talks mediated by the President of Gabon, Omar Bongo. The parties agreed on an agenda for negotiations. In April 2001, Bongo mediated between Ndayikengurukiye and the DRC President Kabila one the one hand, and with Buyoya on the other hand. These talks were held in Pretoria. Jacob Zuma, the Deputy President of South Africa, also acted as mediator at these talks. Zuma had been mandated by Mandela in January 2001 to mediate, as Mandela was focusing on mediating the implementation of the Aruscha accords. No success was achieved at Pertoria. Ndayikengurukiye subsequently questioned South Africa’s continued role in the process.

Nevertheless, in early August 2001, it was announced that Mandela had succeeded in subduing continuing opposition from the CNDD-FDD to the continuation of Buyoya in the presidency. The Implementation Monitoring Commission, established under UN leadership to oversee the transition, had held its first substantive meeting on 19 March 2001. However, the IMC made little progress, since most of the parties merely restated their demands and negotiation positions.

Official negotiations between the Government of Burundi and CNDD-FDD started in 2002. Jacob Zuma, mediated these talks. Zuma’s mandate, initially given by Mandela, was reinforced at the 19th regional summit on Burundi. In February 2002, the Nkurunziza faction of the CNDD-FDD participated in talks with the government, mediated by Jacob Zuma, in Vaal Dam.
On 30 August 2002, the two sides signed memorandums of understanding regarding the peace efforts.

The smaller faction of CNDD-FDD had already concluded an agreement with the government on 7 October 2002, preparing the fighters of this faction for inclusion of the rebels both in the transitional government and in the army. Later, on 29 October, the CNDD-FDD would announce a unilateral ceasefire as negotiations were ongoing with the government in Dar es Salaam.
Negotiations between the government and the Nkurunziza faction, in Kampala in November 2002, started to concern the central issues.
With Zuma as lead mediator, the smaller faction of CNDD-FDD and government signed a ceasefire agreement together on 3 December.

Subsequently, the Burundian Government and the Nkurunziza faction signed a ceasefire on 2 December. It was agreed that the agreement – referred to as the Ceasefire Agreement between the Transitional Government of Burundi and the Conseil national pour la défense de ladémocratie-Forces pour la défense de la démocratie – would take effect on 30 December.
agreement_name: Ceasefire Agreement between the Transitional Government of Burundi and the Conseil national pour la défense de ladémocratie-Forces pour la défense de la démocratie

description: The CNDD-FDD and the government of Burundi re-affirmed their commitment to the 2002 agreement on 27 January 2003.
Negotiations were suspended on 21 February after CNDD-FDD accused the government of blocking the implementation of the agreement.

On 8 August, CNDD-FDD became a political party. Mediation conducted by Zuma subsequently led to the conclusion of three new peace agreements: the first being, the Pretoria Protocol on Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing in Burundi concluded on 8 October 2003.
agreement_name: Pretoria Protocol on Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing in Burundi

description: Mediation conducted by Zuma subsequently led to the conclusion of three new peace agreements: the second being,  the Pretoria Protocol on Outstanding Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing Issues in Burundi concluded on 2 November 2003.
agreement_name: Pretoria Protocol on Outstanding Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing Issues in Burundi

description: Mediation conducted by Zuma subsequently led to the conclusion of three new peace agreements:the third being, the Global Ceasefire agreement between CNDD-FDD of Mr. Nkúrunziza concluded on 16 November 2003.
agreement_name: Global Ceasefire agreement between CNDD-FDD of Mr. Nkúrunziza

description: The ensuing fighting killed at least 25 people by 31 December and around 100 people by 2 January 1992. In late June 1992, the Government of Chad and MDD representatives met in Gabon for talks mediated by President Omar Bongo, which led to the conclusion of the Libreville Agreement on 24 June 1992 in Libreville, Gabon. The agreement was signed by Health Minister of the Chadian Government, Ali Mahamat Zene Ali Fadel, and the vice-president of MDD, Brahim Malla Mahamat. The agreement failed to be implemented, as government forces attacked the MDD fighters at Lagasula in the Lake Chad region on 18 October 1992.
In 1995, negotiations, without the involvement of any third party, led to signing of an agreement in Dougia, Chad, on 22 November.

In January 1996, the MDD took part in the inter-Chadian table talks between the Government and various opposition groups. The talks, which were hosted by Gabon, concerned the legalisation of rebel groups as political parties and the reorganisation of the defence and security forces. The talks were mediated by the Presidents of the Central African Republic, Gabon, and Niger.  The involvement of the Central African Republic and Gabon was based on a mandate stipulated in the Bangui-2 Agreement, signed on 11 August 1994, which set up committee – consisting of the Central African Republic, France, Gabon and the UNHCR – to oversee the implementation of the agreement.
Niger helped to mediate a peace accord in Zinder on 30 September.

On 20 May 1998, the Chadian Government held talks with the MDD. President Ibrahim Bare Mainassara of Niger mediated these talks. The negotiations focused on the right of return for MDD fighters based in Niger, after which the MDD fighters in Niger agreed to lay down their weapons and return to Chad.
Sudanese mediation between the Chadian government and the MDD led to the signing of the Reconciliation Agreement in Khartoum on 3 July 1999.

In August 1993, Libya and Sudan mediated peace talks between the Government of Chad and the CNR. It is only known that the talks at least concerned the right of return for the CNR’s leader, Colonel Abbas Koty. The negotiations led to the signing of an initial peace accord on 15 August 1993.
A second round of negotiations led to another accord on 16 October 1993: the Tripoli-1 Agreement.

Sudan mediated another round of negotiations in February 1995, which allegedly led to the signing of a peace agreement by the new leader of CNR Adoum Idriss, who replaced Koty after his death. However, since the CNR denies it signed this peace agreement, this dyad-year is coded as not having experienced the conclusion of a peace agreement.
Negotiations started in Bangui in the Central African Republic (CAR) in February 1993. These negotiations mediated by CAR did not succeed.
Nevertheless, the conflict parties agreed in a round of bilateral negotiations on a ceasefire in June 1993.

In October 1993, CSNPD leader Kette declared that the CSNPD was willing to initiate new negotiations with the Government. The Central African Republic continued to mediate between the Chadian Government and the CSNPD in 1994. Negotiations started in Bangui on 22 February 1994. The conflict parties concluded a ceasefire on 26 February 1994.
Another round of negotiations led to the signing of the Bangui-2 Agreement on 11 August 1994.

The Front national tchadien (FNT) (English: Chad National Front) took up arms against the Government of Chad in 1992 to create an Islamic State in the region of Ouada. In 1992, several rounds of negotiations between the Chad National Front (FNT) and Chadian Government representatives, mediated by Sudan, took place in Judnaynah, Sudan. A first round of negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 September 1992. The conflict parties further agreed that the FNT fighters would disarm within two months. In return, the government provided an amnesty to all imprisoned FNT members.

Another round of talks led to the signing of the El Geneina Agreement on 31 October 1992. The agreement was signed in Judnaynah, Sudan, as well as El Geneina, which is located on the border of Chad and Sudan.

On 13 and 14 May 1993, talks took place concerning the terms for a truce, the legalisation of the FNT as a political party, and for the return of the FNT leader, Harris Bachar, from exile. No third parties were involved in these talks.

On 12 October 1994, an eight-point peace agreement was signed in Abeche between the FNT rebels and the government of Chad. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to this peace agreement.
In 1997, Sudan conducted mediation between the Chadian government and the FNT, which led to the signing of the National Reconciliation Agreement on 3 October 1997 in N’Djamena.
A round of negotiations without the involvement of a third party led to the signing of a ceasefire on 27 August 1996. The ceasefire did not hold.
On 7 May 1998, the Chadian Government and the FARF signed the the Donya agreement in Donya, Chad. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to the conclusion of this peace agreement.

Although Togoimi had spoken out against any negotiations with the Government, Libya mediated a series of talks between the Chadian government and the Mouvement pour la démocratie et la justice au Tchad (MDJT) (Movement for Democracy and Justice) in Sirte in September 2000. Both MDJT leader Youssouf Togoimi and Chadian president Idriss Deby participated in the negotiations. Muammar al-Gaddafi, the ruler of Libya, acted as the chief mediator during this peace initiative. As observed in a report by the International Crisis Group, the “Libyan leader has always considered the country as being in his backyard, his exclusive domain. President Gaddafi has therefore gradually imposed himself as someone who cannot be ignored in relation to resolving the conflicts in which Chad is involved, whether they are internal or international conflicts.” Issues addressed in the talks concerned an amnesty for the rebels, the integration of MDJT fighters into the Chadian forces and transparency in the election process. The talks, however, did not yield concrete results and the government forces launched a major offensive on rebel positions only a few months later.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Libya started on 5 January 2002. These negotiations were mediated by Libya’s African unity minister Ali Abdel Salam Triki. The negotiations led to the signing of the Tripoli agreement on 7 January 2002.

Burkina Faso mediated a round of negotiations between the Chadian government and the MDJT in December 2003. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 14 December 2003. The ceasefire document – titled the Peace Agreement between the Government of Chad and the Movement pur la démocratie et la justice au Tchad (MDJT) – also provided for an amnesty for MDJT fighters and supporters and the appointment of an undisclosed number of MDJT ministers in the government. A number of hard-liner MDJT fighters rejected the ceasefire signed by MDJT leader Adoum Togoi.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between the Government of Chad and the Movement pur la démocratie et la justice au Tchad (MDJT)

description: On 18 August 2005, another peace agreement was signed: the Yebibou agreement 2005. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to the conclusion of this peace agreement.

On 13 April 2006, the FUCD tried to take control over the capital city N’djamena. However, the government succeeded in repelling the rebels and remained in control over the city. Later in the year, the FUCD began negotiations with the government, which were mediated by Libyan President Muammar al-Gaddafi. This resulted in the signing of the Tripoli accord by the leader of FUCD Mahamat Nour Abdulkerim and the Chadian president Idriss Déby in Tripoli on 24 December 2006. The FUCD was part of the Union des Forces pour la Démocratie et le Développement (UFDD) (English: Union for Democracy and Development) alliance, of which other groups besides the UFDD criticised these negotiations and the subsequent peace agreement. As a result, the FUCD broke away from UFDD alliance.

Negotiations between the Government of Chad and the RAFD started in Sirte, Libya in July 2007. The Union des Forces pour la Démocratie et le Développement (UFDD) (English: Union for Democracy and Development) rebel alliance was also involved in these negotiations. Sudanese diplomats supported the Libyan-led mediation effort.
The negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 4 October 2007. This ceasefire also a stipulated an amnesty for civil and military personnel and the release of all detainees from both sides.

Continued negotiations led to the signing of a peace agreement in Sirte 25 October 2007. Libyan President Muammar al-Gaddafi acted as the chief mediator. In order to move the conflict parties towards compromise, al-Gaddafi offered a significant sum of money to some leaders of the rebel movement if they would join the Government of Chad. The Sirte agreement held just for a month then fighting erupted again. The rebels stated that they took up arms again because of the lack of implementation of the agreement.

Negotiations between the Government of Chad and the UFDD started in Sirte, Libya in July 2007. The RAFD was also involved in these negotiations. Sudanese diplomats supported the Libyan-led mediation effort.
The negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 4 October 2007. This ceasefire also a stipulated an amnesty for civil and military personnel and the release of all detainees from both sides.

Continued negotiations led to the signing of a peace agreement in Sirte 25 October 2007. Libyan President Muammar al-Gaddafi acted as the chief mediator. In order to move the conflict parties towards compromise, al-Gaddafi offered a significant sum of money to some leaders of the rebel movement if they would join the Government of Chad. The Sirte agreement held just for a month then fighting erupted again. The rebels stated that they took up arms again because of the lack of implementation of the agreement.
No mediation or negotiations took place in 2008, but Libya mediated another round of negotiations in July 2009. This led to the signing of peace agreement on 26 July 2009.
Negotiations between UFR and the Chadian government took place in August 2010, resulting in the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

In June 2011, the Central African Republic mediated between the Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR), which was part of the UFR alliance, and the Chadian government. Paulin Pomodimo acted as the chief mediator. This mediation effort led to the Communiqué Final sanctionnant la rencontre entre la délégation officielle tchadienne et le Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR) signed on 13 June 2011.
agreement_name: Communiqué Final sanctionnant la rencontre entre la délégation officielle tchadienne et le Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR)

description: In July 2009, a second face of the conflict started as violent clashes broke out in northern Nigeria between security forces and Jama’atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda’awati wal-Jihad (English: English: Group Committed to Propagating the Prophet’s Teachings and Jihad), commonly called Boko Haram (English: Western education is sinful). The radical Islamic sect sought to topple the government and set up puritanical Islamic rule throughout Nigeria. On 2 August 2011, the government set up an eight-member committee led by Usman Galtimari, its former envoy to Chad, to study the Boko Haram security challenge and advise on ending the violence. Its report, submitted on 26 September 2011, recommended talks and amnesty for sect members who renounce violence. A preliminary round of negotiations between the conflict parties took place in Maiduguri on 16 September 2011. Former President Olusegun Obasanjo led the government delegation. Boko Haram laid out conditions for a temporary ceasefire during these negotiations, which were an end to arrests and killings of Boko Haram members and compensation for families of members killed by security personnel.
Government and Boko Haram representatives engaged in negotiations in January 2013. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 28 January 2013.

In May 2013, President Goodluck Jonathan established a committee to negotiate a settlement with the Boko Haram leadership. A round of negotiations between this committee and Boko Haram led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 8 July 2013.

Following a round of negotiations in October 2014, Boko Haram and the Government of Nigeria signed a ceasefire on 17 October 2014. The ceasefire agreement included the release of around 200 schoolgirls that had been abduced from a school in Chibok by Boko Haram. However, Boko Haram later denied it had signed a ceasefire.
Another round of negotiations on a ceasefire and the relase of the schoolgirls from Chibok started in July 2015. These talks began shortly after President Muhammadu Buhari took office.
A new round of talks on the release of the school girls and a ceasefire in November 2015 also broke down.

In October 2016, Switzerland and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) mediated between the Government of Nigeria and Boko Haram. Boko Haram subsequently freed 21 of around 220 girls from Chibok.
third_party: Switzerland; International Committee of the Red Cross

description: Nigeria’s information minister Lai Mohammed announced in March 2018 that government represenatives were negotiating with Boko Haram. The talks were aimed at securing a permanent cessation of hostilities.
Aisha Wakil, a Nigerian lawyer, mediated negotiations between Boko Haram and the Government of Nigeria in January 2019.
Nigeria mediated a round of negtiations between the conflict parties in Abuja on 4 October 2000, but the negotiations did not lead to any tangible outcome.
Nigeria mediated another round of negotiations on 28 December in 2000, but this did not lead to any progress in the peace process.

Negotiations between the Sudanese government and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army (SPLM/A) took place for the first time on 31 July 1986, when John Garang and Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi met for talks in which the two key demands of the SLPM/A were discussed: the suspension of the Sharia and the termination of military pacts with Libya and Egypt. However, on 16 August 1986, the peace talks were suspended due to the SPLM/A bombing a civil airplane, which resulted in the death of 60 passengers. Egypt – in spite of its military support to the Government of Sudan – managed to facilitate contacts between the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and SPLM/A in the mid-1988. The DUP was one of the three parties in Khartoum’s ruling coalition. Ethiopia subsequently offered to host talks in Addis Ababa between the DUP and the SPLM/A. This led to the signing of what has been referred to as the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement on 16 November 1988 by DUP leader Mohamed Osman al-Mirghani and SPLM/A leader John Garang de Mabior. However, the agreement soon collapsed as a result of an internal power struggle within the Government of Sudan. The opposition in the coalition government, the National Islamic Front (NIF), did not accept the peace agreement, as it wished to maintain Islamic law and refused to abrogate military pacts with Egypt and Libya. The NIF denounced the talks as a conspiracy to block Islamic law. Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi voted down a DUP amendment to recognise the terms of the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement. Consequently, the DUP resigned from government on 27 December 1988. In March 1989, a new Government assumed power, which proposed a peace plan that was based on the peace deal that was reached between SPLM/A and DUP in November 1988, calling for a freeze on Islamic laws. The UN became involved in April 1989, trying to make both parties accept a ceasefire.

At a meeting on 1 May 1989, the UN managed to convince the conflict parties observe a “month of tranquility” to allow aid to reach the area where people are threatened with famine. This ceasefire was later extended for another two weeks. The Government of Sudan subsequently accepted the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement, after which it was also ratified by the parliament.
The parties met for negotiations in Addis Ababa in May 1989.

Following the collapse of the Carter initiative, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi invited Bashir and Garang to his Presidential retreat in Nakuru for peace talks. Both Bashir and Garang accepted the invitation and the meeting was set for 27 February 1990. However, at the last minute Garang decided not to go, so only Bashir showed up.  Similarly, Zaire and Egypt mediated in 1990, but could not bring the conflict parties to the negotiation table. The Government of Sudan took the initiative in March 1990 to request the US to mediate. The US subsequently initiated a mediation effort. In order to move the conflict parties towards a peace settlement, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Herman Cohen began to shuttle between the conflict parties in March 1990. Cohen formulated a proposal that stipulated the conclusion of a ceasefire, withdrawal of troops, followed by a constitutional conference that would decide on a federal system. With regard to the withdrawal of troops, Cohen proposed the complete evacuation of the national army to positions north of the 11th parallel, while the SPLM/A had to guarantee that it would not take control of southern Sudan militarily if the government forces would withdraw. With neither conflict party agreeing to this proposal, Cohen subsequently formulated a new proposal, which stipulated that half of the government forces would be pulled out from southern Sudan, while the SPLM/A would in exchange withdraw all its troops 15 kilometres from the besieged towns. Moreover, the withdrawal of troops would be internationally monitored. Cohen also proposed to hold a constitutional conference . Cohen personally presented the adapted proposal to President al-Bashir in Khartoum on 9 March 1990. While al-Bashir promised Cohen to study the proposal carefully, he soon conveyed that he rejected the possibility of a constitutional conference, preferring bilateral talks with John Garrang. The Government of Sudan also refused to withdraw from some garrison towns in areas controlled by the rebels including some oil fields.  This terminated his round of shuttle talks in March 1990. In May, Cohen again tried to imitate a peace conference, but the government side officially rejected this option on 4 June 1990.

The mediation efforts of the US continued in early January 1991. Yet, diplomatic relations between the US and Sudan severely deteriorated due to the US military action against Iraq on 17 January 1991. As a result, the Sudanese-American dialogue felt silent. In March 1991, the Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity Salim Ahmed Salim offered his good offices to restart the peace process. Salim shuttled between the conflict parties and his efforts led to the conflict parties accepting mediation by the Organization of African Unity and Nigeria. Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, who assumed Organization of African Unity Chairmanship on 3 June 1991, acted as the chief mediator of these negotiations. In spite of separate consultations, Nigeria and the Organization of African Unity did not mediate any direct peace talks between the conflict parties in 1991. Although the negotiations were set to take place in the fall of 1991, they were postponed until May 1992 because of divisions within the ranks of the SPLM/A.

The first phase of what came to be known as the Abuja peace talks started on 26 May 1992 and ended on 4 June 1992 without any progress made. The talks were hosted by the Nigerian president Ibrahim Babangida in his capacity as chair of the Organization of African Unity. Talks focus particularly on issues related to national identity, religion and state, self-determination, and interim security arrangements. The Nigerian mediators suggested to the conflict parties that an effective ceasefire would require a neutral observer team that would ensure all the parties complied with the peace agreement. Although the SPLM/A agreed, the Government of Sudan insisted that such a team would constitute “foreign intervention in the affairs of Sudan.” The first phase of the Abuja negotiations ended with the adoption of the Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference.
agreement_name: Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference

description: IGAD hosted and sponsored several rounds of peace talks throughout 1994. Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi hosted the talks as chairman of IGAD. Preliminary shuttle peace talks were held in Nairobi in the beginning of January in order to determine the issues that would be put on the agenda for the formal talks.
Although the parties had not reached a consensus over an agenda for the negotiations, a first round of official negotiations was held in Nairobi between 8 and 23 March 1994.
Another round of negotiations was held in Nairobi were held between 18 and 20 May 1994.

Since the conflict parties could not agree on an official agenda for negotiations, the IGAD mediation team drafted a Declaration of Principles (DoP) which the conflict parties were meant to review in preparation for a third round of negotiations in July 1994. The compromise envisioned in the DoP was that while the south would have the right to self-determination because of the high level of polarization in Sudan, priority should be given to unity to be created through a national consensus.

Another round of negotiations was subsequently held in Nairobi between 18 and 28 July 1994. While the SPLM/A accepted the DoP, the government side rejected the document. Nevertheless, on 23 July 1994, the Government of Sudan declared a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was initially rejected by SPLM/A, but was eventually accepted. The ceasefire was later broken, probably by both sides.

The parties met again for IGAD-sponsored negotiations in Nairobi between 5 and 7 September 1994, but the talks again ended in a deadlock. Earlier in the year, between May and July, various Western diplomatic initiatives were coordinated in a new grouping, named the Friends of IGAD. The goal of this contact group was to increase the leverage of the IGAD mediation efforts.

In 1995, former US president Jimmy Carter managed to conduct shuttle mediation between the conflict parties, which led to a two-month ceasefire that was unilaterally announced by the Government of Sudan on 28 March 1995. The two-month ceasefire would help a health campaign organized by the Carter Center against Guinea worm infestation and river blindness in the south.  In addition to the ceasefire, the rebels were offered amnesty if they laid down their weapons. The SPLM/A accepted the ceasefire two days later on 1 June 1995, although some elements within the organisation rejected the ceasefire. The SPLM/A also called for international monitoring of the ceasefire. According to Carter, the ceasefire was holding with a few minor exceptions. Yet, the conflict parties accused each other of violating the ceasefire. In August 1995, the conflict parties agreed to resume peace talks, but not to extend the ceasefire. Yet, the talks never took place.

In April 1996, the Sudanese government engaged in negotiations with some breakaway groups of the SPLM/A. This led to the conclusion of the Political Charter on 10 April 1996. A round of negotiations between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government in July 1996, focusing on the Nuba Mountains, led to the conclusion of the Declaration of Principles for the Resolution of the Nuba Mountains’ Problem on 31 July 1996.
agreement_name: Declaration of Principles for the Resolution of the Nuba Mountains’ Problem

description: In addition to negotiations between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government, the Sudanese government engaged in negotiations with the breakaway group of the SPLM/A, the SPLM/A-Nasir faction. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 21 April 1997, referred to as the Khartoum Agreement.

South African President Nelson Mandela held separate discussions with the conflict parties and succeeded in initiating direct talks, which began on 28 August 1997 in Nairobi under the aegis of IGAD. These talks were chaired by Kenyan Foreign Minister Kalonzo Musyoka, but representatives of Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Uganda were all participating in the mediation process.
third_party: IGAD; South Africa; Kenya; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda

description: At this IGAD summit in Nairobi in July 1997, Kenyan President Moi succeeded in convincing President al-Bashir to finally accept the DoP and resume direct negotiations with the SPLM/A in October 1997.
