While the IGAD mediators tried to push the conflict parties to discuss how the DoP could be transformed in a sustained negations process, the negotiations that were held in October 1997 remained deadlocked on the issue of secularism, but also on the modalities of a referendum and the length of the transition period. When talks broke down again, the IGAD mediators issue a communique on 11 November 1997, which stated that the IGAD mediators would shuttle between the adversaries, but that direct negotiations would be adjourned until April 1998

The conflict parties resumed peace talks in Nairobi on 4 May 1998, under the auspices of IGAD. Not wanting to appear as an obstructionist, the Sudanese government accepted self-determination for the south on the basis of a referendum during this round of talks.

On 15 July, the SPLM/A declared a 3-month ceasefire in Bahr el-Ghazal in order to facilitate humanitarian aid. The Government of Sudan accepted the ceasefire. In August, the Government of Sudan extended the ceasefire throughout southern Sudan, but this was rejected by the SPLM/A.

Another round of IGAD-sponsored peace talks was held in Addis Ababa between 6 and 8 August. This round of talks was also attended by Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity Salim Ahmed Salim.
In October, the humanitarian ceasefire was extended by both parties for another 3 months.
The humanitarian ceasefire was continuously extended by both parties for 3 month-periods throughout 1999.

Up until 1999, the Kenyan minister of Foreign Affairs had acted as the chief mediator of the peace talks, but it was decided in mid-1999 that a mediator needed to be appointed that could lead sustained negotiations. To this end, Daniel Mboya, the former Kenyan Ambassador to Sudan, was appointed. IGAD-sponsored peace talks were resumed in Nairobi on 20 July 1999. The parties agreed on procedural issues for further talks, but they failed to make any progress on substantial issues pertaining to a comprehensive ceasefire, self-determination for the south, defining a border, and the relation between religion and state.
Former vice-president of Sudan Abel Alier separately consulted Garang and Bashir, after which he proposed a confederal solution to the conflict. This was rejected by the Government of Sudan.

A round of negotiations mediated by IGAD took place in January 2000. After this round of negotiations, the parties issued a joint communiqué in which they reiterated their commitment to a peaceful solution and said they agreed on self-determination for the people of southern Sudan.

Additionally, the UN was also involved in mediation between the conflict parties in a round of shuttle negotiations in February 2000. The goal of this UN mediation effort was to conclude a humanitarian ceasefire to allow for the vaccination of 54,000 children in the Nuba mountains. This mediation effort was successful. The conflict parties agreed on a three-day ceasefire in February 2000.
Another second three-day ceasefire was brokered in March 2000.

Another IGAD-mediated round of negotiations took place between 21 and 30 September 2000. During this round of peace talks, the mediators proposed a two-tier arrangement in which all institutions on a national level were to be neutral on religion. This proposal was accepted by the SPLM/A, but rejected by the Government of Sudan.

Another IGAD-mediated round of negotiations took place between 21 and 30 September 2000. During this round of peace talks, the mediators proposed a two-tier arrangement in which all institutions on a national level were to be neutral on religion. This proposal was accepted by the SPLM/A, but rejected by the Government of Sudan.
Pre-negotiations took place in Buergenstock in December 2001.

The Government of Sudan and the SPLM/A met for a week of talks in Buergenstock in January 2002. The mediation team included both American and Swiss diplomats and the Swiss Ambassador Josef Bucher acted as the chief mediator. After six days of negotiations, the conflict parties concluded a ceasefire pertaining to the Nuba Mountains on 19 January 2002. It was agreed that the ceasefire in Nuba Mountains would monitored by Britain, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Switzerland and the US. The peace talks in Switzerland were coordinated with IGAD and thus complementary to the IGAD-led peace process.

Negotiations mediated by IGAD were resumed in Machakos in June 2002. The mediation team at Machakos was led by Kenyan General Lazaro Sumbeiywo. Although Kenya chaired the peace talks, diplomats from Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda were also heavily involved. Moreover, there was active engagement from the four official observer countries in the peace process: the UK, the US, Norway and Italy. As soon as the talks at Machakos started, the conflict parties agreed to extend the ceasefire in the Nuba Mountains for another six-month period.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: On 20 July 2002, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan signed the Machakos Protocol. The peace agreement stipulated the general procedures for a transitional process, but also committed the conflict parties to engage in further negotiations to specify the terms of the framework.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Negotiations were resumed in Machakos on 12 August 2002, but collapsed on 2 September 2002 after the SPLM/A seized the strategically important town of Torit.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Nevertheless, the adversaries engaged in another round of IGAD-mediated negotiations between October and November 2002. At the start of this round, the conflict parties signed an initial ceasefire on 15 October 2002, referred to as the Memorandum of Understanding on Cessation of Hostilities.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: On 18 November 2002, when negotiations closed for the year, a Memorandum of Understanding was signed, but no comprehensive agreement had been reached. The talks were adjourned until 6 January 2003, due to Ramadan, Christmas, and the Kenyan elections.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: However, the parties were invited to Washington for informal talks on 19 and 20 December 2002. The US became more involved during 2002. In addition to attending and organising peace talks, it had issued the Sudan Peace Act. This act authorised the President of the US to seek a UN Security Council resolution for an arms embargo and to actively seek other financial and diplomatic methods to influence the conduct of the Sudanese Government. The US held out the prospects of trade and development aid opportunities, as well as a normalization of relations.

IGAD-negotiations, led by the chief mediator Lazaro Sumbeiywo, continued in 2003 throughout the entire year. The US, the UK, Norway and Italy all had observer status during the talks and took part in the mediation. Norway also funded the peace talks. The Arab League announced in May 2003 that it would also begin attending the peace talks as an observer. Ambassador Samir Hosni, Director of the Arab-African cooperation at the Arab League subsequently attended the meetings. In spite of some clashes in early 2003, negotiations started on 23 January 2003. The talks focused on power and wealth sharing.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: The implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding on Cessation of Hostilities signed on 15 October 2002 was further improved during a round of negotiations in February 2003, with the signing an addendum to the MOU on 4 February 2003, which created a Verification and Monitoring Team (VMT). The VMT consisted of international observers to verify accusations of ceasefire violations. The conflict parties also agreed to cede control of areas captured since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in October 2002. With regard to the issue of power sharing, the conflict parties agreed on a framework of a government of national unity in which the SPLM/A would be a major partner.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Another round of negotiations, which started on 4 March 2003, focused on the status of three disputed areas – the Nuba Mountains, Southern Blue Nile, and Abyei – though with limited progress. A major turning point in the peace process occurred at a meeting on 2 April, when President Omar al-Bashir and SPLM/A leader John Garang met and shook hands.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: A new round of talks, addressing security issues, started on 7 April, but was stalemated on how to unify the national army.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: A new round negotiations on security issues was held in May 2003.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Another round of negotiations was held in June 2003.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Yet another round of negotiations on security issues was held in August 2003. None of these rounds of talks resulted in much progress. Nevertheless, the ceasefire, which was due to expire on 30 June, was extended by both parties.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: The peace process took a positive turn when Vice President Ali Osman Mohamed Taha and John Garang entered into negotiations on 4 September 2003.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Subsequent discussions on power sharing and security issues resulted in the signing of the Agreement on Security Arrangements During the Interim Period on 25 September 2003. The ceasefire was also extended by two months.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy
agreement_name: Ceasefire; Agreement on Security Arrangements During the Interim Period

description: On 7 October 2003, the delegations met again for further talks. After nine days of the beginning of these talks, Taha and Garang arrived to continue negotiations, which lasted until 26 October.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Another round of negotiations started again on 30 November.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: On 7 December, Taha and Garang arrived to take part in this round of negotiations. This resulted in the parties agreeing in principle on a 50-50 sharing of oil wealth in the south during the interim period.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Throughout 2004, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan held negotiations in Kenya based on the process agreed on in the Machakos Protocol singed in 2002. The continuous negotiations resulted in the signing of several protocols and agreements that were to make up the foundation of the final Comprehensive Peace Agreement. During a round of negotiations in Naivasha in January 2004, the Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period was signed on 7 January 2004.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy
agreement_name: Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period

description: The next round of talks in May 2004  resulted in the signing of three agreements in Naivasha on 26 May: the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States on 26 May 2004, the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area on 26 May 2004, and the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing on 26 May 2004. The conclusion of the three agreements finalised the political negotiations. The only issues that still needed to be addressed were the more technical issues of a comprehensive ceasefire, security arrangements, and the implementation of the peace agreement. However, during the two months after signing of the three peace agreements, the Government of Sudan claimed to be too busy with the situation in Darfur.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy
agreement_name: Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States; the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area; and the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing

description: On 7 October 2004, Garang and Taha started another round of negotiations.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: On 19 November, the government and SPLM/A signed a Memorandum of Understanding, committing the conflict parties to sign a comprehensive peace agreement no later than 31 December 2004.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Consequently, talks between Garang and Taha resumed again on 7 December 2004 and continued until Christmas Eve. The parties marked the end of the conflict on 31 December 2004 by the signing of a permanent ceasefire.
third_party: IGAD; Eritrea; Ethiopia; Uganda; Kenya; UK; US; Norway; Italy

description: Salva Kiir engaged in negotiations with Sudanese government officials mediated by the US in Washington on 20 July 2006. In August 2006, the SPLM/A and Sudanese government forces clashed in the Rubkona area of Unity State, resulting in the death of eight civilians and three soldiers. Heavy fighting between the SPLM/A and government forces in Malakal from 27 to 30 November 2006 resulted in at least 150 people dead.
The conflict parties subsequently engaged in a round of negotiations and concluded a new ceasefire in December 2006, which also stipulated joint investigation.

As a result of standoff between Sudanese government forces and the SPLM/A in Abyei and the deadlock of talks on the status of Abyei, the SPLM/A temporarily pulled out of the Government of National Unity on 17 October 2007. Negotiations focusing on how entrust the security of the oil-rich areas, including Abyei, to oint Integrated Units led to an agreement on this issue on 12 December 2007. The SPLM/A joined the Government of National Unity again in late December 2007.

Fighting escalated in Abyei May 2008. Between 13 and 21 May 2008, at least 90 people were killed in Abyei during violence between government forces and the SPLM/A. Negotiations mediated by the UN led to the signing of an agreement on 8 June 2008. This agreement stipulated a new ceasefire and referred the boundary demarcation to the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague.

In 2009, the PCA issued its ruling, which considerably decreased the size of Abyei and moved the Heglig and Kharsana oil fields to Sudan. In spite of this ruling, the NCP still rejected the ruling and even occupied Abyei with armed forces. A round of negotiations between the conflict parties in September 2009, without the involvement of a third party, led to the signing of the Juba Declaration on Dialogue and National Consensus on 30 September 2009. This agreement re-affirmed the commitment to the implementation of the CPA, as well as well stressed the importance of reconciliation, democracy, and economic and social progress.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration on Dialogue and National Consensus

description: With tensions increasing and the referendum on self-determination for Southern Sudan approaching, the AU started to take the lead in mediating the successful implementation of the CPA. To this purpose, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP) was established during a meeting of the AU Peace and Security Council on 29 October 2009. Led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, the panel was mandated to assist the Sudanese parties in the implementation of the CPA.

A round of negotiations in June 2010, without the involvement a third party, led to the signing of the Mekelle Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP and the SPLM on Post-referendum Issues and Arrangements on 21 June 2010.  This agreement outlined arrangements for negotiations after the 2011 referendum on self-determination. The agreement also listed all issues that need to be negotiated, including citizenship, security, financial, economic, and natural resources, and international treaties and legal issues. The parties also agreed that these negotiations would be mediated by the AUHIP, with support from IGAD, IGAD partner’s forum, and the UN.
agreement_name: Mekelle Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP and the SPLM on Post-referendum Issues and Arrangements

description: On 19 and 20 July 2010, the AUHIP conveyed a meeting in Juba, at which the AUHIP mediators and the conflict parties formulated a framework for future negotiations, including guiding principles, proposals on clusters for negotiations, and the role of outside experts.

Next, between 7 and 13 November 2010, the Sudanese government and Sudanese government representatives discussed post-referendum issues, agreeing that the overriding principle of post-secession relations between Sudan and Southern Sudan should be the concept of two viable states. However, the negotiation partners could not agree on the status of Abyei, inhibiting them from signing a Framework Agreement.

With the 2011 referendum held in the next month, the AUHIP once more tried to resolve the conflict over Abyei at a meeting in Juba on 13 December 2010, but this effort proved fruitless as well. This meeting also reviewed progress on post-referendum issues.

After the successful military coup of 30 June 1989, which replaced President Ahmed Ali al-Mirghani with President Omar el-Bashir, all political parties were banned, and strict Islamic legal codes were enforced. The coup led to the formation of an umbrella opposition group called the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). In 1990, the SPLM/A joined the NDA, which at the time was a non-militant opposition group. The NDA aimed to remove the regime and set up a democratic system in Sudan. The NDA further envisioned that as part of this new democratic system the people in the South would have the right to a referendum on self-determination. The NDA was fairly loosely organised, composed of a variety of different entities such as civil society organisations, as well as rebel groups. Groups taking part in the alliance have on several occasions acted on their own, both when it comes to negotiations with and fighting against the government. Until 1996, the NDA was a solely political platform, but in September 1996, the NDA decided to set up a joint military force. After this point the NDA was both an umbrella organisation and an organisation with its own military and commanders fighting under the NDA banner. The Sudan peace process led by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) solely included the government and the SPLM/A. Hence, the NDA as an alliance was excluded from all negotiations mediated by IGAD.  In July 1999, Libyan leader of state Muammar al-Gaddafi proposed a conference on national dialogue at a NDA meeting in Tripoli. Both the NDA leadership and the Sudanese government accepted to engage in negotiations mediated by Libya and Egypt. A five-point peace plan was subsequently presented by Libya and Egypt, which included the whole NDA in the process. This plan was welcomed by the NDA as the best comprehensive political solution to the civil war. The Government of Sudan also approved of the five-point plan. The Libyan-Egyptian peace initiative faced great obstacles due to Egypt’s opposition to self-determination for the south, which was one of the cornerstones of the IGAD peace process. Nevertheless, SPLM/A leader John Garang expressed his support for the Libyan-Egyptian initiative in principle, but called for a coordination with the IGAD process. In spite of the acceptance of the peace plan, no direct negotiations between the NDA and the Government of Sudan took place as part this initiative. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1999. Egypt mediated between the adversaries through separate meetings with representatives from the Government of Sudan and the leaders of the NDA. A round of shuttle negotiations between the conflict parties, mediated by Egypt, took place in Cairo in the spring of 2000.
Another round of Egypt-mediated shuttle negotiations took place in Cairo in the summer of 2000.
A round of negotiations between the NDA and the Sudanese government, mediated by Saudi Arabia, in early December led to the conclusion of a framework agreement in Jeddah on 4 December 2003.

A round of negotiations between NDA and the Government of Sudan took place in Cairo in October in 2004 under the auspices of Egypt. The negotiations continued with different rounds throughout the year.

Following a round of negotiations from 14 to 16 January 2005, under the auspices of the Government of Egypt, the conflict parties signed a peace process agreement in Cairo on 16 January 2005. This framework agreement outlined the issues involved in reaching a comprehensive peace and complements the SPLM/A peace agreement of the same month and year. It calls for abolishing emergency laws and statutes restricting freedoms, establishing new laws for Sudanese political parties, methods of allowing for power sharing, and the dissolution of NDA forces. The agreement set up a number of commissions to discuss these issues in order to reach a comprehensive peace agreement.
A round of negotiations in June 2005 subsequently led to the signing of a full peace agreement on 18 June 2005, referred to as the Cairo Agreement.
On 22 September 2005, the NDA joined the Government of National Unity and the parliament of Sudan following discussions between June and August 2005 on the basis of the Cairo agreement.

The Government of Sudan and NDA held another round of talks in June 2006 about the implementation of the peace agreement signed in Cairo in June 2005. The meeting reviewed the jurisdictions of all the committees, which include the political committee, the legal committee, and the committee established to compensate and undo injustice. The conflict parties agreed that the implementation was to be carried out soon and that a timetable needed to be set for the committees to complete their work.

In late 2002, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) and the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) took up arms against the Sudanese government. The JEM leadership expressed in December 2003 that they were prepared to hold separate negotiations with the government in the presence of international observers. In spite of this statement, no negotiations were initiated. Vice-President Taha and Ahmed Ibrahim Diraige, a prominent former governor of Darfur and exiled opposition leader at the time the war broke out, manged to estalblish contacts with the JEM and the SLM/A in Nairobi in January 2004. This led to pre-negotiations on initiating formal negotiations in Geneva in mid-February 2004 on opening up the Darfur region to humanitarian assistance.

The armed opposition groups agreed to this, but the Sudanese government suddenly aborted these talks.” In late March 2004, peace talks between the Government of Sudan and the two rebel groups SLM/A and JEM began in N’djamena in Chad. Chad mediated these negotiations. However, both the SLM/A and JEM were dissatisfied with the mediation by Chad, whom they considered too biased towards the Government of Sudan. The Government of Sudan initially refused to hold face-to-face talks. Yet, when the SLM/A threatened to walk out of the negotiations, the Government of Sudan gave in and sat down with the rebels.

The negotiations that started in late March 2004 led to the signing of the N’djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement on 8 April 2004, stipulating among others a 45-day cessation of hostilities, the release of prisoners of war, and the facilitation of humanitarian access to Darfur. The ceasefire agreement also called for the deployment of a monitoring team to observe compliance with the ceasefire. The Government of Sudan also committed to neutralizing the armed militias during the negotiations. All parties violated the ceasefire agreement at numerous occasions throughout the year.

In early March 2004, senior AU officials held consultations with Sudanese government officials in Khartoum to discuss mediation by the AU. On the basis of these consultations, the AU initiated pre-negotiations between the Government of Sudan on the one side and the SLM/A and JEM on the other side in May 2004. The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konaré, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks.

The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May.
The parties met for a first round of negotiations in Addis Ababa at the AU headquarters between 15 and 17 July 2004.

The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konaré, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks. The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May.   The second round of what came to be known as the Abuja talks started in Abuja on 23 August under the auspices of President Olusegun Obasanjo, the chairman of the AU. These talks resulted in the Protocol on the Improvement of the Humanitarian Situation in Darfur, signed on 1 September by the Government of Sudan, the SLM/A, and the JEM. This round of negotiations ended on 17 September.
agreement_name: Protocol on the Improvement of the Humanitarian Situation in Darfur

description: The third round of Abuja talks started on 21 October, resulting in the signing of the Humanitarian and Security Protocols on 9 November.

The parties met between 11 and 21 December for the fourth round of the Abuja talks, which ended with a promise of the conflict parties to commit to the ceasefire agreement signed on 8 April and the Humanitarian and Security Protocols from November, as well as a promise to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict.

The first meeting in 2005, held in Chad in February, was supervised by Chadian President Idriss Deby and attended by international mediators and the Chairperson of the African Union Commission Alpha Oumar Konaré.

In May 2005, Salim Ahmed Salim, the former Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity, was appointed as the AU Special Envoy for the Darfur Talks and chief mediator. Salim Ahmed Salim mediated a round of negotiations in Abuja between 10 June and 5 July 2005. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the “Declaration of Principles” on 5 July 2005, after more than three weeks of negotiating. The declaration included provisions for refugees to return home and new security arrangements. It also committed the signatories to respect the different ethnic and religious groups in Sudan and work towards an equitable distribution of national wealth.
A sixth round of AU-sponsored peace talks began in September. Yet, these negotiations were plagued by rebel divisions and violence on the ground. The sixth round ended 20 October 2005.

The seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. From the start of the seventh round of talks, the pressure on the conflict parties to sign a peace agreement steadily increased. The Western governments funding the peace process warned the parties that funding for the peace process could dry up in the absence of progress during the talks. The meetings of the seventh round of negotiations were held at different locations, but finished again in Abuja. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006.

A number of high-profile diplomats arrived in Abuja on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hr extensions to the talks’ deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US’s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N’djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and an assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. In spite of the pressure put on the conflict parties to sign the peace agreement, the JEM and the SLM/A led by Abdul Wahid refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the DPA on 5 May 2006. From the signing of the DPA on 5 May 2006 onwards, AU mediators Alex de Waal and Sam Ibok met with SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid several times a day to get clarity on his objections to the DPA. They encouraged him to write to Salim Ahmed Salim a letter in which he could specify on what was needed in order for him to sign the DPA. In his letter send to Salim on 10 May, Abdul Wahid proposed to conclude a ‘supplementary agreement’ to the DPA, demanding greater representation at the legislature and executive bodies of Darfur, as well as a larger compensation fund for Darfur. However, Salim knew that the chief government negotiator, Majzoub El Khalifa, would reject this option, instead insisting that Abdul Wahid had to sign the DPA first, after which some of the remaining issues could be negotiated. Consequently, on 13 May 2006, Salim replied to Wahid that the AU could not re-open negotiations on the DPA, but was willing to support the conflict parties in implementing the agreement. Sam Ibok subsequently tried to persuade Wahid that the AU’s insistence on implementation rather than concluding a supplementary agreement would still allow Wahid to get what he wanted. Ibok’s effort to persuade Wahid did not work. Wahid kept insisting on a supplementary agreement. The AU Peace and Security Council decided on 16 May 2006 that the non-signatory groups would have another two weeks to sign the DPA.

A final mediation attempt was launched by the EU during the last week of May 2006, but Abdul Wahid in the end did not show up for negotiations. Instead, he flew to Asmara, Eritrea, at the invitation of JEM leader Khalil Ibrahim to discuss the founding of a rebel alliance.

In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU.  However, the JEM refused to attend any negotiations.  In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassolé assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign-minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no negotiations took place in 2008 as the warring parties did not meet each other. JEM resisted negotiations with other rebel groups present and said that they should be the only one representing the Darfur side in the negotiations. The reason they stated for this was that the government could play the rebels against each other if they were represented by several groups. Bassolé went along with this demand by JEM, because he also believed that if the JEM would sign a deal, then the other rebel parties would follow.  In January 2009, after it had been agreed that JEM would be the sole representative of the Darfurian rebels, Djibril Bassolé succeeded in initiating negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the JEM.

The negotiations took place from January to February in Doha, the capital of Qatar. The negotiations led to the signing of the declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement (CBA) on 17 February 2009. This agreement was supposed to pave the way for more comprehensive negotiations. However, one day after the agreement was signed, JEM positions were bombed by government forces.
agreement_name: Declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement

description: Another round of negotiations took place in November 2009, but these talks took place in Chad and were mediated by Chadian President Idriss Déby, without the involvement of Bassolé. President Déby initiated these peace negotiations between the JEM and the government of Sudan as part of a rapprochement between Sudan and Chad. Accordingly, Déby presented Sudanese government negotiators with the draft of framework agreement that stipulated that in a final peace agreement the JEM should have representation at all governmental levels.
Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the JEM, mediated by Chad, took place in N’Djamena on 20 January.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010 mediated by Chad led to the conclusion of a framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.  Déby had invited Bassolé to N’Djamena to witness the signing of the framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.The agreement called for a ceasefire, release of hundreds of JEM-fighters that were imprisoned, and set out terms for future negotiations.

On 23 February, the Sudanese government and the JEM signed an almost identical agreement in Doha, allowing “the Qataris to claim the glory for the deal hatched entirely in N’Djamena” as Alex de Waal puts it. As the host country, Qatar provided material incentives for the conflict parties to make peace through promising to allocate substantial funds for future development projects in Darfur. During the negotiations leading up to the Doha Agreement, Qatar had promised an amount of two billion US Dollars for rebuilding Darfur if the Government of Sudan and the various rebel movements participating in the Doha negotiations were to sign a peace agreement. The agreement did not hold.

JEM left the ongoing negotiations on 3 May 2010, making it clear that it suspended its participation in the Doha process because of the Sudanese army of breaching the cessation of hostilities agreement.

The AUHIP’s mediation efforts in 2013 mainly focused on negotiations between the Government of Sudan and JEM. A round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 10 February 2013.
Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in March 2013 led to Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces on 29 March 2013.
agreement_name: Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces

description: Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in April 2013 led to the Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD) on 6 April 2013. This last agreement was based on the DDPD and all its annexes, as well as stipulated additional power-sharing and wealth-sharing provisions. The agreement also stipulated compensation and return of IDPs and refugees and included a permanent ceasefire.
agreement_name: Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)

description: On 5 April 2014, Chadian President Idris Deby met the Chairman of JEM, Jibril Ibrahim, in Paris to discuss a roadmap for official negotiations. The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016.

The Darfur Joint Resistance Forces is a coalition comprised of the SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and the Sudan Liberation Movement for Justice (SLMJ). It was established in 2014. Taher Hajar was the leader of SLMJ until his killing during clashes in June 2014, with Ali Karbino serving as military leader for the SLMJ. The SLM/A and the SLM/A-MM maintained their membership with the SRF in spite of also joining the Darfur Joint Resistance Forces. The Darfur Joint Resistance Forces mainly operated in the northern part of Darfur.  Between 2 and 4 June 2016, US and Chadian diplomats held shuttle talks with representatives from the SLMJ and Sudanese government representatives in Chad. The shuttle talks were aimed at finding a way in which SLMJ could join the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD).

Following a round of informal talks between the Sudanese government and JEM in early 2017, the Government of Sudan announced on 4 January 2017 that these informal talks had led to agreement “on some major issues”, but JEM representatives immediately denied it had reach an agreement on any issues.

A round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and JEM in February 2018, mediated by Qatar, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 11 February 2018. The ceasefire was signed by Mohamed Bashir Ahmed of the JEM-Military Command in Qatar.Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019.

In late 2002, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) and the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) took up arms against the Sudanese government. On 14 March 2003, the Darfur based SLM/A stated in a press release that it shall fight for a secular Sudan with a decentralised form of governance, using armed struggle as one of the means to achieve this political goal. By the time this press statement was released the armed conflict had already begun. One of the first organized attacks took place as early as June 2002, when Darfurian rebels targeted a police station in Golo. Yet, it was not until March 2003 that the armed conflict escalated, when several coordinated armed attacks led by SLM/A leader Abdel Wahid were launched on various government army units. When the armed opposition groups took up arms, the Sudanese government initially kept the communication channels open. For instance, after the attack on the police station in Golo in June 2002, the Sudanese government dispatched the chairman of the Parliament’s Transport Commission, Idris Yusuf, to negotiate with the armed groups.  From March 2003 onwards, when attacks on government targets became more frequent, the Governor of North Darfur, Ibrahim Suleiman, formed and ad hoc Darfur Security Committee to negotiate an end to the violence in Darfur. However, this peace effort was terminated as soon as government officials had successfully negotiated the return of commander of the Sudanese air force Ibrahim Bushra, who had been captured during the attack on El Fasher airbase.

The Minister of Education, Ahmed Babiker Nahar, a Zaghawa, and the Governor of the Nile State, Abdalla Ali Masar, a Rizeigat, conducted pre-negotiations with the SLM/A between June and July 2003. With the approval of President Omar al-Bashir, they entered a SLM/A stronghold with a delegation of thirty traditional leaders and government officials. The SLM/A had insisted on three preconditions for entering pre-negotiations: the negotiations had to address the political roots causes of the rebellion, the Sudanese government should not refer to them as bandits, and that the Janjaweed militia had to be disarmed. The Government negotiator Ahmed Babiker Nahar alledgedly stated during these negotiations that the goals of the armed opposition were “just and rational in some of its aspects, and was amenable to give and take” and he recommended Preisdent al-Bashir to start official negotiations with the rebels.

The Minister of Education, Ahmed Babiker Nahar, a Zaghawa, and the Governor of the Nile State, Abdalla Ali Masar, a Rizeigat, conducted pre-negotiations with the SLM/A between June and July 2003. With the approval of President Omar al-Bashir, they entered a SLM/A stronghold with a delegation of thirty traditional leaders and government officials. The SLM/A had insisted on three preconditions for entering pre-negotiations: the negotiations had to address the political roots causes of the rebellion, the Sudanese government should not refer to them as bandits, and that the Janjaweed militia had to be disarmed. The Government negotiator Ahmed Babiker Nahar alledgedly stated during these negotiations that the goals of the armed opposition were “just and rational in some of its aspects, and was amenable to give and take” and he recommended Preisdent al-Bashir to start official negotiations with the rebels.

In late August 2003, Chad acted as mediator during talks between the Sudanese Government and the SLM/A in Abéché, under the auspices of President Idriss Deby. After five days of negotiations, the conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement on 3 September. Directly after the talks, Sudan released 54 rebel prisoners as part of the deal. However, only a few days later, the SLM/A accused the Government of Sudan of breaking the ceasefire, which the latter denied. A month later, the SLM/A released 42 prisoners. The Abéché Ceasefire Agreement also called for comprehensive peace talks.

Consequently, official negotiations – which came to be known as the Abéché Ceasefire renewal talks – started on 29 October 2003, one day prior to the ceasefire which had been negotiated on 15 September would end. During these talks, the Chadian Government proposed a draft peace agreement. The talks ended without any results, mainly because the SLM/A demanded the presence of international monitors in Darfur, while the Government of Sudan rejected this.

A closed-door round of pre-negotiations between several Chadian generals and a SLM/A delegation led by Minni Minnawi took place in N’djamena on the evening of 28 November 2003 in preparation of the scheduled formal peace talks the next day. However, based on this meeting, President Déby cancelled the scheduled negotiations last minute, accusing the SLM/A of unrealistic demands.
On 15 December 2003, the conflict parties met once more for negotiations in Chad, but the talks broke down after less than 24 hours.

Vice-President Taha and Ahmed Ibrahim Diraige, a prominent former governor of Darfur and exiled opposition leader at the time the war broke out, manged to estalblish contacts with the JEM and the SLM/A in Nairobi in January 2004. The Government of Sudan also committed to neutralizing the armed militias during the negotiations. All parties violated the ceasefire agreement at numerous occasions throughout the year.
