Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassolé assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign-minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place in 2008 as the warring parties did not meet each other. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassolé continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009.In 2010, Djibril Bassolé continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort. In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve.

The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) broke away from the SLM/A in November 2005, when he was “elected” as the leader of the SLM/A at a conference organized by his own supporters within the SLM/A at Haskanita. The SLM/A-MM was part of the seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hr extensions to the talks’ deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US’s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N’djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and an assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. Zoellick also threatened Minni Minawi with possible UN sanctions or an International Criminal Court indictment if he did not sign the agreement. In addition, Zoellick threatened that an attack on Minawi’s forces in South Darfur by Sudanese troops would be executed if he failed to sign the DPA. Despite these threats, Minawi still had reservations when the final stretch of the Abuja talks started on 4 May, which were hosted by Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo at his state house in Abuja. During a break of the plenary peace talks on 4 May, Zoellick allegedly told Minawi privately, “Have no doubt where I stand. I am a good friend and I am a fearsome enemy.” Minawi signed the DPA the next day, on 5 May 2006. However, the JEM and the SLM/A led by Abdul Wahid refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the peace agreement.
UNAMID mediated between Sudanese Vice-President Ali Osman Taha and Minni Minawi in al-Fasher in September 2008. The mediation effort led to an agreement that committed both sides to the DPA.

In August 2009, UNAMID convened a Round Table meeting of the Parties and Partners of the DPA on the implementation of the DPA. The meeting was chaired by UNAMID Joint Special representative (JSR), Mr. Rodolphe Adada.

In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. The UCDP assigns some armed clashes to the SLM/A-MM and some to the SRF from 2011 onwards. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SLM/A-MM are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.  The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016.
A round of secret negotiations between the SLM/A-Unity and the Sudanese government in February 2011 led to the signing of a ceasefire on 15 February 2011.

In April 2010, George Athor participated in elections for becoming the Governor in Jonglei, the largest state in South Sudan. Athor lost the election to SPLM/A candidate Lieutenant General Kuol Manyang, after which he accused SPLM/A for fraud in the elections. On 30 April 2010, the forces of George Athor subsequently attacked a SPLM/A base in the Doleib Hill area, which is located south-west of Malakal, the state capital of Upper Nile. On 7 October 2010, the President of South Sudan Salva Kiir Mayardit issued a pardon for George Athor and his men. George Athor responded by declaring a ceasefire and indicating his willingness to negotiate: “We have accepted the amnesty as a step in the right direction. We have announced also on our side a ceasefire and we have sent a small delegation to Juba so that we can prepare for negotiations.” Negotiations started in October 2010, but no agreement was reached in 2010.

Another round of negotiations starting in early January 2011 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 January 2011. The Episcopal Church of Sudan moderated these talks. On 23 March 2011, fighting erupted between the South Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SSLM/A) led by Peter Gadet and the autonomous Government of South Sudan in the Mayom county in Unity State. Bapiny Monytuil, who would later become the deputy head of SSLA, led these attacks. The SSLM/A operated mainly in the Unity State, but was also involved in clashes in the Upper Nile State. It received support from the Government of Sudan, including weapons, ammunition, funding, and logistical support. On 11 April 2011, the SSLM/A released a document, called the Mayom Declaration, in which it is claimed that the Government of South Sudan has failed.

In early 1987, Joseph Kony decided to take up arms against the Government of Uganda, declaring that he had been instructed by the Holy Spirit to fight and overthrow the new Government. Kony subsequently left his home together with a small number of followers. Soon thereafter, Kony’s group met a number of Acholi soldiers who turned out to be the rebel group UPDA’s Black Battalion under the leadership of Major Benjamin Apia. Kony persuaded the Black Battalion to recognise his spiritual guidance and became their leader. By late 1987, Kony had assembled a large following, which he named the United Holy Salvation Army (UHSA). Abel Okumu, an Angelican priest from Uganda, attempted to mediate between the Government of Uganda and Joseph Kony’s UHSA in June 1987. However, a breakdown in communications led to an attack by government forces on Kony before direct talks could be initiated. Kony blamed Okumu and killed him shortly afterwards. In 1988, Severino Lukoya, the leader of the Lord’s Army and the father of the self-proclaimed spirit medium Alice Lakwena, was captured by government forces. This provided Kony, who allegedly was Alice Lakwena’s second cousin, the opportunity to assume leadership over the remaining fighters of the Lord’s Army. He subsequently named his group of fighters the Uganda Christian Democratic Army (UCDA).  In late 1991, Kony changed the name of his group of followers to the Lord’s Resistance Army (LRA). The Ugandan Minister for the North, Betty Bigombe, initiated contacts with the LRA in mid-1993. This was done through Kony’s close friend Yusuf Okwonga Adek, a northerner residing in Gulu, who delivered a letter from Bigombe to Kony. Adek continued his work as an intermediary between June and November 1993, shuttling between the conflict parties and laying the groundwork for future talks. This led to the first face-to-face peace meeting ever between Government representatives and the rebels on 25 November 1993. The talks were held at Pagik in the Gulu district. The Government delegation was led by Bigombe and included Acholi elders, the Director of Military Intelligence Lieutenant Colonel Fred Toolit, and Colonel Samuel Wasswa. Joseph Kony did not attend the meeting, but sent a tape-recorded message. The parties agreed that they would stop fighting. The LRA promised they would gather in a gazetted area where they would be able to move freely. During the talks, the LRA negotiators demanded an amnesty for all their fighters. A LRA Commander, Cirilo Jurukadri Odego, emphasised that in order for talks to succeed “old wounds should not be reopened.” Bigombe responded by assuring the LRA delegation that the LRA fighters would all be covered by the already existing general amnesty. However, in the weeks after the meeting at Pagik, Bigombe came under increasing pressure. For instance, Brigadier Mugume and Lieutenant Colonel Toolit accused Bigombe of having “caved in too much” to LRA demands. Moreover, Kony kept on refusing to show up for peace talks.

On 10 January 1994, the negotiators met again in Pagik, but the parties were unable to agree security arrangement for the initiation of official negotiations. Although Kony still refused to participate in peace talks, he showed up at Pagik the next day to have a one-to-one meeting with Bigombe.

A third round of pre-negotiations was held at Lakwatimer Primary School on 24 January, but Kony did not show up for this meeting. Relations between the Government and Uganda and the LRA started to deteriorate from this meeting onwards, with the LRA representatives accusing the negotiators of the government side behaving arrogantly. An example of this behaviour might be that Brigadier Mugume told LRA commander Otti-Lagony that he “thought you had come here to negotiate your surrender.” In spite of these misgivings negotiations continued.

A ceasefire agreement was concluded at a peace meeting at Tegot-Atto on 2 February 1994. Yet, soon after this meeting, the national Ugandan army claimed that LRA fighters had made contact with the Government of Sudan. This was unacceptable to the Government delegation and on 6 February 1994, President Museveni announced that the LRA had a week to surrender, otherwise the Government would defeat them. The LRA did not take up this ultimatum, after which most of its troops crossed the border into Sudan, only to return in a few months conducting attacks with more sophisticated weapons and landmines. Fighting continued during the rest of 1994.

President Museveni stated in a speech on 3 June 1996 amnesty would be given to ordinary fighters of the LRA, but not to the LRA leaders. In September 1996, several members of the LRA called for peace talks. A ‘Kacoke Madit’ – which is a big meeting of the Acholi – was subsequently convened in London during October and November 1996. This meeting brought together Acholi communities from Uganda, the diaspora, the Government of Uganda, and the LRA. The Ugandan Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Martin Aliker, stated that he had been mandated by the Government to talk to the LRA on its behalf. The LRA was represented by James Alfred Obita, the Secretary for External Affairs and Mobilisation. Both parties expressed their desire to initiate peace negotiations. After the Kacoke Madit in London ended, the Community of Sant’Egidio contacted its organisers to discuss the possibility of mediation. An initial meeting between the Community of Sant’Egidio and LRA representatives was held in London in November 1996.

The LRA leadership made another call for peace talks in April 1997. The Community of Sant’Egidio mediated secret pre-negotiations in Rome in May 1997, which James Alfred Obita attended on behalf of the LRA. It was agreed that official negotiations would be initiated, in which the LRA would send two representatives of its military wing and two representatives of its political wing.
The LRA leadership approved mediated negotiations during another round of pre-negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio in Khartoum in May 1997.

The Community of Sant’Egidio organised another round of talks with the LRA in Khartoum in June 1997 in order to prepare for official negotiations with the Government of Uganda. After this meeting, the Government of Uganda informed the Community of Sant’Egidio that they were ready to meet the LRA delegation. Moreover, in October 1997, President Museveni accepted the idea of granting LRA leader Kony amnesty. On 22 November, President Museveni replied to a letter of James Alfred Obita, in which agreed to mediation, writing that “our delegation is ready to discuss with your representatives anywhere and we are ready to reach a peaceful settlement within the confines of the 1995 Constitution of the Republic of Uganda.”

On 12 December, the Community of Sant’Egidio mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Rome. Andrea Riccardi and Matteo Zuppi acted as the chief mediators. The Government of Uganda was represented by Amama Mbabazi, the State Minister of Foreign Affairs, and David Pulkol, Director of the External Security Organisation. Charles Laroker and James Alfred Obita negotiated on behalf of the LRA. No agreement was reached, , but the conflict parties agreed to meet again in January 1998.

The Community of Sant’Egidio indeed continued its mediation efforts in 1998. During the talks in Rome in mid-December 1997, the parties had scheduled another round of negotiations on 18 January 1998. While the Government of Uganda attended this meeting, the LRA delegation never showed up. In mid May 1998, the district military commanders of the Ugandan states of Gulu and Kitgum entered into secrete negotiations with eight representatives of the LRA. The secret talks were hosted by Kenya in Nairobi and lasted until early July 1998.

The secret talks were hosted by Kenya in Nairobi and lasted until early July 1998. Taking progress made during these secret talks into account, Museveni announced on 21 July 1998 that he was ready to accept a ceasefire, on the condition that the LRA fighters would remain in defined bases and not move around. In addition, later in 1998, the Kacoke Madit – which is an umbrella organisation of Acholi parliamentarians, religious and opinion leaders – offered to organise round table talks between the conflict parties, but the LRA refused this offer.

The Community of Sant’Egidio succeeded in initiating talks between the conflict parties on 13 May 1999. This led to a promise by President Museveni that an amnesty to all LRA rebels would be granted and that Joseph Kony would get a cabinet post should he be democratically elected.

In January 2000, the US Department for African Affairs and the Carter Centre mediated talks between the conflict parties. Not much is known about this mediation effort, other than that Jimmy Carter acted as the chief mediator.

In June 2001, the Gulu District Chairman Walter Ochorra met a local LRA leader of the Gulu district, Oneu Kandulu. The talks concerned the peaceful resolution of the insurgency, the LRA abductions of civilians, and an amnesty for LRA rebels.

On 23 February 2003, the LRA declared an immediate ceasefire to pave the way for peace talks. The Government of Uganda accepted this ceasefire in early March 2003, but withdrew the ceasefire offer in late April and not a single meeting was held between the two parties. In August 2004, officials from a British-based charity called Africa Relief Trust tried to initiate talks between the LRA and the Government of Uganda, after having been in contact with the rebels since December 2003. Head of the team was Joseph Ocwet, Uganda’s ambassador to the African Union. On 30 August 2004, the Africa Relief Trust mediation team met with three LRA commanders at Abuga village, conducting talks to prepare the ground for formal negotiations. However, the initiative came to an abrupt halt when questions of the authenticity of the LRA commanders arose and the national army attacked a group of rebels that had reportedly been a part of the process, killing a LRA emissary.

The LRA came under military pressure during the second half of 2004 when the Government of Sudan struck a deal with the Ugandan Government, allowing Ugandan forces to move further into Sudan to attack LRA forces. The LRA was severely weakened by November 2004. Accordingly, LRA spokesman Sam Kolo announced that the LRA was willing to enter negotiations. The Ugandan government also wished to negotiate, which led President Museveni to request Betty Bigombe, a former minister in the Ugandan Government, to put together a peace team, consisting of international observers of non-African nationalities, UN representatives, Acholi elders, and members of parliament. The team initially conducted informal talks with rebel officers, attempting to find out what the rebel’s demands were. As this became increasingly clear, Bigombe arranged a meeting between LRA officers and Acholi elders, which was one of the rebel’s pre-conditions for holding formal peace talks. All these efforts eventually led to a first direct meeting between the rebels and a government delegation, led by Ugandan Minister of Internal Affairs, Ruhakana Rugunda, on 29 December 2004. The conflict parties reached agreement on a total ceasefire and a signing ceremony was scheduled for 31 December 2004. However, the mediation team failed to finalise the accord, which resulted in the indefinite postponement of the signing ceremony. In addition to having representatives in Bigombe’s mediation team, Norway, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom finically sponsored the peace initiative.

Bigombe tried to make the conflict parties sign an improved draft of the ceasefire proposal during negotiations in January 2005, but the conflict parties did not sign this agreement. The conflict escalated again in February 2005. After Bigombe communicated with Kony over the phone in April 2005, Kony attempted to set up a face-to-face meeting with Bigombe. Yet, this meeting never materialized due to logistical and security obstacles. In September 2005, Bigombe prepared a draft peace proposal, which president Museveni accepted as the starting point for further negotiations. However, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued an arrest warrant for LRA’s top five leaders before Bigombe had a chance to deliver it to Kony. Nevertheless, after discussions with president Museveni, Bigombe indicated that the door was still open for negotiations and Bigombe stayed in contact with the rebels throughout the rest of the year. The old troika of engaged countries – Norway, the UK, and the Netherlands – was joined by the US in April 2005. The four countries supported the peace team with personnel and financial means. Moreover, in July 2005, in an unprecedented move, the countries issued a direct appeal to LRA to urgently re-establish contact with Bigombe. The message was broadcasted on radio throughout northern Uganda 18 times a day.

In 2006, a new peace process was imitated. Several third parties were involved in the peace process in Uganda at different levels and at different stages during the year. Pax Christi, a Catholic peace movement from the Netherlands, managed to establish channels for contact between the LRA and the Government of Uganda, thus initiating pre-negotiations. Pax Christi also approached vice-President of the autonomous Southern Sudan, Riek Machar, as a potential mediator for negotiations. Machar had offered the conflict parties to mediate as early as November 2005. Instrumental in these initial efforts of Pax Christi was Leonzio Angole Onek, a Sudanses Acholi and former colleague of Riek Machar, who was provided with financial and logistic support by Pax Christi to set up negotiations between the conflict parties. Moreover, Machar was in a good position to initiate negotiations. Determined to get the LRA out of South Sudan, Machar gave the LRA three options: an ultimatum to either leave Sudanese territory peacefully, accept mediation with the Government of Uganda, or face military action. The threat of military action against the LRA remained implicit throughout the Juba peace talks. After a round of pre-negotiations in May 2006, the conflict parties officially agreed to mediation by Riek Machar and it was decided that the negotiations would start in Juba on 14 July 2006.
third_party: Sudan; Pax Christi; Netherlands; Switzerland; UN

description: Prior to the start of negotiations in Juba in July 2006,  President Museveni announced that he guaranteed Joseph Kony’s safety if an agreement was signed. This announcement received widespread attention, since Kony and four of his deputies had been indicted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity. At Juba, Machar was supported both by a mediation team within his vice-Presidential office and by a mediation group that included delegates of Pax Christi, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. Switzerland, provided a professional negotiator that assisted Machar during the talks, while Pax Christi provided the LRA delegates with training in negotiating. The Community of Sant’Egidio, who had been invited by the LRA, also attended the negotiations. UN representatives from the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the Department of Political Affairs were also involved in the process to advice on issues related to the protection of internally displaced persons political aspects of the process respectively. Neither Kony nor his top commanders attended the talks at Juba.  Instead, the LRA delegation consisted of 14 negotiators, who had been appointed by Kony. Almost all of these 14 negotiators were Acholis from the Diaspora. The negotiation teams at Juba soon managed to agree on the issues that needed to be addressed in order to resolve the armed conflict: the cessation of hostilities; comprehensive solutions addressing the underlying issues of the conflict; reconciliation and accountability; the conclusion of a formal ceasefire; and disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of the fighters. Yet, the parties were unable to agree in which order these issues needed to be addressed and talks were adjourned on 24 July. In the meantime, the two negotiation teams consulted with their seniors.
third_party: Sudan; Pax Christi; Netherlands; Switzerland; UN

description: On 18 August, negotiations resumed. The focus in this round of talks was particularly on the cessation of hostilities and demobilisation. After eight days, on 26 August 2006, the parties signed a cessation of hostilities agreement. The Cessation of Hostilities Agreement, among others, called upon all rebels to assemble at two designation points in Southern Sudan within three weeks. These assembly points were to be supervised and protected by SPLM forces.
third_party: Sudan; Pax Christi; Netherlands; Switzerland; UN

description: In late September 2006, the Juba process resumed for a third round of talks, but this time the talks focused on finding a comprehensive solution to the conflict.
third_party: Sudan; Pax Christi; Netherlands; Switzerland; UN

description: As the progress made during these talks stalled, Ugandan president Museveni flew in to meet the LRA negotiation team in October 2006. This did not produce any results. In addition, while many rebels had assembled in the two camps by the deadline, the LRA leadership did not turn up and rebels started to move away from the camps again. The two sides continued to accuse each other of violations of the truce during the rest of the year.

On 1 November 2006 and later again on 16 December 2006, the two sides recommitted to their ceasefire. In November 2006, Jan Egeland met LRA leader Joseph Kony in a mediation effort to support the Juba peace talks.

On 12 January 2007, three days before the Juba talks would resume, the LRA leadership announced that they withdrew from the peace process, stating that they would not resume talks unless Machar was replaced as the chief mediator and a new venue would be found. As a result, efforts were aimed at getting the LRA back to the negotiation table during the following two months, in which UN Special Envoy Joaquim Chissano and Pax Christi played an instrumental role.
In early March 2007, Chissano met Kony somewhere along the Congo-Sudan border in yet another round of pre-negotiations aimed at resuming official negotiations.

In a second visit in late March 2007, Rugunda, the government negotiator, accompanied Chissano, which resulted in the first face-to face meeting between Rugunda and Kony, paving the way for a resumption of peace talks at Juba.

In addition, Pax Christi hosted talks between an LRA delegation and a Government of Uganda delegation led by General Salim Saleh in Mombasa in early April 2007. Hizkias Assefa and Simon Simonse mediated the talks on behalf of Pax Christi.

In preparation of another round of peace talks between the LRA and Ugandan government, UN Special Envoy Joaquim Chissano mediated negotiations between the conflict parties between 14 and 16 April 2007. These negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement 16 April 2007. This agreement was based on a previous ceasefire from August 2006 and was set to last two months.

On 26 April, the Juba process resumed, leading to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 May 2007: the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions. Regional observers from Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo and South Africa were also present at the Juba talks in 2007, serving as informal mediators by promoting communication, confidence, and compromise. After the conclusion of the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions, talks continued focused on issues related to reconciliation and accountability.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: A round of negotiations in June 2007 led to the signing of the Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation on 29 June 2007. This agreement addresses how the conflict parties aim to establish a viable national alternative to ICC indictments against five top-LRA leaders, including Kony. Although another round of negotiations was scheduled in August 2007, no other peace talks were held during the rest of 2007. However, on 1 November the LRA went on a historic first trip to Kampala, where it released a white dove as a symbolic gesture of peace. They then visited President Museveni and signed an addendum to the cessation of hostilities agreement that extended the pact for another three months. Martin Ojul, the LRA delegation leader, then led the group up to Gulu and appeared on a local radio station asking for forgiveness from the local population.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: Two events resulted in uncertainty with regard to whether the Juba talks would continue in 2008. First, the LRA’s second in command, Vincent Otti had died in October 2007. Second, on 22 January 2008, LRA leader Joseph Kony sacked the head of LRA’s negotiating delegation, Martin Ojul, together with three others, accusing them of making money from the peace talks. Nevertheless, the Juba talks resumed on 30 January 2008 with the two sides extending the ceasefire the day before.  The LRA team was now led by David Matsanga. Riek Machar continued to act as the chief mediator. In addition to the third parties already present in 2007, the US, the EU, Canada and Norway joined the talks. The conflict parties reached agreement on a number of issues.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: On 22 February 2008, the Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions was signed.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa
agreement_name: Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions

description: On 23 February 2008, the Agreement on a Permanent Ceasefire was signed.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: On 28 February 2008, the Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration was signed.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa
agreement_name: Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration

description: On 29 February 2008, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa
agreement_name: Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms.

description: After agreement had been reached on these issues, the LRA team travelled to Joseph Kony’s base in Garamba National Park in early March for a new round of negotiations on the text of a proposed Final Peace Agreement before signing. The focus in the negotiations subsequently shifted to the provisions for a final ceasefire, followed by talks on disarmament, demobilization and reintegration. It is unclear whether Kony was briefed, but plans for the signing ceremony continued. On 3 March, the LRA and Government of Uganda signed an agreement that included provisions for not only a ceasefire, but also disarmament and demobilization.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: On 10 April, all actors that had been involved in the Juba talks assembled at Ri-Kwangba to witness the signing of the final agreement. However, Kony did not show up, stating he wanted clarification on the issues of the Mato Oput (traditional judicial system) and the Special Division of the High Court. Kony stated he no longer trusted the mediators, claiming that they were in favour of the Government of Uganda. Kony also fired Matsanga, replacing him with James Obita. The legitimacy of LRA’s negotiation team was thus seriously hampered. This problem became even become worse when Matsanga reappeared in June 2008 and claimed to have been reinstated by Kony as the chief negotiator, which has remained unclear whether this was the case. UN Secretary-General’s special envoy Joaquim Chissano worked to get the negotiations process back on track after Kony had failed to turn up for the signing ceremony on 10 April 2008. To this purpose, Chissano held a series of separate meetings with President Museveni and Kony between April and July 2008. While the LRA continued to request further mediated negotiations, Uganda’s president Museveni stated in July 2008 that his government would not hold further negotiations with Kony. Instead, the Government of Uganda would wait for Kony to sign the Final Peace Agreement. On 11 September, Machar declared the peace process over. Another signing ceremony was prepared in November, but Kony again failed to show up. The LRA called for a ceasefire in January, March, and June 2009. However, the LRA was only willing to resume peace talks provided that another mediator would lead the process and that talks would be held at another venue. In October 2009, Matsanga stated that talks should be held on “neutral ground” such as in Kenya or Tanzania. Matsanga also claimed that Kony would prefer Nigerian ex-president Olusegun Obasanjo to act as the chief mediator. Machar conducted yet a final attempt at restarting negotiations at Juba by the end of September 2009. Prior to Machar’s attempt, Chissano had made several attempts to find a credible negotiator of the LRA, but concluded that this was impossible and ended his role as Special Envoy to the Secretary-General on 29 May 2009. The Government of Uganda rejected calls for peace talks, regardless of the venue and chief mediator, stating that an agreement had already been reached and that the only thing missing was Kony’s signature on the final accord.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: The creation of the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) resulted from the merger between the Tablighi Jamaat sect and the National Army for the Liberation of Uganda (NALU). After legislative elections in June 1996, the Allied Democratic Front (ADF) claimed that the presidential and legislative elections of that year had been rigged.  On November 13, 1996, ADF rebels infiltrated Uganda from Zaire and captured the towns of Mpondwe and Bwera. The ADF operated in the Rwenzori area  on both sides of the Uganda-DRC border. In August 1997, President Museveni publicly stated that he was willing to pardon fighters from the ADF who turned themselves in. In October 1997, the ADF sent a list of preconditions for peace talks to President Museveni. These included power-sharing with the rebel groups, suspension of the country’s 1995 constitution that bans all political parties, and the release of all captured rebels. The Ugandan Government did not respond to these demands. Starting in May 1998, Uganda claimed that ADF border attacks were increasing in frequency, intensity, and destructiveness and accused the DRC and Sudanese governments for supporting the group. The Congolese government declined accusations of support. Nevertheless, fighting the ADF served Uganda as pretext for its military presence in DRC and pursue other goals in the DRC. This is supported by the fact that Uganda went far beyond the border. Ugandan troops ventured all the way to Isoro, which is 580km from the border. On 1 September 1998, Ugandan troops were in Kisangani. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1998 between the Government of Uganda and the ADF took place, but Uganda and the DRC did engage in negotiations. Shortly after Laurent Kabila took of power, the DRC and Uganda signed a ‘Memorandum of Understanding’ which foresaw joint operations between the national armies. A treaty of mutual security was signed on 26 April 1998. Yet, on 17 July 1998, Kabila who had benefitted from Ugandan support to accede to the presidency requested all foreign troops to leave the Congolese territory. This abruptly ended DRC-Uganda military cooperation.  In May 1999, Roman Catholic leaders of the Ruwenzori region offered to mediate between the Ugandan Government and the ADF, but this offer was not accepted. In November 1999, the Chairman of the Ugandan district of Kasese, Yokas Mikande, and the Busongora South Minister of Parliament, Christopher Kibanzanga, held seven peace meetings with the commanders of the ADF in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The talks concerned the possibility peace in the Ruwenzovi region in western Uganda. The peace talks were the result of a letter sent by the ADF leadership to the Ugandan army saying that they were ready to stop fighting. Commenting on the letter, a senior army commander stated that the Government of Uganda was willing to negotiate with the ADF.

In November 1999, the Chairman of the Ugandan district of Kasese, Yokas Mikande, and the Busongora South Minister of Parliament, Christopher Kibanzanga, held seven peace meetings with the commanders of the ADF in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The talks concerned the possibility peace in the Ruwenzovi region in western Uganda. The peace talks were the result of a letter sent by the ADF leadership to the Ugandan army saying that they were ready to stop fighting. Commenting on the letter, a senior army commander stated that the Government of Uganda was willing to negotiate with the ADF.

In December 2007, it was the ADF leadership that tried to initiate negotiations. The head of MONUC, the UN peacekeeping force in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Olamide Adedeji, stated that MONUC’s political section had been in contact with the ADF leadership, who reportedly wanted to negotiate peace and go home. Confidential negotiations between the government of Uganda and the ADF, without the involvement of a third party, were held in Nairobi starting in May 2008. The negotiations were aimed at reaching a ceasefire and amnesty, but the talks failed because the negotiations were complicated as a result of the fragmentation of the ADF's leadership. In mid-December 2008, it was reported that both sides expected that formal peace talks would be initiated in early 2009, but these talks never materialised. In June 1996, a group of fighters broke away from WNBF, creating the Uganda National Rescue Front II (UNRF II). The circumstances under which the split occurred are not entirely clear, but reports indicate that it came about after Museveni had called for WNBF leader Juma Oris to surrender in exchange for amnesty. Opposed to making deals with the Government of Uganda, the elements who later assumed the name UNRF II instead left the movement. In December 1998, the Government of Uganda sent UNRF II a letter asking for a dialogue with the movement. UNRF II did not immediately respond to the offer of peace negotiations issued by the Government of Uganda in December 1998, but UNRF II commanders and a government delegation met for pre-negotiations in January 1999.
The UNRF II and the Government of Uganda conducted a round of pre-negotiations in June 2000, but these talks did not lead to any tangible results.

The Government of Uganda formed the Aringa-Obongi Peace Initiative Committee (AROPIC) in 2001 to act as the government negotiation team. A round of negotiations between the government delegation and the UNRF II leadership was subsequently held in Khartoum in November 2001.
Another round of negotiations was held in Nairobi later in November 2001. While these negotiations took place abroad, no third party was involved in these negotiations.

Another round of negotiations between the UNRF II and the Government of Uganda took place in early 2002. Several days of negotiations in Arua State Lodge  in June 2002 led to the signing of a formal ceasefire agreement on 15 June 2002.

Negotiations in December 2002 led to signing of the Yumbe Peace Agreement on 24 December 2002. The Chairman for the Uganda Amnesty Commission, Justice Onega, mediated the negotiations, but no international third parties were involved.

A unilateral victory by either side was increasingly perceived as unlikely in the civil war in Angola by the end of the 1980s. This explains why both President dos Santos and Savimbi, attended a conference organised by Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko in Gbadolite, Zaire, in June 1989, that involved 20 African countries. Prior to this meeting, Mobutu had obtained a mandate to mediate from the conflict parties through separate meetings on two occasions with Savimbi and Angolan President Eduardo dos Santos to “restore peace and National Reconciliation in Angola.” He had also consulted the regional heads of state at a summit in Tokyo on 22 February 1989 and a conference of regional leaders in Luanda on 16 May 1989. According to some observers, Mobuto wanted to portray himself as a regional peacemaker, since he lost some influence due to the end of the Cold War. The Gbadolite peace agreement was signed on 22 June 1989. The heads of states of the following countries attended the conference in Gbadolite: Zambia, Botswana, Burundi, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Chad, Congo, Gabon, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Tanzania, Zanzibar, Zimbabwe and the king of Morocco. Only a few days after President dos Santos and UNITA leader Savimbi signed the agreement, fighting erupted again with both parties disagreeing about the content of the agreement.
Mobutu undertook several mediation efforts to follow up on the agreement.
At a mini summit in Harare at the end of August, Mobutu and six other African Presidents endorsed the MPLA’s interpretation of the agreement in an attempt to save the peace process.
Mobutu also directly met with representatives of the conflict parties to rescue the peace process, including at meetings in France at the end of October.

A series of clashes at Mavinga in early 1990 cost the MPLA government between 400 and 800 million dollars and between 4,000 and 6,000 lives. Consequently, President dos Santos started looking for a third party and invited Portugal to mediate. Portugal’s Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Jose Durao Barroso, convened the first round of negotiations between the two sides in Evora, Portugal, on 24-25 April 1990. The peace talks initiated by Portugal continued for 18 months and involved six rounds of negotiations.
Savimbi withdrew the UNITA delegation at the second round of talks in June 1990.

Nevertheless, a third round of negotiations was held in Evora in July 1990. A breakthrough occurred in the summer of 1990 when the MPLA government abandoned its Marxist inspired ideology and compromised to the principle of “evolution to a multi-party state”, two points which the US had repeatedly emphasized as essential for their support to the peace process.

These concessions allowed the US and the Russia (Soviet Union) to become directly involved in the negotiations for the first time in the fourth round of talks in September 1990. The conflict parties agreed at this fourth round of negotiations that once a schedule for a ceasefire and elections had been negotiated, military support from the US and the Russia (Soviet Union) to the conflict parties would end.

The negotiations gained further momentum during the fifth round of negotiations in December 1990, when United States Secretary of State James Baker held several meetings with Angolan Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi in Washington, which led to what became known as the Washington Concepts Paper. The meeting in Washington, which was also attended by the Portuguese intermediaries and Soviet diplomats, led to what became known as the Washington Concepts Paper. The Washington Concept Paper stipulated that once a ceasefire would be concluded the conflict parties would organize free and fair elections; and that the parties would create a national army between the time of the conclusion of the ceasefire and the elections. The Washington Concept Paper further specified that the restructuring of the army and holding of elections were to be overseen by a UN monitoring force.

As a result of the Washington Concepts Paper, most of the underlying issues had been resolved by the time the sixth round of negotiations started on 4 April 1991. This allowed the conflict parties to focus on the remaining key issues, which were the formulation of a unified national army, the setting of dates for a ceasefire and multiparty elections, and the international monitoring of implementation of an agreement. Of these remaining issues, the election date proved to be the most contentious point. While the MPLA government demanded the election to be held three years after the ceasefire date, UNITA proposed the elections to be held as early as nine months after the ceasefire. It was only after the US and the Russia (Soviet Union) agreed to take part in the implementation process of the agreement that the conflict parties agreed to the elections taking place 18 months after the ceasefire would take effect, which was set on 15 May 1991.

On 31 May 1991, the Bicesse Agreement was signed. A variety of different mediation methods were used by the third parties to move the conflict parties towards the Bicesse Accords. First, the Bush administration made negotiations more attractive to the MPLA Government by promising that if the conflict parties would reach a negotiated settlement, then Washington would normalise relations with the MPLA Government and recognise it.  Second, the third parties used military inducements, both through extending and refusing to extend military assistance. Seeking to maintain their position in Southern Africa, the US had been supporting UNITA, while the Russia (Soviet Union) had been supporting the MPLA government. However, as the Cold War waned by the end of the 1980s, the conflict parties could no longer depend on unqualified support from their clients. Besides scaling back their support, both Washington and Moscow became increasingly willing to apply pressure to the conflict parties in favour of a peaceful solution to the conflict. The US drew on its patron client relationship with UNITA by urging the latter to make public statements calling for national reconciliation, making it easier for the MPLA government to reach out. The US had also tacitly assured dos Santos that with national reconciliation, the military aid to UNITA would be ended. In addition, the third parties guaranteed the implementation of the Bicesse Accords. The agreement stipulated that representatives of Portugal, the USA and the USSR, together with sub-groups and members of the government and UNITA, were to take part in the joint Politico-Military Commission (CCPM), with the task of overseeing the political and ceasefire process. It was also agreed that around 30 observer states would be involved in the implementation process, as well as a UN force of 800 people financed by a US grant of 40 million US Dollars. Moreover, President dos Santos was promised by US Secretary of State James Baker that “the USA had all the means to guarantee the implementation of the accords and also to prevent the accords being violated.”

However, the concluded peace was unstable. Several minor confrontations took place between soldiers and police loyal to the MPLA and supporters of the UNITA after the signing of the Bicesse Accords. On 6 February 1992, the UN Secretary-General appointed Miss Margaret Joan Anstee as his Special Representative to coordinate all United Nations activities in connection with the Angola Peace Accords. Although no large-scale fighting took place until after the elections in the last week of September 1992, the security situation deteriorated as the elections came closer. Representatives from Portugal, the US and Russia (Soviet Union) continued their efforts in the CCPM, set up under the Bicesse accord, with the task of overseeing the political and ceasefire process. It was stipulated in this peace agreement that the CCPM was mandated to ensure the “implementation and functioning of the mechanisms instituted to verify and exercise control over the ceasefire, provided for in the [Bicesse Accords] documents signed on this subject.” The UN Angola Verification Mission II (UNAVEM II) also continued its work and in addition to the monitoring of the military aspects of the agreement, it also oversaw the elections in late 1992. On 31 October, the United Nations brokered a truce between the Angolan government and UNITA in Huambo.
In another round of negotiations mediated by the UN,  the two sides reaffirmed commitment to the 1991 peace agreement and a ceasefire on 26 November.

The MPLA won both the parliamentary and presidential elections, although the presidential elections required a second round of elections since dos Santos did not receive more than the required 50 percent of the votes. In spite of the UN describing the elections to be free and fair, UNITA leader Savimbi claimed fraud, left Luanda and resumed UNITA’s fight against the government.  When UNITA took up arms again after the elections, the UN Security Council imposed sanctions against UNITA’s war effort. UN Security Council Resolution 864 issued on 15 September 1993 stipulated that all countries were prohibited from selling arms, petroleum, and related products to UNITA. Later resolutions also imposed travel restrictions and trade measures. In addition to imposing sanctions, the UN sponsored negotiations. In January 1993, government and UNITA delegations met in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to discuss both political and military matters. However, the talks broke down without an agreement on a ceasefire. A second round of negotiations was due to take place the following week, but was postponed indefinitely when UNITA withdrew their support.

In April 1993, UN-sponsored peace talks were held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The negotiations continued for 6 weeks, and revolved around issues like national reconciliation, UNITA enhanced participation in national, provincial and local government, and the respect for the Bicesse Accord. However, the parties failed to reach an agreement on a ceasefire and the talks broke down in late May.

Following a series of setbacks on the battlefield, UNITA agreed to preliminary talks aimed at discussing the details of formal peace negotiations. This peace initiative was led by the new UN special envoy to Angola, Alione Blondin Beye, who was mandated to implement the Bicesse Accords. American, Russia (Soviet Union)n, and Portuguese diplomats also took part in the mediation effort led by Beye. These exploratory talks started in Lusaka in October. These exploratory talks ended with UNITA issuing a communiqué reaffirming the validity of the Bicesse Accords, opening the way for new peace talks.

As a result, in December 1993, a new round of peace talks was launched in Lusaka, Zambia, by the new UN’s special envoy to Angola, Alione Blondin Beye, who was mandated to implement the Bicesse Accords.

The negotiations launched in Lusaka in November 1993, at which Beye acted as the chief mediator, continued throughout 1994. American, Russia (Soviet Union) and Portuguese diplomats also took part, including US President Bill Clinton’s special envoy, Paul Hare. On 16 November, the two sides signed a truce in order to support the ongoing peace talks. The Lusaka Accord was signed on 20 November 1994. The accord stipulated that a Joint Commission would oversee the peace agreement. This was to be composed of government and UNITA representatives and chaired by the Alioune Blondin Beye, while representatives of Portugal, Russia (Soviet Union) and the USA were to be observers. On 8 December 1994, the UN Security Council mandated Beye and the Joint Commission to “continue their efforts aimed at the full implementation of the “Acordos de Paz” [Bicesse Accords], the Lusaka Protocol and relevant Security Council resolutions.”

Due to repeated crises in the peace process – both as a result of and resulting in – severe delays in the implementation of the Lusaka Accord, the Secretary-General’s special envoy to Angola was active in a number of mediation efforts from 1995 until early 1999, both together with US, Portuguese and Russia (Soviet Union)n representatives in the Joint Commission and in other contexts. UNITA and the Government of Angola held a round of negotiations, mediated by the UN, in February 1995 to discuss violations of the Lusaka Protocol.

On 6 May 1995, UN-brokered negotiations in Lusaka brought together dos Santos and Savimbi for the first time in 3 years. They both reaffirmed their commitment to implement the accord. This summit meeting was expected to facilitate the task of the UN Peacekeeping force, which was to be deployed in the country.
In July 1995, further talks were held in Lusaka, focusing this time on the implementation of the military aspect of the accord.

In August 1995, dos Santos and Savimbi met at the Franceville summit in Gabon. Negotiations did not reach any concrete results. The key stumbling block was the disarmament of UNITA, the confinement to barracks of government security forces and the formation of a single national army.

Another meeting was held in Libreville, Gabon, on 1 March 1996, where dos Santos and Savimbi managed to reach an agreement on the formation of a government of national unity within the following four months. Savimbi also committed himself to complete the quartering of UNITA forces by June 1996 and both leaders agreed that the formation of the unified armed forces should be concluded by the same date. President dos Santos repeated his invitation for Savimbi to become a vice-president, but the latter failed to respond. The creation of a government of national unity was never realised.

In mid-March 1997, the Joint Commission finally managed to meet after five successive postponements. Agreement was reached on some, including the granting of “special status” to Savimbi, following his rejection of the title of vice-president in late 1996. It was agreed at the same meeting that several UNITA leaders would become members of Parliament, providing the first parliamentary opposition to the MPLA since Angola gained independence in 1975. Dos Santos dissolved his government and subsequently formed a government of national unity in April 1997, with four UNITA cabinet ministers and seven deputy ministers.

Negotiations aimed at implementing the Lusaka Declaration continued following the establishment of a government of national unity. On 9 January 1998, negotiations took place in Luanda, attended by dos Santos together with a delegation from government and UNITA.  A new schedule was agreed for the implementation of the accord, stipulating that the terms of the protocol was to be fulfilled by 28 February. However, this failed to materialise. Since this deadline was yet again not met, the UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on UNITA on 25 June 1998, which stipulated the freezing of UNITA’s foreign bank accounts and a ban on the purchase of Angolan diamonds without a certificate of origin, as well as prohibited all air and water transport in and out of the territories controlled by UNITA. Savimbi had indicated on 6 June 1998 that if the UN would impose new sanctions, UNITA would regard this as an attack on UNITA to which it was ready to respond. Indeed, following the imposition of new UN sanctions, UNITA immediately seized control in some of the localities in which it had transferred power to the central government. By the end of 1998, the Government of Angola had lost patience with the lack of implementation of the Lusaka Protocol and resumed the civil war. At an MPLA congress held in early December 1998, President dos Santos stated that “the only path to lasting peace is the total isolation of Jonas Savimbi and his movement.” Large-scale armed fighting subsequently resumed.

It was not until 2002 that the conflict parties engaged in dialogue again. These talks followed the death of UNITA leader Savimbi, who was killed by government forces on 22 February 2002, plans were immediately made to initiate peace talks. The Government of Angola initially indicated that its counter-insurgency campaign against UNITA would continue in spite of Savimbi’s death, but following a series of meetings President dos Santos held with the Portuguese Government in Lisbon, President George W. Bush in Washington, and UN Under Secretary for African Affairs Ibrahim Gambari in New York, the Government of Angola announced on 2 March that it would contact UNITA to prepare the ground for a ceasefire.

The Secretary-general of UNITA, Paulo Lukamba, subsequently formed the so-called Management Committee which was to negotiate with the Government of Angola. The conflict parties engaged in informal discussions, which led the Government of Angola to declare a unilateral ceasefire on 13 March. The Government of Angola also presented a peace plan, which called for negotiations on the outstanding military and political issues in accordance with the Bicesse Accords and Lusaka Protocol. No third parties were involved in the peace process, but the UN endorsed the peace plan. The UN Special Representative in Angola, Mussagy Jeichande, expressed satisfaction with the peace plan, describing it as “conciliatory.” Crucially, UNITA’s breakaway factions, which had challenged Savimbi’s leadership in 1998, also supported the peace talks. UNITA-Renavado leader Eugenio Manuvakola publicly declared not to interfere with the peace negotiations, reportedly allowing “UNITA to represent UNITA.”

Preliminary talks between the conflict parties subsequently started on 15 March in the town of Cassamba in Moxico province. It was agreed at these talks that official negotiations would mainly focus technical military matters. The conflict parties also decided that the provincial capital Luena would be the venue of the peace talks, because the Government of Angola had the necessary facilities in this town to host talks, but the town was also close to the battlefield. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire at Cassamba on 18 March. In spite of the ceasefire, some low-level fighting continued throughout Angola.

Yet, the negotiators kept the positive momentum, insisting that this fighting was only the result of a lack of information getting to the fighting elements. Official peace talks started on 20 March in Luena. The UNITA delegation was headed by UNITA’s Information Secretary Marcial Dachala and by UNITA’s Secretary for Foreign Affairs Alcides Sakala. The negotiations focused mainly on the technicalities of a ceasefire and the DDR process. The negotiators agreed that the Lusaka Protocol would be taken as the basis for the political resolution of the conflict. On 30 March 2002, the parties agreed on a ceasefire agreement, referred to as the Luena Memorandum.

The Luena Memorandum was formally signed in Luanda on 4 April 2002. The agreement essentially provides for the implementation of a ceasefire and the signatories’ compliance with the outstanding clauses of the Lusaka peace agreement from 1994. In contrast to the peace agreements previously concluded to end Angola’s civil war, the security provisions in the Luena Memorandum were quickly implemented. No armed fighting took place following the signing of the agreement and UNITA troops began to move towards the assembly points designated by the Luena Agreement on the same day the agreement was signed. UNITA officially gave up its armed wing on 2 August 2002, declaring it would from this moment onwards solely be a political party.

In June 2004, the Government of Ethiopia and the ONLF agreed to mediation by Kenya and the United Kingdom. Representatives of ONLF held talks with the Ethiopian government in both Nairobi and London. The London talks were held between ONLF secretary-general, Muhammad Sirad Dolal, and officials from the Ethiopian embassy. The Nairobi talks involved ONLF chairman, Muhammad Umar Usman and an official from the Ethiopian Foreign Affairs Ministry. The Government offered political positions to the ONLF leadership on the condition that the group be disbanded, but no agreement was reached.

In June 2004, the Government of Ethiopia and the ONLF agreed to mediation by Kenya and the United Kingdom. Representatives of ONLF held talks with the Ethiopian government in both Nairobi and London. The London talks were held between ONLF secretary-general, Muhammad Sirad Dolal, and officials from the Ethiopian embassy. The Nairobi talks involved ONLF chairman, Muhammad Umar Usman and an official from the Ethiopian Foreign Affairs Ministry. The Government offered political positions to the ONLF leadership on the condition that the group be disbanded, but no agreement was reached.

Talks mediated by Kenya were scheduled to take place in August, but were postponed due to the death of President Meles. A first meeting was subsequently held between 6 and 7 September 2012, when a delegation from the Ethiopian government, led by Defence Minister Siraj Fegisa, met an ONLF delegation under the leadership of the group’s foreign secretary Abd-al-Rahman Mahdi. A Kenyan mediation team under the leadership of Yusuf Haji, the Defence and a Kenyan Ogaadeni, functioned as the chief mediator during the process that aimed to start up official negotiations between the Ethiopian government and ONLF. At this initial meeting, the parties focused mainly on the modalities for future talks and at the end of it, they had agreed on principles to end the conflict. It was announced by ONLF that the two sides were committed to holding formal negotiations to solve the conflict; that the goal of the process was to attain just and lasting peace; that the negotiations were to be comprehensive, addressing the root causes of the conflict; that no preconditions were to be made of either party; that the substantive agenda was to include issues that would facilitate the implementation of a future agreement; and, finally, that both parties were to agree to specific measure of good-will and confidence-building in order to create a favourable climate for the negotiations.

The Nairobi talks resumed in October 2012, but soon ran into difficulties as the government delegation insisted that the continuation of the talks depended on the ONLF first accepting the Ethiopian constitution, thereby accepting Ogaden as being part of Ethiopia.

On 12 August 2018, the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) declared a unilateral ceasefire. The leadership of the group publicly stated that it declared the ceasefire in response to call for peace by the Ethiopian government led by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed. The improvement in relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea in July 2018 gave further impetus to the peace process between the Government of Ethiopia on the one hand and the OLF and the ONLF on the other hand. In spite of Eritrea hosting both groups on its territory, it initiated a mediation effort between the Ethiopian government and these two rebel groups. A round of negotiations in Asmara mediated by Eritrea led to the signing of a peace agreement between the government and the ONLF on 21 October 2018. Many ONLF leaders subsequently returned to Ogaden to transform the group into a political party ahead of 2020 elections.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration Between the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia And The Ogaden National Liberation Front

description: A POLISARIO delegation, led by Mahfoud Ali Beiba, held negotiations with King Hassan II in Marrakesh on 4 and 5 January 1989, although the King described the meeting as “discussions” rather than “negotiations”. The talks took place without the involvement of any third party and was instead chaired by King Hassan II himself. However, the UN Secretary-General remained involved in the conflict throughout the year, particularly with regard to the implementation of the in 1988 presented peace plan, which aimed to end the war by holding a referendum to decide on the future status of the disputed territory.

In June 1990, the Secretary-General presented a more elaborate plan, including a timetable for the process. This plan was approved by the UN Security Council, calling on both Morocco and POLISARIO to “co-operate fully” with the Secretary-General. On the basis of the this new mandate, Pérez de Cuellar arranged a meeting with the conflict parties in Geneva held in late June 1990, but he failed to convince the Moroccan side to engage in official negotiations during five days of pre-negotiations under the auspices of the UN.
In 1991, Pérez de Cuellar mediated between the conflict parties throughout the entire year regarding updating the administrative aspects of his peace plan.

On 28 June, the government of Morocco and POLISARIO agreed to a ceasefire starting on 6 September, mediated by the UN. On 19 December, less than two weeks before he would leave office, the UN Secretary-General submitted a final report to the UN Security Council, recommending extending the eligibility of potential voters in the referendum. However, the proposal was only “welcomed” by the UN Security Council. Nevertheless, Morocco began moving around 170,000 individuals to the Western Sahara who were supposedly allowed to vote on the basis of Pérez de Cuellar’s proposed criteria.

On 26 January 1992, Boutros-Ghali issued an update report on the situation in the Western Sahara, outlining different options to resolve the conflict. The Security Council choose to pursue the resolution of the conflict on the basis of intensification of talks and mandated the UN Secretary-General and his Special Representative “to intensify their efforts, with the parties, in order to resolve the issues ... in particular those relating to the interpretation and application of the criteria for voter eligibility.” On the basis of this mandate, the Secretary-General travelled to the region in June 1992 and consulted with both Moroccan Government and representatives of POLISARIO in a round of pre-negotiations.

This led to initiation of official negotiations between the adversaries in the Sahrawi capital of Al-Ayounby mid-July 1992. Although these negotiations took place under UN auspices, the UN did not act as mediator during the talks. Another meeting was scheduled in New York for October 1993, but instead of sending Government officials, Morocco sent Sahrawi defectors to negotiate.

In 1997, the UN succeeded in mediating four rounds of direct negotiations. James Baker, who had been appointed by UN Secretary-General by Kofi Annan as his Personal Envoy on 18 March 1997, acted as the chief mediator during these peace talks. The first round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London in June 1997.

The second round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London in July 1997. The second round resulted in a compromise proposal concerning the identification process of people eligible to vote in the planned referendum.

The third round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in Lisbon in August 1997. The third round resulted in an agreement regarding the how to deal with the prisoners of war and political detainees.

The fourth round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in Houston September 1997. The four rounds of negotiations were referred to as a “breakthrough” by POLISARIO. As a result of these talks, the identification process was restarted in December 1997.

In 2000, James Baker mediated another three rounds of talks. The first round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London on 14 May 2000. These talks were also attended by neighbouring Algeria and Mauritania. No progress was made, and the meeting ended with Baker inviting the parties to come forward at the next meeting with concrete suggestions on how to resolve the multiple problems facing the settlement plan launched by the UN in 1988 and discussed ever since, or else, to be prepared to discuss alternative options.

The second round of negotiations mediated by the UN was held in London on 28 June 2000. The parties both presented areas of difficulties with the settlement plan, but neither offered specific proposals to resolve these problematic areas, which both could agree to.

On 28 September 2000, the third and final round of negotiations mediated by the UN of the year was held in Berlin. Since no progress was made and neither party seemed open to discuss their position, Baker suggested that new options should be explored. However, both POLISARIO and the Moroccan representatives reiterated their commitment to the settlement plan, while disagreeing on how to implement it.

In January 2003, Baker presented a new peace plan to the parties, named the “Peace plan for self-determination of the people of Western Sahara”, also known as the Baker Plan II. This plan provided for a referendum to take place within four to five years. The final vote would offer the inhabitants of the territory a choice between independence, autonomy within Morocco or complete integration with Morocco. The plan also proposed that, in the run-up to the referendum, an autonomous Western Sahara Authority would be made responsible for running key parts of the administration, taking control of local government, taxation, economic development, internal security and other dossiers. Yet, Morocco would retain control over foreign relations, national security, external defence and all matters relating to the production, sale, ownership and use of weapons during the interim period.

Following a round of negotiations in July, POLISARIO accepted the plan, but the Government of Morocco rejected it. The main obstacle for the government was that one of the ballot choices was independence.

On 30 April 2007, the UN Security Council adopted resolution 1754, in which it called upon the parties to enter negotiations. A first round of negotiations under UN auspices was held in June 2007, in which Van Walsum acted as the chief mediator.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Van Walsum took place in August 2007. However, no agreement was reached as the government continued to stick to its proposal for limited autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty for Western Sahara, while POLISARIO maintained its demand for a referendum with a choice of autonomy or independence. In December, POLISARIO threatened that they would consider going back to armed conflict to “speed up the process.”
Between 7 and 9 January 2008, Van Walsum mediated negotiations in Manhasset, near New York City. The talks ended without the parties reaching further agreement than to resume talks in March.

As a result, another round of mediated negotiations in Manhasset took place on 18 and 19 March 2008, but again without success. In May 2008, POLISARIO again expressed their scepticism regarding the possibility of a political solution and again threatened to resume violence. POLISARIO further demanded that Peter Van Walsum had to be replaced, since he had expressed that independence for Western Sahara was unrealistic

Van Walsum was replaced on 14 January 2009 by Christopher Ross, as the UN Secretary-General for Western Sahara. In February, Ross began a series of separate meetings with the concerned parties in the conflict.

Ross mediated direct talks between the parties in Duernstein, Austria, on 10 and 11 August 2009. Although the parties appeared satisfied with the talks and promised continued negotiations in the near future, no progress towards an agreement appeared to have been made, as Morocco continued to propose autonomy while POLISARIO demanded a referendum and possible independence.

Ross mediated three rounds of negotiations between the government of Morocco and POLISARIO in 2010. He first mediated informal talks near New York in February 2010, but these broke down after two days without reaching any progress.

The two parties met again for talks mediated by UN Special Representative Ross in New York on 8 and 9 November 2010. Yet, these talks were overshadowed by the Moroccan military entering a camp near Laayoune just days before the talks, resulting in a small number of fatalities.
New talks mediated by the UN were held in New York between 16 and 18 December 2010. While each party continued to reject the proposals of the other, they agreed to meet again for talks in 2011.
UN Special Representative Ross mediated a round of negotiations in Malta in March 2011.
Another round of UN-mediated negotiations was held in New York in May 2011.
Another round of UN-mediated negotiations was held in New York in June 2011. However, the parties continued to reject each other’s proposals.

The Government of Morocco and POLISARIO engaged in negotiations outside of New York in March 2012. The talks were mediated by Christopher Ross, the personal of the UN Secretary-general for Western Sahara. Mauritania and Algeria also participated in the mediation efforts at this meeting.
UN Special Representative Christopher Ross mediated a round of shuttle negotiations between the conflict parties in February 2016.
Another round of shuttle negotiations mediated by Ross took place in September 2016.
Another round of shuttle negotiations mediated by the UN took place from late November to early 2017.
Köhler managed to initiate the first face-to-face negotiations between the conflict parties on 5 and 6 December 2018. These negotiations took place in Geneva.
Another round of negotiations mediated by Köhler took place in Geneva on 21 and 22 March 2019.

South Africa mediated peace talks from May until September 1989. Since South Africa previously had provided secondary support, its mediation efforts in Mozambique are coded as biased. On 3 October, South African Minister of International Relations and Cooperation, Pik Botha, announced that Mozambique and Renamo had signed the Joint Declaration on a Cessation of Armed Activity and Conflict and that talks would continue on outstanding issues. However, both parties made statements indicating that fighting would continue until a full agreement would be reached. In addition, the South African mediation efforts came under increasing pressure from the South African military and other domestic group. On 2 November 1984, Renamo withdrew from the talks. In September 1988, President Chissano met South African President Pieter Willem Botha at Songo in the Tete province, where they promised to commit to the in 1984 concluded Nkomati accord. In addition, Chissano gave permission to senior leaders of the Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Protestant Churches to open direct contacts with Renamo leaders. Exploratory talks between church leaders in Mozambique and a delegation from Renamo were held in Nairobi in August in 1989. The goal of these talks was to prepare for direct talks between the Government of Mozambique and the rebel movement. The talks were chaired by President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who had been officially requested to mediate by the Government of Mozambique on 21 July. The mediation efforts of Moi and Mugabe continued throughout the rest of the year, but they did not succeed in initiating direct negotiations.

The first direct talks between the conflict parties were held in Rome between 8 and 12 July 1990. This was the starting point of what came to be known as the Rome process, brokered by two members of the Catholic Community of Sant’Egidio, as well as the Archbishop of Beira Jaime Gonçalves, and Italian government representative Mario Raffaelli. Mugabe and Moi participated in the first round of talks, but due to accusations of being biased they ended their mediation efforts after this round of negotiations. Zimbabwe was considered as biased towards the Government by Renamo because of its military support, while the Government perceived Kenya to be biased towards Renamo because of a Renamo presence on Kenyan territory.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; Italy; Kenya; Zimbabwe

description: The second round of negotiations of the Rome process took place between 11 and 14 August 1990, but ended in deadlock. It was reported that Renamo was reluctant to address substantial issues.

The parties came together for a third round of talks from 8 November to 1 December 1990, which led to a partial ceasefire. The conflict parties agreed to stop fighting in the Beira and Maputu corridors, which link Zimbabwe and other landlocked countries with the ocean. It was also decided that the number of Zimbabwean troops would be reduced by half and confined to the corridors.

In late December 1990, during the fourth round of negotiations, a Joint Verification Committee – consisting of members of the government, Renamo, and eight countries – was set up to monitor the ceasefire, ensuring nondefection. Of the eight countries serving on the committee, Renamo chose Kenya, Portugal, the US, and Zambia, while the Government selected Congo, France, the UK, and the Russia (Soviet Union). In addition, from the start of the Rome talks onwards, the Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes.

Parallel to the Rome process initiated in 1990, President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia and Tiny Rowland, a British businessman, launched a separate initiative. Rowland was the chairman of Lonroho, a company based in the United Kingdom which was the first major transnational corporation to make major investments in Mozambique. Rowland regarded the civil war as a serous hindrance to expansion of his business interests, which is why he worked to initiate a face-to-face meeting between President Chissano and Renamo leader Dhlakama. However, Rowland did not mediate direct negotiations during 1990.

The fifth round of talks in the framework of the Rome negotiations – which were mediated by the Roman Catholic Community of Sant’Egidio, the Archbishop of Beira, and the Italian government – took place from 23 January to early February 1991. The talks were supposed to address the major disagreements, including issues related to electoral procedures, but no progress was made.
During the sixth round of talks, held in May 1991, an agenda for negotiations was agreed upon and the Protocol on the Agreed Agenda was signed on 28 May 1991.

Tiny Rowland together with Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe managed to convince Renamo leader Dhlakama and President Chissano to meet face to face for negotiations in Dhlakama, Botswana, on 5 July 1992.  As a result of the meeting in Botswana, the parties signed, on 7 August 1992, a declaration of intent to sign a ceasefire in early October 1992.
The seventh round of negotiations in July 1991 broke down as Renamo introduced new demands.

However, during the eighth round of talks, held in October 1991, substantial progress was made. On 18 October a protocol on Fundamental Principles was signed, where Renamo recognised the legitimacy of the Government during a transitional period between a formal ceasefire and elections. The protocol confirmed the May agenda and cleared the ground for a general peace agreement once a protocol for each agenda item had been negotiated.
On 13 November, a partial peace agreement, dealing with criteria for political parties was signed: the Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties.
agreement_name: Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties

description: On the ninth round of negotiations in December 1991, a joint communiqué confirming consensus on simultaneous presidential and parliamentary elections supervised by the UN and the Organization of African Unity and held within a year of the signing of a general peace agreement, was issued. Throughout the Rome talks, the Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes.

The mediation efforts of Rowland, which were conducted separately from the Rome process, continued in 1991. This process stalled due to Chissano’s refusal to attend a meeting mediated by Rowland until the Rome peace talks reached agreement on a nationwide ceasefire.
