Zambia also consulted the conflict parties, encouraging them to conclude a negotiated settlement in Rome.

Round ten of the Rome negotiations – which were mediated by the Roman Catholic Community of Sant’Egidio, the Archbishop of Beira, and the Italian government – took place between 21 January and 12 March 1992. The tenth round resulted in the signing of a protocol, which supplemented the earlier agreements on electoral issues.

In mid-June 1992, round eleven of the negotiations started. They were supposed to focus on military issues, but instead revolved around famine relief due to the worst drought in 30 years. British businessman
On 16 July 1992, representatives from the government of Mozambique and Renamo reached a ceasefire agreement in Rome in order to allow for humanitarian aid to reach rebel areas.
The twelfth round of the Rome process was initiated on 5 August 1992. The conflict parties signed a declaration of intent on 7 August 1992.

Negotiations on military issues continued until the end of September 1992. Finally, the Acordo General de Paz was signed on 4 October 1992. The Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes; in fact, by the time of the signing of the Rome Accord, the Government of Italy had spent around 20 million US Dollars on purchases to promote cooperation in the peace process.

On 15 April 2012, Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama met with the Mozambican president in Maputo to discuss issues of security and defense. These negotiations did not lead to a peace agreement. In response to several armed attacks conducted by Renamo in October 2012, the Government of Mozambique agreed in November 2012 to meet and negotiate with the organization.
The two sides subsequently convened at a hotel in Maputo on 3 December 2012.

On 17 April 2013, the government invited Renamo to a round of negotiations in Maputo on 22 April, but this invitation was rejected by the Renamo on the basis of preferring a different location. Ultimately, the two sides met for bilateral peace talks at the Joaquim Chissano Conference Centre  in Maputo on 2 May 2013.
Another  peace meeting was held in Maputo on 13 May 2013.
The parties also met for negotiations in Maputo on 20 May 2013.
Another round of negotiations was held in early June.
The conflict parties also met in mid-June for negotiations.

Negotiations in early September 2013 were terminated because Renamo demanded a third-party mediator to be involved. The Community of Sant’Egidio, which had also been heavily involved in mediation during the first civil war, subsequnetly started to play a leading role in mediation.

Community of Sant’Egidio mediator Matteo Zuppi mediated a round of negotiations in late September 2013. The negotiations did not lead to any tangible results. While the government side demanded that all Renamo troops would lay down their weapons, Renamo demanded the withdrawal of government troops from the main Renamo stronghold, the Gorongosa area. Renamo also demanded a better representation within the armed forces, a share of the mineral revenues, and a new electoral law.

Negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio in October 2013 broke down, after which the government forces managed to capture the main Renamo bases at Satunjira and Maringue in October 2013. Renamo subsequently retreated to the bush and engaged in small scale attacks.
During pre-negotiations in in December 2013, the government agreed to involve local observers in future discussions with Renamo.
During a round of pre-negoiations on 1 February 2014, the conflict parties agreed on a list of national observers to attend future rounds of negotiations.
A round of negotiations on 10 February 2014 led to an agreement that called for the restructuring of the the National Electoral Commission.
On 15 February 2014, another round of negotiations was held.
The government conced to international mediation during a round of pre-negotiations on 17 March 2014.
On 24 March 2014, during another round of pre-negotiations, the two sides agreed to the Southern African Development Community (SADC) being an observer.
Following another round of negotiations on 14 April 2014, Renamo agreed to disarm and reintegrate its members into the national army.
From 22 April to 23 April, the government and Renamo enagaged in negotiations that ended with the former agreeing to let the Renamo leadership potentially run in forthcoming presidential elections.

A round of negotiations that started on 21 July 2014 led to a full draft of a peace agreement on 28 July 2014. This draft agreement included provisions for a ceasefire and the reintegration of rebel members.  However, the agreement was neither formally signed nor implemented. The conflict parties continued to negotiate in 2014, but without the involvement of a third party.

Ahead of elections on 15 October 2014, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire in Maputo on 24 August 2014. As part of the negotiations, the government began to release Renamo prisoners a week prior to the conclusion of the ceasefire. The ceasefire was signed by Renamo’s chief negotiator Saimon Macuiane and government represnetatives. The ceasefire was seen as part of a wider attempt to bring peace to the country ahead of elections scheduled for October 2014. Saimon Macuiane, the Renamo’ chief negotiator, called the ceaefire an “important step towards national reconciliation... and a durable peace.”

A round of negotiations in September led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 5 September 2014. The agreement was signed by Mozambican President Arnando Guebuza Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama. The latter emerged from two years in hiding to sign the deal in the capital, Maputo. Foreign military observers under the Military Group for the Observation of the Military Hostilities (referred to as EMOCHM) mission would later arrive to oversee the implementation of this agreement. It was intended to last 135 days, but would be extende
From 7 to 9 February 2015, the Government of Mozambique and Renamo convened in Maputo for negotiations that were praised by the United Nations.
Between 4 and 12 May, the two sides engaged in negotiations. This did not lead to a peace agreement.
On 26 May 2015, another round of negotiations was held once again in Maputo.
In early June 2015, the EMOCHM foreign observers left the country.  Another round of negotations took place on 29 June 2015.
On 27 July 2015, a round of negotiations respectively took place in Maputo.

In August 2015, Renamo unilaterally suspended talks with the government. Nevertheless, the conflict parites resumed negotations in October 2015. Mozambican religious leaders and academic figures acted as mediators of these peace talks.
In mid-June 2016, the conflict parties agreed to the involvement of international mediators in their negotiations.

The subsequent mediation process was led by Community of Sant’Egidio, but mediators from the European Union were also involved. Mario Raffaeli of the by Community of Sant’Egidio acted as the coordinator of the international mediation team. These third parties mediated a round of negotiations in July 2016, only to terminate the negotiations in late July in the wake of escalating violence and an impasse over the status of the six northern and central provinces, which Dhlakama insisted were under Renamo’s control.

The mediation process subsequently stalled and the international mediation team left Mozambique in mid-December 2016. On 26 December, the parties reached a 7-day ceasefire agreement through bilateral negotiations over the phone.
The previously agreed upon ceasefire was extended for two months during a round of negotiations on 3 January 2017.

In February 2017, Switzerland was announced as a lead mediator in an international team intended to mediate between the rebels and government. However, in early March 2017, the Government of Mozambique announced that a further round of negotiations would be held, but without the involvement of international mediators. The ceasefire was extended once again in early May.
The parties met 11 May to for a round of negotiations.

At the start of August 2017, President Nyusi met with Dhlakama in the Gorongosa forest. No peace agreement came out this particular bilateral effort. It was also announced that mediated negotiations would be held in the future.
Switzerland took the lead in mediating these peace talks. Switzerland mediated a round of negotiations in October 2017.
Another round of negotiations was mediated by Switzerland in December 2017. Ultimately, the peace process did not move forward significantly in 2017.

On 3 May 2018, Afonso Dhlakama, the longtime and influential leader of RENAMO, died after suffering a heart attack. Peace talks between the rebel group and Mozambicean government continued in May 2018.
On 11 July 2018, leadership from both sides met for a peace talk in which progress was made regarding integration of former rebels.

A round of negotiations in August 2018 led to the signing of a memorandum of understanding on 6 August 2018 that outlined terms for disarmament. Later that year, in December 2018, several of Renamo officials were announced as new members of the Mozambicean government.

Swiss diplomats led the international mediation team that was involved in the peace efforts during 2019. Swiss-mediated negotiations in August led to the signing of a peace agreement by President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade at Renamo’s remote military base in the Gorongosa mountains on 1 August 2019.
They signed another peace agreement in Maputo on 6 August 2019.

On 6 April 1981, the Somali National Movement (SNM) was formed in London, stating it aimed to overthrow President Siad Barre and his “absolute and despotic dictatorship.” In November 1983, Collonel Abdikadir Kosar Abdi, a former member of the Somali army, was made chairman of the group, after which the SNM took up arms against the Government of Somalia. No negotiations or mediation took place between the Government of Somalia and SNM between 1983 and 1988. In 1989, the US Ambassador Frank Crigler urged the conflict parties to engage in peace talks. The US was in a good position to influence the Government of Somalia, as it had been providing military assistance to the Government of Somalia since 1983. Moreover, US Secretary of State James Baker had threatened the Somali Prime Minster that US bilateral assistance would be suspended unless the Government of Somalia would improve its respect for human rights and listen to the opposition movements. US diplomats subsequently talked to the SNM in one of the rebel organisation’s offices in Washington, while another US delegation held talks with the USC in Nairobi. As it had been severely weakened by mid-1989, the Barre regime accepted the offer to engage in official mediated negotiations. Yet, the rebel groups insisted that it was too late for negotiations, expressing that Barre had committed to many crimes and therefore had to go. Another mediation attempt was conducted by Italy and Egypt in 1990, which proposed a peace conference to be held in Cairo in December 1990. Although Egypt had been invited by Italy to join its peacemaking efforts, it was decided Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Egypt, would act as the chief mediator at this conference. Yet, while the Government accepted, the SNM and the USC again rejected negotiations. Fighting continued until the main Somalia rebel groups, including SNM, managed to overthrow the Barre regime on 26 January 1991. Instead of participating in the struggle over government power between the USC and a breakaway faction of the USC led by General Mohammed Farah Aideed, the SNM decided to solely take control of the Issaq clan territory in the northwest, where most of the SNM fighters were from. Since it just had proclaimed an independent Republic of Somaliland on 16 May 1991, the SNM did not participate in the Djibouti peace conferences in June and July 1991.The SNM did participate in the Addis Ababa conference in 1993. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasised that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared an immediate ceasefire and a cessation of all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: It was agreed at the first meeting of this committee on 22 January that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March 1993. A donor conference organised by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement on 27 March 1993. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohamed Farrah Aididon’s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October 1993, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: A third UN-sponsored conference in Addis Ababa was held in November-December 1993. Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.”
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: The Somali Patriotic Movement (SPM) emerged in 1989 after a group of Ogaden officers deserted the army and took up arms against Siad Barre, to overthrow the regime and establish a democratic form of government. In the power vacuum that followed after Barre’s fall, the USC declared their leader Ali Mahdi the interim President of Somalia. Several clan-based armed militias subsequently challenged Mahdi and began to violently compete for the presidency. In response to the growing tensions over tensions who should assume the presidency, the Government of Djibouti organised a conference June 1991, in which Egypt, the Arab League, Italy, and the US also acted as third parties. Hassan Gouled Aptidon, the President of Djibouti, acted as the chief mediator at this conference.
third_party: Egypt; Arab League; Italy; US; Djibouti

description: The same group of third parties mediated another conference in Djibouti in July 1991. Although the SNM and the USC Faction refused to attend this conference, the SSDF and the SPM agreed to talk to the USC led by the self-proclaimed new President of Somalia Ali Mahdi. US Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, Ivin Hicks, expressed support for Ali Mahdi’s designation as interim President. The Italian delegation also expressed their support for Mahdi and tried to persuade the insurgent groups to do the same. However, the conferences failed to reach a substantial outcome.
third_party: Egypt; Arab League; Italy; US; Djibouti

description: From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasised that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared an immediate ceasefire and a cessation of all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this committee on 22 January 1993 that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March. A donor conference organised by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement on 27 March 1993. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohamed Farrah Aididon’s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October 1993, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: A third UN-sponsored conference in Addis Ababa was held in November-December 1993. Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.” No negotiations or mediation took place in 1994, but the SPM participated in a conference aimed at reconciling three Darod clains in November 1995. On 29 November, the UN Secretary-General’s Representative for Somalia, Abdi Kabla, and the EU’s special envoy in Somalia, Sigurd Illing, talked to the vice chairman of the SPM, Ali Nuur, about peace and security in the Lower Juba and Middle Juba regions. Yet, this did not lead to any tangible results.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: In the power vacuum after Barre’s fall in January 1991, the United Somali Congress (USC) declared their leader Ali Mahdi the interim President of Somalia. The UCDP considers the USC led by Ali Mahdi as the government of Somalia from January 1991 onwards. Several clan-based armed militias began to violently compete for government control. This resistance against Mahdi assuming the Presidency not only came from other rebel groups. A military faction within the USC, led by General Mohammed Farah Aideed, also rejected Mahdi’s self-appointment as illegitimate. This group is referred to as the United Somali Congress / Somali National Alliance (USC/SNA), also known as the United Somali Congress Faction (USC Faction). Although internal competition within the USC was already prevalent well before Siyaad Barre was overthrown, tensions between the USC led by Ali Mahdi and the USC/SNAled by Aideed started to grow even further from early 1991 onwards. The Arab League tried to reconcile the USC and the USC Faction, but failed in persuading the latter to attend two peace conferences in Djibouti in June and July 1991. The conflict further escalated in September 1991, when Aideed demanded Mahdi’s resignation. Although there had been sporadic clashes between the forces loyal to Mahdi and Aideed in Mogadishu in March and June, fighting between 5 and 7 September resulted in hundreds of people killed. Between 3 and 5 January 1992, the UN assistant Secretary-General, James O. C. Jonah, visited Mogadishu in an attempt to end the fighting between Mahdi’s forces and the USC/SNA, but he failed in his mission.

In February 1992, talks between the two warring factions were held in New York under the auspices of the UN, the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League, and the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC). UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali had invited the conflict parties and acted as the chief mediator.
On 14 February 1992, the parties met again for talks mediated by Boutros-Ghali in which solely the UN was involved. This resulted in the signing of a ceasefire agreement, but fighting continued.

By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zinawi acted as the chief mediator of this conference that was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. It was further agreed that direct, bilateral discussions between the leaders of the different conflict parties would be held in November and December 1992, prior to the conference.On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC/SNA leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa.

Through much of late 1992, Mohamed Sahnoun, the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General, tried to mediate a ceasefire between the conflict parties. Sahoun had been appointed in March 1992 and was mandated to work out a “plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.”

From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasised that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared an immediate ceasefire and a cessation of all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this committee on 22 January 1993 that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March. A donor conference organised by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement on 27 March 1993. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohamed Farrah Aididon’s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October 1993, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: A third UN-sponsored conference in Addis Ababa was held in November-December 1993. Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.” No negotiations or mediation took place in 1994, but the SPM participated in a conference aimed at reconciling three Darod clains in November 1995. On 29 November, the UN Secretary-General’s Representative for Somalia, Abdi Kabla, and the EU’s special envoy in Somalia, Sigurd Illing, talked to the vice chairman of the SPM, Ali Nuur, about peace and security in the Lower Juba and Middle Juba regions. Yet, this did not lead to any tangible results.
third_party: Ethiopia; OAU;  Arab League; OIC; US

description: On 24 March 1994, Aideed and Mahdi signed a peace agreement in Nairobi, following negotiations brokered by Ambassador Lansana Kouyate of Guinea, who had been appointed the Acting Representative of the UN Secretary-General for the UNOSOM II mission in February 1994.
Peace talks were resumed in Cairo on 12 November, which resulted in the signing of the Cairo Declaration on Somalia on 22 December.
A ceasefire was declared by both conflict parties on 1 August 1996, following the death of USC/SNA leader Mohammed Farah.

However, heavy fighting erupted again in mid-August, after Aideed’s son, Hussein Aideed, had taken over the leadership of USC/SNA. Although the USC/SSA led by Mahdi, which is coded as the Government of Somalia, called for mediation by the UN, the USC Faction rejected this proposal, stating it objected outside interference. Nevertheless, between 9 and 15 October 1996, peace talks took place in Nairobi, under the aegis of the Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi. Moi’s mediation effort did not lead to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the adversaries did commit to an immediate cessation of hostilities. The ceasefire lasted until December when renewed fighting broke out in Mogadishu. As a response to the broken ceasefire, the EU initiated a mediation effort. In spite of several consultations with the conflict parties, the Italian Special Envoy, Giuseppe Casini, failed to initiate direct negotiations.

However, in January 1997, a meeting did take place between Mahdi and Aideed, which was mediated by Italian Special Envoy Giuseppe Casini. The negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire. Casini was now mandated by the EU, which closely coordinated its peacemaking efforts with Kenya.
Building on the momentum of the ceasefire, Kenya subsequently mediated negotiations in Nairobi in February 1997.
The EU stayed involved and in April 1997, the EU representative to Somalia, Sigurd Illing, met Aideed and Mahdi for negotiations on an end to armed violence in Mogadishu.
Between 4 and 12 May 1997, another round of talks was held in Yemen, which resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire.
This ceasefire was confirmed at a round of negotiations between Aideed and Mahdi in Cairo on 29 May 1997.

Although Mahdi and Aideed started cooperating and formed a joint administration in the Banadir region, fighting between different militias continued after 1997. Yet, it is impossible to identify a government side in Somalia between 1997 and 2000, which is why UCDP has coded the armed fighting taking place in this period as a non-state armed conflict rather than a state-based interstate conflict. In 2000, a Transitional National Government (TNG) was elected by clan elders in a conference in Djibouti, although the conference was boycotted by many opposition parties. In reaction to the formation of the TNG, the opposition formed an umbrella organisation on 30 March 2001, called the Somali Reconciliation and Restoration Council (the SRRC). After the formation of the TNG and the SRRC, the Somali armed groups became allied with either one of these two parties and the armed fighting resumed the nature of an intrastate conflict again.  Peace talks, mediated by Kenyan President Moi’s Special Envoy for Somalia Elijah Wasike Mwangale, between the TNG and SRRC were held on 23 and 24 December 2001 in Nakuru, Kenya. These talks led to a ceasefire, but not any substantial outcome on political issues.

A Reconciliation Conference in Eldoret, Kenya, started in October 2002. Numerous third parties were involved, but IGAD called for the conference on 15 October 2002 and subsequently organised the conference. Mwangale acted as the chief mediator at Eldoret. The first round of negotiations mediated by IGAD ended with the signing of a ceasefire between the TNG and the opposing groups on 27 October 2002.
third_party: IGAD; US; UN; EU; Arab League; Egypt; Kenya; Ethiopia; Djibouti; Eritrea; Sudan; Uganda

description: Another round of negotiations mediated by IGAD took place in mid-December 2002. More than 300 participants, divided in six committees with 23 delegates each were formed to deal with different aspects of the conflict. The committees included Federalism and Provisional Constitution, Demobilisation Disarmament and Reintegration, Land and Property Issues, Economic Recovery, Institution Building and Resource Mobilisation, and Regional and International Relations.
third_party: IGAD; US; UN; EU; Arab League; Egypt; Kenya; Ethiopia; Djibouti; Eritrea; Sudan; Uganda

description: A new round of negotiations mediated by IGAD at Eldoret started in January 2003. In addition, the work of the six committees formed the previous year, which were now assisted by external experts from the World Bank. Although representatives from the EU did not participate in the negotiations in 2003, the Peace Conference in Kenya was mainly funded by the EU and its member countries, as well as Norway. On 20 January, the newly elected Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki, appointed Bethuel Kiplagat as the chief meditator.
third_party: IGAD; US; UN; EU; Arab League; Egypt; Kenya; Ethiopia; Djibouti; Eritrea; Sudan; Uganda

description: A new round of negotiations that started in February 2003 was held in Nairobi rather than Eldoret. Throughout the first half of the year, several factions threatened to walk out on the peace talks, citing too much Ethiopian influence. Moreover, the mediation team experienced great difficulties in determening who spoke for whom or who could actually deliver on formal commitments, as a result of the fragmentation and the lineage-based politics.
third_party: IGAD; US; UN; EU; Arab League; Egypt; Kenya; Ethiopia; Djibouti; Eritrea; Sudan; Uganda

description: Following a round of negotiations in July 2003, representatives from both sides signed the Somali Interim Charter. However, President Abduqassim Salad Hassan rejected the accord and sacked the TNG representatives that had signed the Interim Charter in August 2003. In November, the UN Security Council urged all Somali leaders to reach an agreement on a viable government through a “Leaders meeting” that was being planned by IGAD in Kenya. The dates for the 10-day meeting were being pushed forward throughout December. At the end of the year, it was announced that the Conference would begin on 9 January 2004.
third_party: IGAD; US; UN; EU; Arab League; Egypt; Kenya; Ethiopia; Djibouti; Eritrea; Sudan; Uganda

description: Not much progress was made at the Somali peace conference in Kenya that started on 9 January 2004, when Ugandan and Kenyan mediators brought 38 Somali leaders into the Safari Park Hotel in Nairobi. The transitional charter agreed on in September 2003 was criticized during these negotiations.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Uganda; AU; UN; US

description: Three weeks later, on 29 January 2004, the Transitional Federal Charter for the Somali Republic, also referred to as the Safari Park Declaration, was signed by eight representatives. The revised transitional charter immediately became contested and after a month only three of the signatories still supported the Declaration. In early May, it seemed like the entire peace process would collapse. However, at the Sixth IGAD Ministerial Meeting on Somalia on 21 and 22 May 2004, the member states reaffirmed their unity of purpose and agreed to jointly push the process forward. The IGAD mediation team warned the Somali leaders that “spoilers and those who obstruct the process from within and outside SNRP [Somali National Reconciliation Process] will be named publicly and subject to targeted international sanctions.” A few days later, the AU also declared that targeted sanctions would be imposed against the Somali leaders who did not participate in the process.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Uganda; AU; UN; US
agreement_name: Transitional Federal Charter for the Somali Republic

description: On 22 August 2004, the first 194 members of the Transitional Parliament were sworn in at the UN complex in Nairobi. During the nomination period, the breakaway leaders had returned to participate in the negotiations, as preparations were made for the election of a president. On 14 October 2004, the Transitional Parliament elected Abdullahi Yusuf as interim president. The TNG thus transformed into Transitional Federal Government (TFG) in 2004. Negotiations continued until October.

In a radio broadcast on 21 July 2006, the newly appointed chairman of the Union of Islamic Courts (UIC), Sheik Hassan Dahir Aweys, declared that the TFG led by Abdullahi Yusuf was an Ethiopian puppet-regime that did not look after the interests of the Somali people. He argued that the presence of Ethiopian military near the parliament base of Baidoa was an infringement of Somali sovereignty and called on the Somali people to wage a holy war against Ethiopians and their servants. The UIC had been renamed on 25 June 2006 and was previously known as the Supreme Islamic Council of Somalia (SICS) or the Supreme Council of Islamic Courts (SCIC). The Arab League and Sudan hosted attempts to negotiate a peaceful solution to the tense relationship between the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and UIC. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and the Secretary-General of the Arab League, Amr Moussa, acted as joint chief mediators. A first round of negotiations mediated by the Arab League and Sudan took place in Khartoum on 22 June 2006.
A second round of negotiations mediated by the Arab League and Sudan took place in Khartoum on 2-4 September 2—6.
A third round of negotiations mediated by the Arab League and Sudan took place in Khartoum throughout October 2006. On 11 November, the TFG declared that there would be no more negotiations.

The AU and the UN were active as third parties in Somalia in 2008. Negotiations, mediated by the Special Representative for the UN Secretary-General for Somalia, Ahmedou Ould Abdalla, started in Djibouti on 31 May and lasted until 9 June 2008. The mediation team focused predominantly on securing a commitment to formal peace talks during the first half of 2008.

The peace process gained momentum when the conflict parties agreed on the basic principles of the peace process on 9 June 2008. It was among others agreed that the Ethiopian forces, which had intervened in Somalia in July 2006, would withdraw. This last issue caused led to the UIC to split in July. The basic principles were subsequently laid down during a round of negotiations in August 2008.
The principles were laid down in the Djibouti Agreement signed on 19 August 2008.

During another round of negotiations in November 2008, the Djibouti agreement was complemented on 26 November 2008. On 26 November, the two sides also came to an agreement on collaborating on Somalia Emergency Drought Relief (SEDR). Supplementing the UN Security Council arms embargo that had been in place since 1992, the UN, IGAD, and the AU repeatedly threatened to impose targeted sanctions throughout the mediation process in 2008. These sanctions would be aimed at individuals and entities obstructing the peace process.

An episode of armed fighting in north Mogadishu between different clans triggered peace talks. The UIC and the Somali government were also involved in these negotiations. On 12 May, UIC and the Somali government along with other actors signed a ceasefire.

Al-Shabaab (Harakat al-Shabaab al-Mujahidiin, Mujahidiin) (English: the Youth Movement) aims to overthrow the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) of Somalia and expel foreign troops, installing a system of governance based on Sharia law. Al-Shabaab did not participate in the negotiations mediated by the AU and the UN that were held in 2008. Yet, in early February 2009, the newly instated President Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Aden held secret talks in Mogadishu with Al-Shabaab spokesperson Sheikh Muqtar Robow Abu Mansur, as well as the group’s second in command, Sheikh Hasan Abdullahi Ali. However, no official negotiations aimed at resolving the conflict took place in 2009.

An episode of armed fighting in north Mogadishu between different clans triggered peace talks. The al-Shabaab and the Somali government were also involved in these negotiations. On 12 May, al-Shabaab and the Somali government along with other actors signed a ceasefire.
In June 2010, negotiations between TFG members and Hizbul Islam leader Aweys took place, but broke down without any progress made.

In May 1990, peace efforts were being mediated by the Liberian Inter-Faith Mediation Committee (IFMC), but NPFL left the talks when it became apparent that President Doe refused to step down. The rebels advanced quickly during the first half of 1990.
location_negotiations: A process to resolve Liberia’s conflict had begun on 17 September 2002, when a meeting was held at the UN to form an International Contact Group on Liberia that would seek to bring the Liberian government and LURD insurgents together for peace negotiations. The contact group composed of the Ghana, Morocco, Nigeria, the UK, France, the US, the AU, ECOWAS, and the UN. President Taylor had been rejecting the possibility of direct negotiations with LURD, but after international pressure from the contact group, as well as the fact that that the rebels were rapidly approaching Monrovia, Taylor accepted mediation negotiations with LURD.

description: The rebels advanced quickly during the first half of 1990. In an attempt to halt the chaos ECOWAS launched a regional peacekeeping mission in August 1990, named ECOMOG (Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group). ECOMOG was mandated to support the interim government, which had been installed on 22 November as a result of the Murder of President Doe by the INPFL on 9 September 1990. In addition to the deployment of ECOMOG, ECOWAS established a five-member Standing Mediation Committee with the task of achieving a peace settlement to the Liberian civil war. This committee was chaired by Gambian President Dawda Jawara. On 7 August, ECOWAS held the first mediation session at Banjul. At this meeting, ECOWAS presented a peace plan which called for a ceasefire, the establishment of ECOMOG, a national conference to establish a broad based interim government in Liberia, and elections within 12 months. The peace plan was rejected by the NPFL, as it objected an ECOWAS-sponsored interim government and an ECOWAS peacekeeping force.
Another round of talks on 21 August also failed.

On 22 September, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire. Peace talks on 28 November 1990 led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Liberia, NPFL and INPFL. However, Taylor did not see the endorsement of the Bamako agreement as an acceptance of President Sawyer, who had been sworn in as President of the Interim Government on 22 November.
Talks resumed and, on 21 December, the parties signed the Banjul IV agreement.
In January 1991, the parties met several times to discuss the implementation of the agreements concluded in 1990.
location_negotiations: A process to resolve Liberia’s conflict had begun on 17 September 2002, when a meeting was held at the UN to form an International Contact Group on Liberia that would seek to bring the Liberian government and LURD insurgents together for peace negotiations. The contact group composed of the Ghana, Morocco, Nigeria, the UK, France, the US, the AU, ECOWAS, and the UN. President Taylor had been rejecting the possibility of direct negotiations with LURD, but after international pressure from the contact group, as well as the fact that that the rebels were rapidly approaching Monrovia, Taylor accepted mediation negotiations with LURD.

description: The interim government sent out proposals to the warring parties on how to end the conflict in early February, after which the ECOWAS Standing Mediating Committee continued negotiations in Togo on 12 and 13 February. At these negotiations Gnassingbe Eyadema, the President of Togo, acted as the chief mediator. The negotiations led to the signing of the Lomé Ceasefire Agreement.

However, the peace process subsequently stalled, since the Government of Liberia insisted on disarmament prior to the installation of another interim government, whereas the NPFL insisted on the formation of a new interim government before disarmament. On 1 March, leaders from both sides met to affirm their intentions to work with ECOWAS to bring the conflict to a peaceful end.

Between 15 March and 18 April, the All-Liberia National Conference was held, with the goal to discuss the distribution of political power in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent an NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference formed an Interim government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held in October 1991.
location_negotiations: A process to resolve Liberia’s conflict had begun on 17 September 2002, when a meeting was held at the UN to form an International Contact Group on Liberia that would seek to bring the Liberian government and LURD insurgents together for peace negotiations. The contact group composed of the Ghana, Morocco, Nigeria, the UK, France, the US, the AU, ECOWAS, and the UN. President Taylor had been rejecting the possibility of direct negotiations with LURD, but after international pressure from the contact group, as well as the fact that that the rebels were rapidly approaching Monrovia, Taylor accepted mediation negotiations with LURD.

description: Four rounds of direct negotiations between Sawyer and Taylor were held in Yamossoukro between June and October 1991, under the auspices of ECOWAS and the International Negotiations Network (INN) of former US President Jimmy Carter. Negotiations in June led to the Yamossoukro I Peace Agreement on 30 June 1991.

Four rounds of direct negotiations between Sawyer and Taylor were held in Yamossoukro between June and October 1991, under the auspices of ECOWAS and the International Negotiations Network (INN) of former US President Jimmy Carter. Negotiations in July led to the Yamosoukro Peace Agreement II on 29 July 1991.

Four rounds of direct negotiations between Sawyer and Taylor were held in Yamossoukro between June and October 1991, under the auspices of ECOWAS and the International Negotiations Network (INN) of former US President Jimmy Carter. Negotiations in September led to the Yamosoukro III Peace Agreement on 17 September 1991.

Four rounds of direct negotiations between Sawyer and Taylor were held in Yamossoukro between June and October 1991, under the auspices of ECOWAS and the International Negotiations Network (INN) of former US President Jimmy Carter. Negotiations in October led to the Yamosoukro IV Peace Agreement on 30 October 1991.

The OAU appointed Reverend Canaan Banana, the former President of Zimbabwe, as its eminent person to Liberia in January 1993. Together with United Nations Secretary-General's Special Representative (SGSR) Gordon-Sommers, Banana was actively involved in peacemaking activities and discussed the establishment of a ceasefire with Charles Taylor in April 1993. An UN-sponsored peace conference was held in the UN Palais des Nations in Geneva from 10 to 17 July 1993, under the joint chairmanship of the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in Cotonou on 25 July 1993. At this peace conference, Somers acted as the UN’s chief mediator, while the OAU’s eminent for Liberia person Canaan Banana acted as the OAU’s chief mediator. In addition, Nicéphore Soglo, President of Benin and chairman of ECOWAS, acted as the chief mediator of ECOWAS. Although the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU cooperated in the Liberian peace process, there was some rivalry between the different third parties.
In August 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Consequently, Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in August 1994.
On 9 September, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire. A round of negotiations mediated by Rawling led to the conclusion of the Akosombo Peace Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994.

At the time of the signing of the Akosombo Peace Agreement, the fighting was still raging throughout Liberia. In fact, Charles Taylor and his forces were being expelled from their headquarters in Gbarnga simultaneously to the peace process in Akosombo. Hence, the peace process continued and another conference started in Accra in November 1994 and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. Yet, this ceasefire did not hold either.

In early 1995, a new round of negotiations between all the factions was mediated by Nigeria’s General Sani Abacha in Abuja. Prior to these talks, Abacha had held private consultations with NPFL leader Taylor for four days, which had led to a rapprochement between Nigeria and the NPFL. With Nigeria no longer opposing his ambitions, Taylor became more amenable to a political solution to the conflict. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995.

In April 1996, heavy fighting broke out in Monrovia between the NPFL and fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. Liberia’s Government forces were not involved in this fighting. At the behest of representatives from Nigeria and Ghana, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire on 6 May. A new peace agreement, which was signed by both the NPFL and the Government of Liberia, was mediated by Nigeria’s General Sani Abacha in Abuja on 17 August 1996, known as the Abuja II Agreement. At an OAU meeting in Yaoundé earlier in July 1996, the OAU leaders had made it clear that if the ECOWAS assessment of the Liberian peace process would be negative, then the OAU would help sponsor a draft Resolution in the UN Security Council for the imposition of severe sanctions.

The Independent National Patriotic Forces of Liberia (INPFL), led by Prince Yormie Johnson, was a breakaway faction from the NPFL. On 9 September 1990, the INPFL captured and murdered President Samuel Doe. At the 13th summit of the Heads of States of ECOWAS countries held in Banjul, Gambia, on 30 May 1990, under the chairmanship of Sir Dawda Jawara of Gambia, the member states decided to set up the five-member Standing Mediation Committee with the task of achieving a peace settlement to the Liberian civil war. Subsequent negotiations between the Government of Liberia and the INPFL in Gambia led to the signing of the Banjul III agreement on 24 October 1990.

Another round of peace talks on 28 November 1990 led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Liberia, NPFL, and INPFL. However, Taylor did not see the endorsement of the Bamako agreement as an acceptance of President Sawyer, who had been sworn in as President of the Interim Government on 22 November.
Talks resumed and on 21 December the parties signed the Banjul IV agreement.
In January 1991, the parties met several times to discuss the implementation of the agreements concluded in 1990.

The interim Government of Liberia sent out proposals to the warring parties on how to end the conflict in early February 1991, after which the ECOWAS Standing Mediating Committee continued negotiations in Togo on 12 and 13 February 1991. At these negotiations Gnassingbe Eyadem, the President of Togo, acted as the chief mediator of the Standing Mediating Committee. The negotiations led to the signing of the Lomé Ceasefire Agreement.

On 15 March, the All-Liberia National Conference took place to discuss the distribution of political power in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Charles Taylor sent an NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference formed an Interim government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held in October 1991.

A process to resolve Liberia’s conflict had begun on 17 September 2002, when a meeting was held at the UN to form an International Contact Group on Liberia that would seek to bring the Liberian government and LURD insurgents together for peace negotiations. The contact group composed of the Ghana, Morocco, Nigeria, the UK, France, the US, the AU, ECOWAS, and the UN. President Taylor had been rejecting the possibility of direct negotiations with LURD, but after international pressure from the contact group, as well as the fact that that the rebels were rapidly approaching Monrovia, Taylor accepted mediation negotiations with LURD. The cumulative effect of the battle dynamics, international pressure, and calls for peace from civil society groups paved the way for Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, Chairman of ECOWAS, successfully initiating peace talks between the Taylor Government and LURD. After having agreed on the venue and date for negotiations, Wade met with Charles Taylor once more in early 2003 to discuss possible candidates to assume the role of chief mediator. From a list with notables, including names as Archbishop Desmond Tutu from South Africa, Taylor chose General Abdulsalami Abubakar from Nigeria. Commenting on his choice for Abubakar, Taylor expressed that during an earlier visit to Nigeria he had been impressed with the calm and controlled way Abubakar managed his affairs.
On 7 and 8 February 2003, ECOWAS, the Inter-Religious Council (IRC) of Liberia, and Sierra Leone facilitated peace talks in Freetown.
third_party: ECOWAS; Inter-Religious Council (IRC) of Liberia; Sierra Leone

description: A new round of negotiations, within the framework of the ECOWAS Peace Process for Liberia, took place in Akosombo in June and July 2003. Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS took place in Accra in August 2003. The President of Ghana, John Agyekum Kufuor, who had assumed the role of Chairman of ECOWAS on 31 January 2003, as well as General Abdulsalami Abubakar, former Head of State of Nigeria, acted as the mediators at these talks, but Abubakar acted as the chief mediator. Throughout the negotiations, Chief mediator Abubakar employed a mediation strategy aimed at facilitating consensus among the conflict parties. However, the negotiations were simultaneously influenced by pressure from external actors. Arguably the most external influence came from an indictment against Charles Taylor. Just as the negotiations were to begin, on June 4 2003, the Special Court for Sierra Leone, which was established by the UN Security Council, issued an indictment against Charles Taylor for complicity in crimes against humanity in Sierra Leone. Consequently, Ghana had to decide whether to hand over Taylor or not. Many of the participants commented on the possible removal of Taylor as being in violation with African hospitality. Indeed, in line with earlier statements on the absolute safety of all participants in the negotiations, the Government of Ghana refused to turn over Taylor. Nonetheless, later the same day, Charles Taylor left Accra and went back to Monrovia, while negotiations would continue according to schedule. Although Charles Taylor stayed in close contact with the representatives of the Government of Liberia present in Accra, his departure had a profound effect on the dynamics of the negotiations. Before the indictment of Taylor, the prospect for the conclusion of a peace agreement seemed bleak. Most participants of the negotiations believed President Taylor would never give up his presidency, while the rebel parties would never compromise on their main demand of Taylor’s immediate removal. These insurmountable positions remained relevant when Taylor left Accra, as he still had no intention of giving up the presidency. However, the indictment resulted in Taylor losing any last support from international partners and de-legitimatized him. It also affected the morale of his troops, who had not been paid in months at that time. These developments negatively affected Taylor’s bargaining position in the negotiations. The conflict parties started negotiations on 12 June in order to conclude a ceasefire agreement in preparation for negotiations on a political solution to the conflict. This round of negotiations resulted in the conflict parties agreeing on a ceasefire on 17 June, in which a clause was included that Charles Taylor would not be included in the transitional government. Although the concluded ceasefire on 17 June did not hold, it had become clear that the indictment of Taylor enabled agreement on what had seemed fixed positions. After the conclusion of the ceasefire agreement on 17 June, negotiations mediated by General Abdulsalami Abubakar continued. During the negotiations in late June, he actively listened to the concerns of the adversaries without imposing any of his own solutions to end the conflict. As is noted by Hayner, some participants in the negotiations “were even frustrated with his mediation style at times: even while Monrovia was being shelled and the urgency seemed great, he remained in listening mode for several weeks, rather than pushing for agreement or action of any kind.”

Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS took place in Accra in August 2003.The President of Ghana, John Agyekum Kufuor, who had assumed the role of Chairman of ECOWAS on 31 January 2003, as well as General Abdulsalami Abubakar, former Head of State of Nigeria, acted as the mediators at these talks, but Abubakar acted as the chief mediator. The conflict parties focused on the details of an interim government. On 5 August, they declared a ceasefire. Finally, on 18 August 2003, the Accra Agreement was signed.
In follow-up negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in November, the Government of Liberia, MODEL, and LURD signed a disarmament agreement on 3 November 2003.

The process of forming the National Transitional Government of Liberia (NTGL) was suddenly disrupted in early 2004 as a result of disagreement over the appointment of 84 assistant ministerial positions. The appointment of these positions was not covered in the Accra Agreement. General Abubakar therefore returned to Liberia in beginning of June 2004 for negotiations between the signatories of the Accra Agreement, helping with interpreting the agreement concerning issues such as appointment of junior ministers, but also concerning issue related to the central bank. This mediation effort was successful in averting the crisis after the parties agreed on all the names of the candidates submitted to the Transitional Legislative Assembly.
In late July 2004, another round of negotiations was held in Accra to review the Accra Agreement.

In 2003, the Movement for Democracy in Liberia (MODEL) took up arms against the Government of Liberia. MODEL emerged as a splinter group from LURD and was first led by Thomas Nimely and later by Benjamin Taylor. MODEL had not participated in the peace talks in Sierra Leone in early 2003, but did participate in negotiations taking place in Akosombo and Accra between 4 June and 18 August. General Abdulsalami Abubakar, former Head of State of Nigeria, acted as the chief mediator at these talks. Abubakar, appointed by ECOWAS, had been chosen to mediate by the Charles Taylor and the LURD leadership earlier in 2003. The conflict parties started negotiations on 12 June in order to conclude a ceasefire agreement in preparation for negotiations on a political solution to the conflict. A ceasefire agreement was concluded on 17 June 2003.

In 2003, the Movement for Democracy in Liberia (MODEL) took up arms against the Government of Liberia. MODEL emerged as a splinter group from LURD and was first led by Thomas Nimely and later by Benjamin Taylor. MODEL had not participated in the peace talks in Sierra Leone in early 2003, but did participate in negotiations taking place in Akosombo and Accra between 4 June and 18 August. General Abdulsalami Abubakar, former Head of State of Nigeria, acted as the chief mediator at these talks. Abubakar, appointed by ECOWAS, had been chosen to mediate by the Charles Taylor and the LURD leadership earlier in 2003. On 18 August 2003, the Accra Agreement was signed.

In 2003, the Movement for Democracy in Liberia (MODEL) took up arms against the Government of Liberia. MODEL emerged as a splinter group from LURD and was first led by Thomas Nimely and later by Benjamin Taylor. MODEL had not participated in the peace talks in Sierra Leone in early 2003, but did participate in negotiations taking place in Akosombo and Accra between 4 June and 18 August. General Abdulsalami Abubakar, former Head of State of Nigeria, acted as the chief mediator at these talks. Abubakar, appointed by ECOWAS, had been chosen to mediate by the Charles Taylor and the LURD leadership earlier in 2003. In follow-up negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in November, the Government of Liberia, MODEL, and LURD signed a disarmament agreement on 3 November 2003.

General Abubakar returned to Liberia in beginning of June 2004 for negotiations between the signatories of the the Accra Agreement. He helped with interpreting the agreement concerning issues such as appointment of junior ministers and the central bank.
In late July, talks were to be held in Accra to review the Accra Agreement.
An informal meeting between ANC representatives and a delegation of South African lawyers was held in early February 1989, in which the parties discussed the possibility of official negotiations.

In July 1989, outgoing President Botha met with the imprisoned ANC leader Nelson Mandela in what was described as a non-political meeting, but which in reality can be seen as a round of pre-negotiations.

In August 1989, Frederik Willem de Klerk succeeded Botha as President of South Africa, after which de Klerk immediately embraced a position more conducive to negotiations and recognised the ANC as a prospective negotiation partner. De Klerk invited the ANC to a “procces of dialogue and negotiations “on the condition that the ANC committed “itself to the pursuit of peaceful solutions.”  In September 1989, a secret meeting took place in Switzerland between two officials of the South African National Intelligence Service and two ANC officials, Thabo Mbeki and Jacob Zuma, in which the conflict parties assessed their positions.
In December 1989, de Klerk met with Mandela in another round of pre-negotiations to discuss the possibility for negotiations.
In February 1990, ANC officials and the officials within South Africa’s National Intelligence Service met for negotiations in Switzerland to prepare for the official talks.
Another such round of pre-negotiations in Switzerland took place in early March 1990.

The first substantive negotiations between the ANC and the government took place in Cape Town between 2 and 4 May 1990. At the end of the meeting, the parties signed a joint declaration of intent to end violence and begin negotiations. This declaration was referred to as the Groote Schuur Minute.

Another round of negotiations in September 1990 led to the signing of the Pretoria Minute on September 1990. The Pretoria Minute stipulated an end to the use of violence by the ANC its military wing Umkhonto we Sizwe and also stipulated an end to the state of emergency.

During negotiations in January 1991, the ANC leadership presented a proposal for an all-party congress which would be tasked with negotiating and drafting a new constitution. This was a major concession, as the ANC had up to this point maintained that the constitution should be drafted by an assembly appointed through democratic elections. This concession paved the way for a round of negotiations in September that led to the signing of the National Peace Accord on 14 September 1991. This agreement was signed by representatives of twenty-seven political organisations and the government and prepared the way for the all-party congress, named the Convention for a Democratic South Africa (CODESA).

The CODESA began on 20 December 1991. Delegates of nineteen political groups engaged in negotiations and aimed to draft an interim constitution at this conference, which resulted in the signing of a declaration of intent that outlined the basic principles of the future constitution.

Negotiations within the framework of CODESA resumed in May 1992. Yet, following a massacre of ANC supporters in the Boipatong Township near Johannesburg in June 1992, talks collapsed. As a response to this crisis, the UN Secretary-General dispatched Cyrus Vance as his Special Representative to prevent the talks from going off track. Vance consulted separately with the parties, but did not mediate any direct negotiations between them. In addition, Vance’s efforts led to the deployment of an UN observer mission which eventually grew to about 3,000 observers.

Attempts to resume negotiations were initially rejected by the ANC, but in Cyril Ramaphosa and Roelf Meyer, the chief negotiators for the ANC and the Government, of South Africa respectively, conducted negotiations in September 1992. No international third party was involved in these negotiations. These talks culminated in the Record of Understanding signed by Nelson Mandela and de Klerk on 26 September 1992.  The document was replaced by the final constitution, adopted by the democratically elected national assembly, on 18 December 1996.

The Algerian government called for a ceasefire and invited the Government of Mali, the MPA and another rebel group, the Tuareg group Front islamique arabe de l’Azaouad (FIAA) (English: Islamic Arab Front of Azawad), to negotiate to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Negotiations, mediated by Algeria, on 5 and 6 January 1991 led to the conclusion of the Tamanrasset Agreement. The Minister of Interior Department of Algeria acted as the chief mediator at these negotiations.

Two other rounds of talks mediated by Algeria were held in January and March 1992 respectively. At these negotiations, the Azawad Unified Movements and Fronts (MFUA), which was a newly formed umbrella-organization for the MPA, the FIAA and several other smaller rebel groups, negotiated on behalf of the MPA.

Two other rounds of talks mediated by Algeria were held in January and March 1992 respectively. At these negotiations, the Azawad Unified Movements and Fronts (MFUA), which was a newly formed umbrella-organization for the MPA, the FIAA and several other smaller rebel groups, negotiated on behalf of the MPA.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact.

In 1994, Algeria mediated three rounds of negotiations between the Government of Mali on the one side and the MPA and the FIAA on the other side. The first round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Tamanrasset in April.
The second round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Algiers in May.

The third round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Tamanrasset in June. Instead of concluding a new peace agreement, Algeria offered to implement the 1992 National Pact peace agreement. Although negotiations took place throughout 1994, the role of Algeria as mediator in the conflict was officially confirmed at the Bamako Conference taking place in August 1994, which was attended by Algeria, Mali, Mauritania, Burkina Faso, Libya and Niger. The final document produced at this conference makes provision for security measures along the border and greater coordination among the countries of the region, but also stressed that Algeria is playing the role of mediator in the Tuareg conflict.

The Algerian government called for a ceasefire and invited the Government of Mali, the FIAA and another rebel group, the Mouvement populaire de l’Azaouad (MPA) (English: Azawad People’s Movement), to negotiate to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Negotiations, mediated by Algeria, on 5 and 6 January 1991 led to the conclusion of the Tamanrasset Agreement. The Minister of Interior Department of Algeria acted as the chief mediator at these negotiations.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact.

In 1994, Algeria mediated three rounds of negotiations between the Government of Mali on the one side and the MPA and the FIAA on the other side. The first round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in April, the second round of negotiations was held in Algiers in May, and the third round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in June. Instead of concluding a new peace agreement, Algeria offered to implement the 1992 National Pact peace agreement. These negotiations did not end armed fighting. In fact, the armed conflict between FIAA exceeded 25 battle-related deaths for the first time on 4 October 1994, when an army patrol based at Niafounke was attacked by FIAA fighters.

In 1994, Algeria mediated three rounds of negotiations between the Government of Mali on the one side and the MPA and the FIAA on the other side. The first round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in April, the second round of negotiations was held in Algiers in May, and the third round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in June. Instead of concluding a new peace agreement, Algeria offered to implement the 1992 National Pact peace agreement. These negotiations did not end armed fighting. In fact, the armed conflict between FIAA exceeded 25 battle-related deaths for the first time on 4 October 1994, when an army patrol based at Niafounke was attacked by FIAA fighters.

In 1994, Algeria mediated three rounds of negotiations between the Government of Mali on the one side and the MPA and the FIAA on the other side. The first round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in April, the second round of negotiations was held in Algiers in May, and the third round of negotiations was held in Tamanrasset in June. Instead of concluding a new peace agreement, Algeria offered to implement the 1992 National Pact peace agreement. These negotiations did not end armed fighting. In fact, the armed conflict between FIAA exceeded 25 battle-related deaths for the first time on 4 October 1994, when an army patrol based at Niafounke was attacked by FIAA fighters.

Negotiations between the conflict parties took place in Tripoli in April 2008 and were mediated by the Gaddafi Foundation, which was a charitable organization chaired by Libyan leader Muammar al-Gaddafi’s son Saif al Islam. These talks led to a ceasefire that also stipulated that the rebels were to release any soldiers being held hostage, while the Malian army was to partly withdraw from the Kidal area. The parties expressed in a joint statement that the ceasefire would create a climate of appeasement which would open the way for a dialogue to forge a final settlement. However, the ceasefire soon broke down with both parties accusing each other of not implementing it.
Negotiations without the involvement of a third party on 11 May 2007 did not lead to any tangible outcome.

In June 2007, the Malian Foreign Minister Moctar Ouane went to Algeria to meet with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to request mediation by Algeria. Bouteflika agreed, after which Abdelkrim Ghrieb, the Algerian Ambassador to Mali, acted as the main mediator in peace talks in July, which led to a new ceasefire on 21 July 2007.
On 31 August 2007, the conflict parties engaged in negotiations without the involvement of a third party. This led to a ceasefire, but this ceasefire did not appear to last.
On 19 September, a temporary ceasefire was concluded in negotiations in which elected Tuareg officials served as mediators.

The Libyan government became involved in mediation in 2008 and after preliminary negotiations in March, the two sides agreed to negotiations in the first week of April. On 3 April 2008, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire agreement in Tripoli.

The Libyan government became involved in mediation in 2008 and after preliminary negotiations in March, the two sides agreed to negotiations in the first week of April. On 3 April 2008, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire agreement in Tripoli.
Another ceasefire agreement was negotiated in Algiers on 21 July, but this ceasefire failed to bring peace.
The Malian government sought to negotiate again with the rebels in November, but this round of negotiations failed.

In October 1993, a number of rebel groups joined together and established the coalition group Coordination de la résistance armée (CRA) (English: Coordination of the Armed Resistance), fighting the Government of Niger for autonomy for Aïr and Azawad. The new group began launching guerrilla attacks in early 1994. In June 1994, negotiations between the CRA and the Government of Niger began in Paris. France served as mediator, together with Algeria and Burkina Faso. After the talks, the government agreed to meet the CRA demands for autonomy for Tuareg regions, which would be governed by elected assemblies and governors. The government agreed, in principle, to the carving out of a new administrative map, taking account of “cultural and social homogeneity.” The agreement also included a quota system which would guarantee Tuaregs a fair share of government jobs and military positions.

In October 1994, the negotiations resumed in Ouagadougou, where Burkina Faso initially solely hosted the meetings with no external mediators involved in the talks, but later mediators from France, Algeria, and Burkina Faso joined and participated in the talks. The talks led to the signing of the Ouagadougou Accord on 9 October 1994. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also stated that the issues of defence and internal security would be dealt with at a later stage of the negotiations. The agreement emphasized that Niger was unitary and indivisible, but also contained amendments to the political-territorial structure of Niger, rearranging the country into smaller entities of political control. Finally, the accord included provisions with regard the facilitation of the return and resettlement of refugees.

The CRA experienced internal tensions in early 1995, which resulted in Front de libération de Tamoust (FLT) (English: Tamoust Liberation Front) leaving the umbrella organisation in June 1995. Nevertheless, negotiations took place between the CRA and the Government of Niger in March 1995. These negotiations were mediated by Laala Mohamed and Alain Deschamps, an Algerian and a French mediator respectively, as well as the Foreign Minister of Burkina Faso, Ablassé Ouedraogo.

Another round of negotiations mediated by these third parties took place in April 1995. This led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement in Niamey on 24 April 1995. Negotiations and third party involvement with regard to the implementation of the agreement continued throughout the year.
On 25 May 1995, the Special Peace Committee set up to implement the peace agreement signed in Niamey met for the first time to discuss issues related to the implementation of the agreement.

During another meeting of the Special Peace Committee on 9 September 1995, CRA leaders threatened to resume armed struggle of the government if it did not meet its commitments stipulated in the peace agreement signed in April 1995.

At another meeting in November 1995, following a clash in which one Tuareg was killed, both the government and the CRA reaffirmed their commitment to peace agreement. This meeting came after the most serious clash since the April Peace Accord was signed. In late 1995, the Burkinabe Prime Minister Roch Marc Christian Kaboré called on the Tuareg factions to hold the peace after new clashes had occurred in December 1995. The French co-operation minister Jacques Godfrain subsequently held talks with officials of the Government of Niger on the Tuareg peace-process in December, after which France gave a 40,000 US Dollar grant for policing the Tuareg. On 28 December 1995, France, together with Burkina Faso and Algeria, announced that they ended their involvement in the peace process on 31 December 1995, but that they would still respond to any requests of peace negotiations.

On 18 March 1996, the transitional government recognized the CRA as a political party. On 17 December 1996, the government held some peace talks with the CRA and other Tuareg groups. This led to the signing of an agreement providing for the return to barracks of former Tuareg fighters, which was agreed to precede the integration of the former Tuareg rebels back into the regular army.

On 1 October 1990, the Front patriotique Rwandais (FPR) (English: Rwandan Patriotic Front) launched its armed struggle against the Government of Rwanda, invading the country from the Uganda with around 2,000 men. As early as 14 October, the Belgium Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, aided by his Foreign Minister and Defence Minister, travelled to Kigali to “halt the offensive and seek a peaceful solution within the framework of the Organization of African Unity.” Martens discussed the conflict with Rwandan President Habyarimana, Ugandan President Museveni, Zairian President Mobuto, and Tanzanian President Mwinyi. Belgium also tried to initiate negotiations between the conflict parties, yet as the Government of Rwanda claimed that the conflict was an interstate conflict with the FPR being Uganda’s proxy army rather than an independent insurgent group supported by Uganda, the Government of Rwanda refused to engage in mediated negotiate with the FPR. Moreover, the RPF demanded the direct resignation of President Habyarimana. The Belgian peace initiative was followed by several ad hoc summits organised by both the Communauté Économique des Pays des Grand Lacs (CEPGL) (English: the Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries) and the Organization of African Unity: the Mwanza summit on 17 October attended by the Presidents of Tanzania, Rwanda, and Uganda; the Gbadolite summit on 26 October attended by the Presidents of Zaire, Rwanda, and Burundi; and the Goma summit on 20 November attended by the Presidents of Zaire, Rwanda, and Burundi, as well as the third deputy Prime Minister of Uganda. The Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko acted as the chief mediator of the countries in the region during these summits. Mobutu’s appointment was in large part based on the idea that he could prevail over Habyarimana, thus delivering the agreement of the conflict party that the mediator favoured. Although no real attempts to bring the FPR in seemed to be made, talks were held between Ugandan President Museveni and Habyarimana, where the former promised to put pressure on the FPR to commit to a ceasefire. Indeed, to respect ongoing peace efforts, Rwanda and FPR concluded a ceasefire agreement, without any direct negotiations between them, on 24 October 1990. In addition, most of the regional conferences focused on the refugee problem, which was at least in part due to the perception that the refugee problem forced the FPR into Rwanda. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1990.

Meetings between countries in the region continued to be held in early 1991 through the efforts of both the CEPGL and the Organization of African Unity, in which the participants discussed the refugee situation, as well as the possibility of the deployment of a neutral peacekeeping force in Rwanda. Summits were held in Zanzibar on 17 February and Dar-es-Salaam on 19 February. While little effort was made to include the FPR in negotiations during the summits in 1990, the regional leaders persuaded President Habyarimana to engage in peace talks with the FPR leadership during the summits in early 1991. At the Dar-es-Salaam summit on 19 February, a Declaration was drafted in which President Mobutu was thanked “for his efforts in instituting a dialogue between the Rwandan government and the armed opposition” and urged him to “maintain the momentum of the dialogue.” The Declaration further committed the conflict parties to “find a definitive and durable solution to the problem.” Accordingly, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR met for the first time in March 1991. Under Mobutu’s mediation, the conflict parties agreed to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 March 1991, which was signed by Rwandan Foreign Minister Casimir Bizimugu and FPR vice-Chairman Paul Kagame in N’Sele on 29 March 1991. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire and the deployment of a Neutral Military Observer Group, comprised of personnel from Nigeria, Senegal, Zimbabwe, the Organization of African Unity, and representatives of the warring parties. The agreement – referred to as the N’Sele Ceasefire Agreement – did not include provisions on how to resolve the conflict issues. Instead, the document included a short agenda for future talks, specifying that rule of law and democracy should be created, that the formation of a new national army should commence, and that power-sharing arrangements need to be established. The ceasefire did not hold, with Government forces attacking FPR forces almost immediately after the Neutral Military Observer Group was deployed on 7 May 1991

At the Organization of African Unity’s annual summit in June 1991, it was decided to reactivate the peace process, after which an Organization of African Unity summit aimed at finding a solution to the crisis was organised in Gbadolite, Zaire, on 7 September. Direct talks between the Rwandan Government and the FPR continued in Gbadolite between 15 and 17 September 1991. Zairian President Mobutu acted as mediator at these talks, which ended with the parties expressing their commitment to the N’Sele Ceasefire Agreement. The Gbadolite Ceasefire did not hold.

On 7 April 1992, a coalition Government was set up, which was a result of a compromise President Habyarimana made with the political opposition in Rwanda. The new Government of Rwanda was mandated to directly negotiate with the FPR.
