In 1992, the US Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Herman Cohen, undertook a round of shuttle negotiations to push for mediated negotiations: the first meeting took place in Kampala on 8 and 9 May with Ugandan President Museveni and the FPR leadership.
The second meeting took place in Kigali on 10 and 11 May with Rwandan Government officials and political opposition leaders.

On his trip to Rwanda, Cohen reportedly persuaded Rwandan Foreign Minister Boniface Ngulinzira to explore the option of negotiations by pointing out that these could be held without any preconditions. Consequently, Ngulinzira met with the FPR vice-chairman Patrick Mazimpaka for a round of negotiations mediated by the US in Kampala on 24 May 1992.

The final May meeting led to a round of pre-negotiations between the Rwandan government and the FPR in Paris between 3 and 6 June 1992. After the pre-negotiations in Paris it was agreed that comprehensive negotiations would start on 10 July 1992 under Tanzania’s mediation. At the invitation of the Director of African Affairs at the French Foreign Ministry, Henri Dijoud, Herman Cohen had been present in Paris too. Cohen put significant pressure on the conflict parties to start official negotiations. Crucially, he put pressure on Uganda to push the FPR to accept negotiations. Cohen expressed to Ugandan Foreign Minister Paul Ssemmogere that the continuing civil war in Rwanda is not without costs and that the United States and the donor community are “devoting considerable resources to the care of hundreds of thousands of displace Rwandans”, he then continued by pointing out that Uganda was the recipient of major bilateral aid and that if the Rwandan negotiations did not move forward soon, it would “be necessary to finance continued assistance to the internally displaced by reducing assistance to Uganda.”

Parallel to the talks in Paris in early June 1992, several representatives of the FPR met with a delegation of the Rwandan political opposition parties in Brussels, under the auspices of Belgian representatives.

Prior to the Organization of African Unity’s annual summit in June the conflict parties met in Dakar, Senegal, and confirmed their commitment to comprehensive negotiations in Arusha, as agreed in Paris.
third_party: US; France; Belgium; DR Congo (Zaire); Tanzania; Burundi; Uganda

description: The first round of negtoiations in Arusha started on 10 July 1992. This led to the signing of a temporary ceasefire agreement. This was followed by three more days of peace talks.  Although Zairian President Mobutu was present at the first round of the negotiations in Arusha, the Tanzanian mediation team was most actively involved in the negotiations. In fact, at the meeting in Gbadolite in September 1991, the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi had been mandated by the regional countries to mediate. While Mobuto officially continued to be the mediator, Mwinyi officially was appointed the chief facilitator. Hence, although Mobutu continued to be the chief mediator on paper, Miwinyi in reality assumed the role of chief mediator.

Mobutu became increasingly less active from the second round of the Arusha talks onwards and the first three rounds of negotiations in June, July, and August were primarily led by the Tanzanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Hassan Ahmed, aided by Ami Mpungwe, who worked for the Tanzanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The first three rounds focused on the implementation of the new ceasefire, as well as the integration of the FPR in the army and the issues of democracy and national unity. A second round of negotiations in late July led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 31 July 1992.
The third round of negotiations in Arusha took place in August 1992, but did not lead to any results.
In October 1992, during a fourth round of negotiations, a partial accord on power sharing was signed in Arusha. The progress made during the year did however not last all the way out.

In November, the parties failed to agree on the creation of a neutral zone for the Organization of African Unity observers, as well as on the issue of repatriation of refugees, the participation of the FPR in the transitional government, and the final incorporation of the FPR in the Rwandan army.

Another round of negotiations started in January 1993. This led to the signing of a protocol on power sharing in Arusha. However, President Habyarimana’s political party the Mouvement républicain national pour la démocratie et le dévelopement (MRND) (English: National Republican Movement for Democracy and Development) immediately rejected the agreement. This round of negotiations subsequently broke down in early February 1993.

A month later, in March, new peace talks were convened in Arusha, in which the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi acted as the chief mediator. This round of negotiations could produce a solution to the crucial issue of the structure of the future Rwandan armed forces. However, the conflict parties did sign a ceasefire on 7 March.
Another round of negotiations mediated by Mwinyi in Arusha in April also failed to make resolve the issue of the structure of the future Rwandan armed forces.

A new round of negotiations started in Kinihira in May 1993. During these rounds, progress was made. A timetable for the demobilisation of the 19,000 troops of security forces was agreed on. Consensus was also reached on the creation of a neutral zone to be observed by the Organization of African Unity observer group. Moreover, an agreement was signed for the establishment of transitional structures and the demilitarisation of Kigali.
Negotiations mediated by Tanzania in Arusha in June 1993 led to the conclusion of a protocol for the repatriation of all Rwandan refugees resident in Uganda, Tanzania, and Zaire.

The final round of negotiations in Arusha took place in August 1993 and led to the signing of the Arusha Accord on 4 August 1993. This agreement included all the provisions agreed upon during the Arusha talks from July 1992 onwards.

In 1994, the UN and the Organization of African Unity initiated several attempts to negotiate ceasefires during the ongoing genocide. On 8 April 1994, the two sides reached a 48-hour ceasefire agreement during negotiations in Kigali.
Two other ceasefire agreements were reached during negotiations between 12 and 13 April 1994.
On 5 May 1994, General Roméo Dallaire from the UN brokered a ceasefire between the FPR and Rwandan government.
On 6 May 1994, the two sides reached a ceasefire in Gbadolite, as well as agreed on another round of peace talks two days later.
The negotiations on 8 May 1994 were without results.
Ahead of the arrival of the UN special envoy, a temporary truce was brokered between the conflict on 22 May.

Another round of negotiations between representaitves of the Government of Rwanda and the FPR was held at the UNAMIR headquarters on 30 May 1994. Force Commander of UNAMIR, Roméo Dallaire acted as the mediator during these talks. The UN Security Council had earlier in May imposed an arms embargo on Rwanda.
In June 1994, the Organization of African Unity organised a meeting on situation in Rwanda in Tunis, but the FPR did not attend. Instead, Uganda represented the FPR
On 13 June 1994, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR attended a round of ceasefire talks mediated by the UN in Kigali.
A day later, on 14 June 1994, a round of negotiations mediated by Zaire led to the signing of another ceasefire agreement.

The Mouvement des forces démocratiques de Casamançe (MFDC) (English: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance), initially a political party calling for independence of the Casamance region in the early 1980s, engaged in an armed conflict with the Government of Senegal in 1990.  Negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC led to a ceasefire on 29 March 1991.

In May 1991, negotiations, mediated by Guinea-Bissau, led to the signing of the Bissau Accord, which called for a ceasefire, as well as the release of hundreds of Casamançe detainees, among them the political leaders of MFDC. However, the accord mainly focused on a ceasefire and failed to address any of the conflict issues, including the status of Casamance.

A peace commission was established in January 1992. The commission comprised representatives of the Government and the MFDC, but mediators from Guinea-Bissau were also active in the commission throughout 1992.

On 8 April 1993, the leader of the MFDC, Diamacounce Senghor, called for a ceasefire between the parties to take effect on 10 April 1993, while calling for negotiations with France as mediator. However, the government responded with heavy clashes on 18 and 19 April 1993, after which it also called for a ceasefire with the rebels on 27 April 1993. Senegal’s Minister of Defence, Madieng Khary Dieng, and the leader of MFDC, Diamacoune Senghor, conducted a round of negotiations in early July and signed a ceasefire agreement on 8 July 1993. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, the release of Casamançe prisoners, the non-reinforcement of government troops in Casamançe, and the free return of refugees.
In September 1995, a new peace commission was established, the Commission nationale de paix, which sought dialogue with the MFDC.
The commission engaged in some preliminary talks in September 1995. It was proposed that more preliminary discussions would take place in January 1996 to be followed by peace negotiations.

The proposed preliminary discussions within the context of the the Commission nationale de paix took place on 8 January 1996, but the peace negotiations were postponed indefinitely. A first meeting between MFDC leader Abbe Diamacoune Senghor, the Secretary-General of the MFDC and several members of this commission was held the day before. At this meeting Senghor handed over a proposal which demanded immunity for the delegates who are assigned to the negotiations. The proposal also includes an MFDC demand that negotiations take place in a neutral country. The government did not accept these conditions.

Negotiations between the Government of Senegal and MFDC took place in Ziguinchor in late August 1997. On 27 November 1997, MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor called on the Catholic clergymen in Ziguinchor to help them resume the suspended negotiations. A round of negotiations was scheduled for Christmas, but the negotiations were cancedled because of a flare up of armed fighting a fews days before.

On 3 January 1998, the Senegalese president, Abdou Diouf, confirmed his willingness for talks mediated by Gambia. Gambian President Yahya Jammeh subsequently started hosting regular meetings between the MFDC and the Senegalese Government. In a round of negotiations mediated by Gambian President Yahya Jammeh on 28 January 1998, MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor asserted that he is ready to give up the demand for Casamançe's independence, but on condition that the government take measures towards greater economic and social development of this region.
President Abdou Diouf held talks with MFDC leader Diamacounce Senghor on 22 January 1999, which led to a call for an end to hostilities and a peaceful settlement.
The MFDC and the Sengalese government conducted another round of negotiations in Banjul, in Gambia, in April 1999.
Another round of talks was held in Banjul in July 1999.

On 26 December 1999, new negotiations commenced in Banjul, where the conflict parties agreed to an immediate ceasefire in the Casamance. They also agreed to meet face to face at least once a month to negotiate. In addition to representatives of the Gambian government, representatives of Guinea-Bissau also mediated in this round of negotiations in December.

After his inauguration in April 2000, Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, immediately dismissed all those persons who mediated in the Casamance crisis before his election to the presidency.  A round of negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC in November 2000 let to the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 30 November 2000.
With the Bishop of Ziguinchor serving as mediator, a round of negotiations between the conflict parties let to the signing of a truce on 16 March 2001 in Ziguinchor.
The conflict parties conducted unofficial talks in Dakar in January 2002.

Following these unofficial talks, negotiations between the Senegalese Government and the MFDC resumed in Banjul on 25 March 2002. Both parties expressed their willingness to find a solution to the conflict in the Casamance region. On early July and early September, the government offered negotiations to the MFDC. On October 22, the MFDC leadership announces its readiness to accept negtoiations. The adversaries also recognised Gambia and Guinea-Bissau as mediators.

In early 2003, there was an upsurge in fighting between the Senegalese army and MFDC forces. The former claimed that the string of operations it conducted were a result of MFDC’s mine laying efforts throughout the region. Nevertheless, negotiations did take place in 2003. On 4 May, President Wade met with MFDC leader Senghor without the involvement of a mediator. These negotiations did not lead to an agreement, but President Wade promised an amnesty for all MFDC fighters, a reintegration program for former combatants, funding for economic recovery of the Casamance region, resettlement of refugees and displaced people.

Peace talks between the Government of Senegal and the political leadership of MFDC continued in 2004. In January 2004, France provided good office for talks between the external wing of the MFDC and a Senegalese government delegation. The talks ended without any results and did not lead to a breakthrough.

Secret negotiations without the involvement of any third party took place between October and December 2004 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. During these negotiations, the Senegalese Government was represented by Interior Minister Ousmane Ngom and the MFDC was represented by Augustin Diamacoune Senghor. The Accord general de paix entre le gouvernement de la republique du Senegal el le Mouvement des forces democratique de la Casamace was signed on 30 December 2004.
agreement_name: Accord general de paix entre le gouvernement de la republique du Senegal el le Mouvement des forces democratique de la Casamace

description: On 1 February 2005, negotiations on the implementation of the 2004 accord were launched in the central town of Foundiougne. The Government’s delegation was led by Interior Minister Ousmane Ngom, while the rebels were led by MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor. After a day of talks, the two sides agreed to set up four 10-member technical committees consisting of five people from each side. The committees were to address political issues, economic and social development; as well as disarmament, demobilisation, and demining. Yet, the talks were suspended two days later. New talks, scheduled to take place in late March 2005, were postponed due to divergences within the MFDC. Groups within the rebel movement opposed the peace deal and the rebel leadership wanted to arrange consultations between the various factions in order to include more factions in the peace process. The peace process was postponed yet again in December 2005.

In January 2012, Salif Sadio, one of MFDC’s military chiefs, announced that he was willing to negotiate with the Government of Senegal on the condition that these peace talks would be mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio and would be held in a foreign country. Not responding directly to this proposal, President Wade announced a new peace proposal for Casamance while being on a campaign trail in the region on 12 and 13 February 2012. Although this plan was immediately rejected by the MFDC, they stated that they demanded “frank and sincere” negotiations in a neutral setting and brokered by a neutral third party as their precondition for working towards peace. In April 2012, Macky Sall was elected as the new Senegalese president, stating that resolving the Casamance conflict was one of the first national priorities and that he was willing to work with neighbouring Gambia and Guinea-Bissau in the search for lasting peace. Yet, Salif Sadio maintained his demands for the process to take place under the auspices of rhe Community of Sant’Egidio to which President Sall then agreed. The Sadio faction of MFDC subsequently met with a Government delegation in Rome in October 2012 under the auspices of the Community of Sant’Egidio. Don Angelo Romano and Mauro Garofalo mediated the talks.

Another round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Edgidio took place in December 2012. On 14 December, president Sall announced that Casamance would be a test-case for advanced decentralization policy.

Both the Community of Sant’Egidio and Humanitarian Dialogue were involved in mediation between 2014 and 2016. There is, however, limited information available about these mediation efforts. On 29 April 2014, the leaders of MFDC, Salif Sadio, declared a unilateral ceasefire. The ceasefire was announced after a government and the MFDC delegation met in Rome in April 2014 under the facilitation of the Community of Sant’Egidio.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue

description: Both the Community of Sant’Egidio and Humanitarian Dialogue were involved in mediation between 2014 and 2016. There is, however, limited information available about these mediation efforts.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue

description: Both the Community of Sant’Egidio and Humanitarian Dialogue were involved in mediation between 2014 and 2016. There is, however, limited information available about these mediation efforts.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue

description: A round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio took place in October 2017.
A round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant’Egidio between the conflict parties took place in early January 2018. The army released two MFDC fighters following negotiations and peace.

In February 1992, France, as a former colonial power, mediated a ceasefire between FRUD and the government. Since France provided direct military aid in support of the Government of Djibouti, totaling approximately 5.2 million US Dollars between 1991 and 1994, France had leverage of the government. Nevertheless, when the French Minister-Delegate for Foreign Affairs, Alain Vivien, first met with FRUD on 22 January, the Government of Djibouti accused France for loving the foreign invaders, saying it had never asked France to mediate in the conflict. Foreign Minister Farah stated afterwards that Vivien’s visit had changed nothing. Yet, the following month, Paul Dijoud, Director of African Affairs at the French Ministry for Foreign Affairs, met with FRUD on 23 February. After having mediated between the two parties in these separate talks he announced the deployment of a French peacekeeping force on 25 February. On 28 February 1992, the rebels declared a unilateral ceasefire, which was followed by the Government releasing the imprisoned FRUD representative Abbate Ebo Adou. However, the ceasefire only lasted for a few months. France subsequently threatened to cut of development aid.

Paul Dijoud, Director of African Affairs at the French Ministry for Foreign Affairs, met with President Hassan Gouled Aptid on 20 and 24 February 1992. After having mediated between the two parties in these separate talks he announced the deployment of a French peacekeeping force on 25 February. On 28 February 1992, the rebels declared a unilateral ceasefire, which was followed by the Government releasing the imprisoned FRUD representative Abbate Ebo Adou. However, the ceasefire only lasted for a few months. France subsequently threatened to cut of development aid.
Negotiations, in which no international third parties participated, led to the signing of the Agreement for Peace and National Reconciliation in Djibouti on 26 December 1994.
agreement_name: Agreement for Peace and National Reconciliation

description: Negotiations in 2000 with the FRUD-C resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement on 7 February 2000. The agreement called for an end to hostilities and the release of prisoners.
Another peace agreement was concluded between the Djibouti government and the FRUD-AD on 12 May 2001. The accord ended hostilities between the conflict parties.

The Revolutionary United Front (RUF) launched a rebellion from neighbouring Liberia on 23 March 1991. The RUF was led by a former army corporal, Foday Sankoh, who had been trained in Libya during the 1980s. The RUF received military and financial support from the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) led by Charles Taylor.  The RUF initially rapidly advanced, but the Sierra Leonean army went on the offensive in late 1991, after which the fighting reached a stalemate by the beginning of 1992. One-party rule had been abolished in Sierra Leone in 1991 and elections were to be held in July of 1992 to establish a democratic regime. Yet, these elections were never held, since disgruntled soldiers staged a coup in April 1992, forming the National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC). The NPRC acted as a military junta and was led by Captain Valentine Strasser. The NPRC had made it clear that the war against the RUF would continue, which resulted in the RUF suffering massive defeats throughout 1993.  The government issued a unilateral ceasefire declared in December 1993. The NPRC had made it clear that the war against the RUF would continue, which resulted in the RUF suffering massive defeats throughout 1993.  The government issued a unilateral ceasefire declared in December 1993.  The RUF used this unilateral ceasefire declared by the Government of Sierra Leone in December 1993 to regroup, after which they conducted a counterattack in early 1994. In November 1994, the Head of State of Sierra Leone addressed a letter to the UN Secretary-General, formally requesting him to provide his good offices to facilitate negotiations between the Government and the RUF. The RUF and the government reached a ceasefire agreement on 4 December in indirect negotiations, paving the way for official negtoiations. On 15 December 1994, the Secretary-General sent an exploratory mission to Sierra Leone to initiate negotiations. However, this mission was without any success, as the RUF rejected negotiations.

In February 1995, the UN Secretary-General decided to appoint Berhanu Dinka as his a Special Envoy. Dinka was tasked to try to negotiate a settlement to the conflict and return the country to civilian rule, in collaboration with the Organization of African Unity and ECOWAS. In December 1995, an Organization of African Unity mission conducted negotiations with RUF representatives in Abidjan. The London-based International Alert, which had had helped to secure the release of European and Sierra Leonean hostages held by the RUF in April 1994, was instrumental in making contact with the RUF and helping to bring about the meeting between the rebels and the Organization of African Unity, with the latter being represented by the Assistant Secretary-General for Political Affairs of the Organization of African Unity, Daniel Antonio. The Government proposed a coalition government of national unity in 1996, but RUF refused to compromise.

The implementation of the Abidjan Agreement failed. The main reason for this is that the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC) toppled the Government of Sierra Leone in a coup on 25 May 1997 and took control of the Government, after which the RUF entered into an alliance with the AFRC. The AFRC was ousted from power in February 1998, when ECOMOG took control over Freetown. President Kabbah was reinstated in March 1998. No mediation or negotiations took place between the RUF and the Government of Sierra Leone in 1997 and 1998, prior to the May 1997 coup and following the AFRC being ousted from power in March 1998.  Although the AFRC and the RUF were ousted from power in early 1998, the war was not over. The AFRC and RUF remained and put up tough resistance against the government forces and their allies in the eastern parts of Sierra Leone. On 1 January, the government announced it had reached a temporary ceasefire with RUF through indirect negotiations. Even so, the RUF and the AFRC forces invaded Freetown on 6 January 1999, resulting in a battle that lasted for more than six weeks. Following the attack on Freetown, heavy international pressure began to be put on the Kabbah government to negotiate a peaceful settlement with RUF. The US, the UN and the UK became more strongly involved. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan actively supported the efforts of his Special Representative Francis Okelo to initiate negotiations. What is more, the UN Security Council arms and oil embargo that had been adopted in 1997 was still in place. Similarly, US President Bill Clinton sent his special envoy for Africa, Jesse Jackson, to actively lobby with RUF and Government officials to start peace talks.
This third party pressure brought an unwilling President Kabbah to Togo’s capital Lomé, where peace negotiations mediated by ECOWAS were held in April 1999.
Another round ECOWAS-mediated negotiations took place in  Lomé in May 1999. On 18 May 1999, a ceasefire agreement was signed.
A further round of ECOWAS-mediated negotiations in July led to the signing of the Lomé Peace Agreement on 7 July 1999, which was mediated by ECOWAS Chairman, President Gnassingbe Eyadema.

On 15 May 2000, government forces attacked a traditional stronghold of the RUF, after they had secured key bridges and towns the troops had lost to the rebels the previous week. In response, the UN tried to mediate a ceasefire and reconfirm the conflict parties’ commitment to the Lomé Agreement.

A six-member ECOWAS delegation mediated between the conflict parties in June 2000, but was unsuccessful in restoring the ceasefire. From June 2000 onwards, RUF began attacking UNAMSIL troops. However, Sankoh’s attempt to take control of the country was foiled by the arrival of battle-hardened and well-equipped British forces that aligned themselves with the remnants of the Sierra Leone army. Sankoh was captured once again and after significant losses the rebels began to cooperate with the Lomé peace agreement.

In November 2000, negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS, were held in Abuja between representatives of the Sierra Leone government and the RUF. The two sides discussed an agenda which included the restructuring of the Sierra Leone Army, the free movement of all people in Sierra Leone, the return of all weapons seized from UN peacekeepers, the ceasefire, the political agenda of the RUF, and disarmament. The Sierra Leone government delegation was led by Justice Minister and Attorney-General Solomon Berewa and the RUF delegation was led by Colonel Jonathan Kposowa. An agreement confirming the Lomé peace agreement was reached on 10 November and would be referred to as the Abuja Ceasefire Agreement.
The two sides reaffirmed their adherence to the Abuja Ceasefire Agreement on 3 May 2001.

On 25 May 1997, the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC), under the command of Major Johnny Paul Koroma, toppled the Government of Sierra Leone in a coup and took control of the government. After this successful coup, the AFRC formed a new government with the RUF and civilians. In July 1997, under the ECOMOG flag – together with the Ivory Coast, Guinea and Ghana – Nigeria began to lead the military campaign to restore Kabbah to power. This campaign initially failed. As a result, a four-nation committee – consisting of Nigeria, Ivory Coast, Guinea, and Ghana – established by ECOWAS subsequently negotiated with both Kabbah supporters and the AFRC in Conakry, Guinea, on 23 October 1997. The parties agreed that President Kabbah would be reinstated within six months, but the AFRC effectively stalled the implementation of this agreement. By January 1998, as many as 10,000 Nigerian troops were stationed in Sierra Leone, which together with the Kamajors fought the AFRC junta. In February 1998, fighting between the ECOMOG forces and the forces of the AFRC and the RUF escalated, which resulted in ECOMOG taking control over Freetown, reinstating President Kabbah in March 1998. Although the AFRC and the RUF were ousted from power in early 1998, the war was not over. The AFRC and RUF remained and put up tough resistance against the government forces and their allies in the eastern parts of Sierra Leone. What is more, the RUF and the AFRC forces invaded Freetown on 6 January 1999, resulting in a battle that lasted for more than six weeks. The rebel AFRC regrouped to retake the capital in January 1999, but was again forced out by the Nigerian-led force. Following this unsuccessful attempt to take control of Freetown, the AFRC devolved into bands of loosely associated combatants.
third_party: ECOWAS; Nigeria;  Ivory Coast; Guinea; Ghana

description: Negotiations have taken place between the conflict parties, of which the first took place between AIS leaders, Abassi Madani and Ali Belhadj, and Algerian government officials from December 1993 to March 1994. The talks concerned, among others, an amnesty and a three year transitional period towards a democratic political system.

Further talks were initiated in August 1994, after AIS leader Abassi Madani had sent two letters to President Liamine Zeroual in which he stated that his party agreed to respect the principle of changes in government through elections. These negotiation ended by the end of October 1994 as a result of disagreements over the issues concerning the future role of the army, the nature of a transitional regime, and the status of the estimated 10,000 political prisoners.

On 21 and 22 November 1994, the Community of Sant’Egidio, a Christian NGO based in Italy, hosted a conference in Rome that sought to gather Algeria’s main political forces in order to find a solution to the civil war. The AIS attended, but the Algerian Government charged the conference as foreign interference in Algeria’s domestic affairs refusing to come to the conference.
Another round of bilateral negotiations was held between May and July 1995, breaking down due to a refusal by the AIS to call for the end of violence before its leaders were released.
Another round of talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 1 October 1997.
The FIS and the Algerian Government concluded a peace agreement following negotiations in December 1999. The agreement stipulates, among other things, that all AIS fighters receive full amnesty.

Namibian President Sam Nujoma and Foreign Minister Gurirab served as mediators in indirect talks between the government and FLEC-R that took place in Windhoek, Namibia, in early June 1995. These talks were to focus on reaching a ceasefire agreement, which could then clear the road for substantial negotiations on a long-term peace settlement.
Through the good office of Ethiopia, further talks were held in Addis-Ababa, in late June, between President dos Santos and FLEC-R leader Jose Tiburico Zingba Luemba.
Another round of negotiations took place in Windhoek, Namibia, in August 1995.

A round of negotiations mediated by Congo finally led to the signing of a four-months ceasefire agreement between the government and FLEC-R in Pointe Noir on 24 September 1995 that came into effect on the night of 26 to 27 September.
Negotiations in Windhoek led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 27 February 1996.
Negotiations in Brazzaville led to a ceasefire in July 1996.

The rebel groups announced a unified FLEC in 2004, but this unification already broke down in 2005 because of a disagreement on entering into negotiations. While the FLEC-FAC opposed peace talks, the FLEC-R was open to the possibility of entering negotiations.  In early June 2006, the 24 January 2006 appointed AU Chairman and President of the Republic of Congo, Denis Sassou-Nguessou, who was also a long-time ally of President dos Santos, hosted negotiations in Libreville, Gabon.

After some follow-up meetings, the parties met again in Brazzaville in mid-July 2006. After three days of negotiations, the conflict parties agreed on a final text of the memorandum of understanding and on 18 July 2006 a ceasefire accord was signed.

Another round of negotiations in the municipality of Namibe led to the conclusion of a peace agreement – called the Memorandum of Understanding for Peace and Reconciliation in Cabinda – on 1 August 2006. This agreement was formally signed by Virgilio de Fontes Pereira, the Angolan minister for Territorial Administration, and Antonio Bento Bembe.
agreement_name: Memorandum of Understanding for Peace and Reconciliation in Cabinda

description: Fighting between FLEC and MPLA troops took place throughout November 1975, but it is not clear how many people died in battle. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1989. Nevertheless, it is clear that the conflict was inactive until 1994, when fighting escalated beyond 25 battle-related-deaths for the first time. In February 1994, President dos Santos and FLEC-FAC leader Henriques Tiago N’Zita met face to face for the first time. They discussed a ceasefire to pave the way for negotiations on the future status of the province. Jean Pierre Salanic, who is a French lawyer, and Brigadier Bernard Leandri served as facilitators at this meeting. The talks ended without progress being made.
In early May 1996, talks, facilitated through the good office of Congo, between the government and FLEC-FAC were held in Pointe-Noire.
A subsequent round of negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement in Libreville on 15 May 1996.

Military delegations met in Libreville, Gabon, on 22 July of the same year. These talks focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire and other issues, but FLEC-FAC refused to discuss the possibility of a ceasefire and instead suggested scaling down the hostilities, after which the government delegation unilaterally suspended the meeting.
In late 2001, the conflict parties engaged in exploratory talks. Yet, these exploratory talks did not lead to official negotiations.

Fighting in Cabinda intensified in 2002. As a result of the defeat of UNITA, the Angolan government redirected at least 30,000 troops to Cabinda and started a large-scale offensive in October 2002. The government forces managed to destroy the main bases of both FLEC-FAC and FLEC-R by the end of 2002. The Angolan government simeltanously offered negotiations without accepting the separatist’s demands for a referendum on the legal status of Cabinda in October 2002. Simultaneously to the government offensive, FLEC-FAC and the Government of Angola met in Paris for official negotiations in February 2003. The government delegation proposed that in return for Cabinda remaining an integral part of Angola, it would increase its budget for the enclave and promised to integrate FLEC-FAC fighters into the armed forces. The FLEC-FAC rejected this proposal, allegedly because the government had promised the same to FLEC-R.

In March 1993, some 20 Islamic scholars and leaders mediated between the government side and the militants, meeting both sides and suggesting terms for a ceasefire. The interior minister, Mohammed Abdel-Halim Moussa, was sacked after he publicly mentioned the mediation meeting. The Government of Egypt subsequently denied mediation had taken place.
In early 1997, Chad met FDR representatives and persuaded them to engage in negotiations with the Government of Niger in Chad, mediated by Algeria, Burkina Faso, Chad, France and Libya.
third_party: France; Algeria; Burkina Faso; Chad; Libya

description: Heavy clashes took place between government forces and the FDR in May 1997, which prompted the FDR to withdraw from the peace process. Alergia tried to resume the peace process again. During the last two weeks of November 1997, negotiations between Government of Niger and the FDR, mediated by Algeria, were held in Algiers. The talks led to the signing of a peace accord on 29 November 1997.

On 22 August 1998, the Chadian government mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties in N’djamena. This led to a peace agreement between the FDR and government of Niger. The agreement calls for the incorporation of rebel elements into government security and civilian services.

The Organization of African Unity condemned the secession as “totally unacceptable” and did not recognise it. In spite of condemning the unilateral declaration of independence, the Organization of African Unity dispatch Pierre Yere as a special envoy of the Organization of African Unity to the Comoros to serve as mediator and shuttle between the Comores capital Moroni and Anjouan. Yere had been appointed by the Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim. Commenting on his mediation effort, Yere stated that “Our objective right now is to bring all these people together around a negotiating table.” Pierre Yere, arrived on the islands for his first exploratory talks on 8 August. Before his mission ended on 16 August, Yere appeared to have secured the agreement of all parties on the institution of a settlement plan to include an international conference on the Comores, the deployment of Organization of African Unity military observers and the organisation of a Round Table of Donors to mobilise the necessary resources for development. On 22 August 1997, the Organization of African Unity’s Central Organ for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution met at ambassadorial level to consider developments in the Comores. It decided that the proposed conference on the situation should be held in Addis Ababa from 10 to 17 September and should examine the political, institutional and socio-economic problems of Comores in their entirety. On the basis of this decisions, Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim asked Yere to return to the islands on 30 August to make arrangements for the conference.
Yere met with the parties to prepare for official negotiations at a peace conference, but on 3 September, the Government of the Comoros launched an invasion of Anjouan.

On 19 September, Yere began his third mission to the islands. An apparently chastened Taki assured the envoy of his determination to do everything possible to seek a peaceful solution to the crisis, and promised an amnesty for deeds committed by the secessionists. On their part, the Anjouanais negotiators’ position had hardened: they accused the Comoran government of reneging on its previous undertakings and of inflicting severe human and material damage on their island. The pre-negotiations that had started on 19 September, mediated by Yere, continued until 2 October, centring on the proposed conference in Addis, the release of the soldiers taken prisoner on Anjouan, and the deployment of the Organization of African Unity observer mission on that island. The Organization of African Unity invited all conflict parties to an inter-Comorian reconciliation conference in Addis Ababa, under Organization of African Unity auspices. The conflict parties accepted the invitation, after which the conference was scheduled to take place between 10 and 13 December 1997.

In its meeting of 6 November, the Organization of African Unity Central Organ also asked the Secretary General to consider appropriate measures to preserve Comoran unity. Four days later, Ambassador Yere was on his fourth mission to the islands. He failed to secure the agreement of the Anjouanais to the deployment of an Organization of African Unity observer mission or to the demand that Anjouan would be represented at the conference as a part of Comores.

Representatives of various parties participated in the negotiations at Addis Ababa between 10 and 13 December, including the Comorian Government, the self-proclaimed Governments of Anjouan and Moheli, Comorian political parties, and international organisations. After three days of talks, agreement had been reached to convene an inter-island conference under Organization of African Unity auspices to work out a mutually acceptable institutional framework. The final communique also recorded deep regret at the military action on Anjouan and Mohkli. A document, referred to as the Addis Abeba Agreement, was drawn up, but this documents is not coded as a peace agreement since it was merely stated in this agreement that a Comorian inter-island conference should be held as soon as possible “with a view to defining a new institutional framework meeting the aspiration of the Comorian people.” On 25 December, an Organization of African Unity mission led by Said Djinnit, the Organisation’s chief of cabinet, arrived in the Comores. It returned with the welcome news that all parties seemed committed to the arrangements agreed in Addis earlier in the month.

Secret negotiations between the Anjouan separatists and the Comorian government in 2000 resulted in the signing of the Famboni declaration on 26 August. No third party had been involved in the negotiations leading up to this agreement. However, the agreement was severely criticized by the Organization of African Unity on the grounds that it contravened the Antananarivo Agreement from 1999 (this agreement was never signed by the Anjouan separatists). Additionally, the opposition on both Anjouan and Moroni strongly criticized the agreement for excluding a great majority of the Comorian people and political shareholders. As a result, negotiations continued.

Negotiations continued in early 2001, under the auspices of the Organization of African Unity and la Francophonie. Francisco J. C. Madeira, the Special Envoy on Comoros of the Organization of African Unity Secretary-General, and André Salifou, the Special envoy on Comoros of la Francophonie and former Minister of Foreign Affairs of Niger, acted as the joint chief mediators. The peace talks led to the signing of the Famboni II Agreement on 17 February. However, the implementation of the accord was fraught with difficulties. Consequently, negotiations regarding the new constitution continued. In addition, three coup attempts took place, of which one was successful. In a coup taking place on 8 and 9 August, Anjouan President Said Abeid Abdérémane was removed from power and replaced by a collective military presidency, which appointed a Government consisting of eight civilian commissioners. The new leaders committed themselves to the Famboni II agreement, which improved the prospects of successful implementation. The new constitution was finally approved in a referendum in December 2001. This constitution granted autonomy to the federation’s three islands, as well as stipulated that each island was to have its own local president, overseen by a single Union President.

In 2003, the AU urged the government of Comoros to hold parliamentary elections and to establish a constitutional court. A delegation of the AU’s countries of the region – which included South Africa, Madagascar, Tanzania, Mauritius, and Mozambique – mediated the talks in August 2003 that led to the conclusion of a draft document, the so-called Pretoria Memorandum, which covered the main points of contention. South African President Thabo Mbeki acted as the chief mediator during these talks. A follow-up meeting was scheduled in early September to decide how the agreement was to be implemented, but this meeting was postponed after the Union government claimed that it could not guarantee the safety of South African President Mbeki. The Union government also rejected parts of the draft agreement.
In December 2003, the parties met again, which led to the conclusion of the Agreement on the transitional arrangements in the Comoros in Moroni on 20 December.
agreement_name: Agreement on the transitional arrangements in the Comoros

description: The re-run of the legislative election held in May 1993, which was won by Pascal Lissouba’s party the Union Panafricaine pour la démocratie sociale (UPADS) (English: Pan-African Union for Social Democracy), triggered political violence in the capital. The opposition refused to accept the results. In response to the growing tensions, the main political parties created militias to increase their security. In November, fighting broke out in the Bakongo district between the Government army and the Ninja militia, with the latter being loyal to Bernard Kolelas and the the Mouvement congolais pour la démocratie et le développement integral (MCDDI) (English: the Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development). The Government of Congo requested the Organization of African Unity to mediate when the war broke out in 1993. Three names were submitted by the Organization of African Unity, and the conflict parties selected Mohamed Sahnoun as mediator, who in turn invited President Bongo of Gabon to work with him. Sahnoun succeed in concluding a ceasefire during a first round of negotiations in May 1993.
Next, the parties went to Libreville for negotiations, where Sahnoun and Bongo, aided by French diplomats, conducted shuttle diplomacy in early August 1993.

Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 November 1993 by Prime Minister of Congo, Joachim Yhombi-Opango, and the political leader of the Mouvement Congolais pour la Démocratie et le Développement Intégral (MCDDI) (Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development), Bernard Kolela. Under the agreement the Prime Minister was to order the security forces back to barracks while Kolelas was to call for calm. No third party was involved in these negotiations.

Congolese General Ngollo mediated in January 1994 between the MCDDI and President Lissouba’s party, the Union Panafricaine pour la Démocratie Sociale (UPADS) (English: Pan-African Union for Social Democracy), which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 30 January. Both sides also agreed to disarm their militias.

In April, Ngollo held talks with northern army officers loyal to Sassou-Nguessou. In December 1994, President Lissouba hosted a regional peace forum in Brazzaville, where the conflict parties agreed to set up a committee to monitor the disarmament of the militias.

Since he seized power in October 1997, President Sassou-Nguessou refused to initiate peace talks with any conflict party. However, in 1999, Sassou-Nguessou seemed willing to negotiate directly with the various rebel factions, as he sent secret emissaries to establish contact. Following four days of intense negotiations between representatives of the Government and the Conseil National de la Résistance (CNR) (National Resistance Council) – which acted as a political umbrella organisation of the Ninja, Cocoyes, and Ntsiloulous militias – a ceasefire agreement was signed in Pointe-Noir on 16 November 1999. The negotiations leading up to this ceasefire were a strictly internal affair.

A second round of negotiations was mediated by President Omar Bongo of Gabon and Mohamed Sahnoun in Libreville in December. President Omar Bongo of Gabon had been contacted to end the hostilities by President Sassou Nguesso of Congo, who was also Bongo’s father-in-law. Gabon effort to resolve the conflict were aided by the International Negotiation Network (INN), which had been involved consultations with the conflict parties since August 1999, when Professor William Zartman and Joyce Neu had travelled to Brazzaville. On the basis of these consultations, the representatives of the INN drafted an eight-point document outlining a framework for a transition to free and fair elections. Although the INN launched its mediation attempt separately from Omar Bongo’s efforts, President Sassou-Nguessou made it clear that he wold only accept mediation by the INN if they would coordinate with Bongo. On 16 November, the Congolese government signed a peace agreement in Pointe-Noire with smaller militias that supported the Cocoyes and Ninjas. However, the rebel groups themselves rejected this accord.

Peace talks mediated by Bongo opened in Libreville on 18 December 1999. During the negotiations, Bongo built on the eight-point document that had been produced by the INN. The peace talks led to the signing of the Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités in Brazzaville on 29 December 1999.
agreement_name: Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités

description: After three years, the situation heated up again in 1997. Early in the morning of 5 June 1997, Government troops surrounded Sassou-Nguessou’s residence in the Mpila district of northern Brazzaville, stating that they were looking to disarm his illegal Cobra militia. Heavy fighting subsequently erupted. On 9 June, French President Jacques Chirac negotiated a ceasefire between the conflict parties by telephone.
The conflict parties reached a 3-day truce on 18 June, which was extended into another week.
Other ceasefires were reached on 28 June and 6 July, albeit both were violated.
Other ceasefires were reached on 28 June and 6 July, albeit both were violated.
Mohamed Sahnoun, the United Nations’ special envoy brokered a ceasefire between the Congolese government and Cobras on 12 July.

On 18 July 1997, representatives from both sides, along with a national mediation committee headed by the leader of the Ninjas militia Bernard Kolela, began talks in Libreville, Gabon, but no progress was made.

On 14 September, African leaders organised a new summit meeting in Libreville. To this purpose, President Omar Bongo of Gabon set up and led an international mediation committee, consisting of heads of state of Central African Republic, Chad and Mali, as well as representatives from several other African countries. Joint UN-Organization of African Unity special envoy to the Great Lakes region, Mohammad Sahnoun, also acted participated in the peace talks. The involvement of Bongo and Sahnoun was based on an earlier mediation effort in 1993, but when fighting intensified in 1997 they resumed their efforts. The political leader of the Cobras, Sassou-Nguessou, attended in person, whereas President Lissouba opted to stay away and send the leader of the Ninjas militia Bernard Kolela on his behalf. Both sides made presentations to the assembled dignitaries, but no significant progress was made. The stumbling block in the meeting was over who should govern the country pending fresh elections. Distrust was deep and both sides were fearful that the other would be able to exploit a period of a national unity government to turn the future elections to its own advantage.
third_party: Central African Republic; Chad; Mali; OAU; UN

description: On 9 October, the UN brokered another ceasefire agreement. In late October 1997, with strong secondary warring support from Angola, the Cobras gained control over Brazaville, which made Sassou-Nguessou declare himself head of state, thus terminating this dyad.

Since he seized power in October 1997, President Sassou-Nguessou refused to initiate peace talks with any conflict party. However, in 1999, Sassou-Nguessou seemed willing to negotiate directly with the various rebel factions, as he sent secret emissaries to establish contact. Following four days of intense negotiations between representatives of the Government and the Conseil National de la Résistance (CNR) (National Resistance Council) – which acted as a political umbrella organisation of the Ninja, Cocoyes, and Ntsiloulous militias – a ceasefire agreement was signed in Pointe-Noir on 16 November 1999. The negotiations leading up to this ceasefire were a strictly internal affair.

A second round of negotiations was mediated by President Omar Bongo of Gabon and Mohamed Sahnoun in Libreville in December. President Omar Bongo of Gabon had been contacted to end the hostilities by President Sassou Nguesso of Congo, who was also Bongo’s father-in-law. Gabon effort to resolve the conflict were aided by the International Negotiation Network (INN), which had been involved consultations with the conflict parties since August 1999, when Professor William Zartman and Joyce Neu had travelled to Brazzaville. On the basis of these consultations, the representatives of the INN drafted an eight-point document outlining a framework for a transition to free and fair elections. Although the INN launched its mediation attempt separately from Omar Bongo’s efforts, President Sassou-Nguessou made it clear that he wold only accept mediation by the INN if they would coordinate with Bongo. On 16 November, the Congolese government signed a peace agreement in Pointe-Noire with smaller militias that supported the Cocoyes and Ninjas. However, the rebel groups themselves rejected this accord.

Peace talks mediated by Bongo opened in Libreville on 18 December 1999. During the negotiations, Bongo built on the eight-point document that had been produced by the INN. The peace talks led to the signing of the Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités in Brazzaville on 29 December 1999.
agreement_name: Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités

description: Since he seized power in October 1997, President Sassou-Nguessou refused to initiate peace talks with any conflict party. However, in 1999, Sassou-Nguessou seemed willing to negotiate directly with the various rebel factions, as he sent secret emissaries to establish contact. Following four days of intense negotiations between representatives of the Government and the Conseil National de la Résistance (CNR) (National Resistance Council) – which acted as a political umbrella organisation of the Ninja, Cocoyes, and Ntsiloulous militias – a ceasefire agreement was signed in Pointe-Noir on 16 November 1999. The negotiations leading up to this ceasefire were a strictly internal affair.

A second round of negotiations was mediated by President Omar Bongo of Gabon and Mohamed Sahnoun in Libreville in December. President Omar Bongo of Gabon had been contacted to end the hostilities by President Sassou Nguesso of Congo, who was also Bongo’s father-in-law. Gabon effort to resolve the conflict were aided by the International Negotiation Network (INN), which had been involved consultations with the conflict parties since August 1999, when Professor William Zartman and Joyce Neu had travelled to Brazzaville. On the basis of these consultations, the representatives of the INN drafted an eight-point document outlining a framework for a transition to free and fair elections. Although the INN launched its mediation attempt separately from Omar Bongo’s efforts, President Sassou-Nguessou made it clear that he wold only accept mediation by the INN if they would coordinate with Bongo. On 16 November, the Congolese government signed a peace agreement in Pointe-Noire with smaller militias that supported the Cocoyes and Ninjas. However, the rebel groups themselves rejected this accord.

Peace talks mediated by Bongo opened in Libreville on 18 December 1999. During the negotiations, Bongo built on the eight-point document that had been produced by the INN. The peace talks led to the signing of the Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités in Brazzaville on 29 December 1999.
agreement_name: Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilités

description: In 2002, the conflict between the government side and the Ntsiloulou militia again surpassed 25 battle-related deaths. Secret negotiations mediated by Omar Bongo were held between the government and the Ntsiloulou militia, starting in January 2003. Isidore Mvouba, the government’s coordinator and Adelaide Moundele-Ngollo, the Minister of trade, led the government side.

Due to the secretive nature of the Bongo-led talk, not much is known about the proceedings, but on 17 March a peace agreement was concluded, which was referred to as the accords of reaffirmation of the 1999 accords.

On 28 December 2009, Ntoumi finally arrived in Brazzaville to take up his post as the General Delegate in Charge of the Promotion of Peace and Post-Conflict Reconstruction. However, tensions between Toumi and President Sassou increased again in the run up to the 2016 elections, in which Sassou sought a third term as president. In early April 2016, the Ntsiloulous militia attacked government targets in the wake of the contested elections won by Sassou. The government in retaliation conducted bombings and attacks in the Pool area, targeting Ntoumi and his Ntsiloulous militia. France tried to mediate between the conflict parties, but failed to initiate direct negotiations. Jean Gustave Ntondo, a representative of Ntoumi and the Ntsiloulous militia, momentarily withdrew from Brazzaville to take shelter following the armed violence in April 2016, but he was invited back to enter into negotiations by the Minister of the Interior and Territorial Administration, Raymond Zéphyrin Mboulou. Jean Gustave Ntondo subsequently came to Brazzaville with a delegation of 12 people to begin negotiations with the government on 6 May 2016.

A round of negotiations without the involvement of any third party in December 2017 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 24 December 2017. The ceasefire agreement stipulates that the Ntsiloulous militia led by Ntoumi would facilitate the collection of weapons held by its fighters and not create any obstacles to the reestablishment of state authority in the department of Pool. The ceasefire agreement further stipulated that for its part, the government should guarantee “the process of demobilization, as well as professional, social, and economic reintegration of ex-combatants after the collection of weapons.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: In early 1998, President João Bernardo Viera dismissed General Ansumane Mané, falsely accusing him of gunrunning to Casamançe. In June 1998, Viera sent troops to arrest Mané, but fighting erupted. Mané subsequently formed the Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice. The Government avoided defeat by relying on troops from Guinea and Senegal. In June 1998, President Vieira accepted Gambia’s President Yahya Jammeh offer of Gambian mediation, after which Sedath Jobe, the Foreign Minister of Gambia, began its efforts to bring peace to Guinea-Bissau. A round of negotiations mediated by Gambia led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 10 June. The two sides also agreed to further talks.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: The Ambassadors of Portugal and Angola launched a joint mediation effort and scheduled the first meeting between the conflicting parties aboard of a Portuguese frigate anchored off the coast on 28 June 1998, but no government representatives showed up: Francisco Henriques da Silva, the Portuguese ambassador, who acted as the official go-between for this planned meeting was waiting on board of the Vasco da Gama with the rebel delegation.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: On 3 July, ECOWAS Foreign and Defence Ministers met to discuss the situation in Guinea-Bissau and it was decided to support the military intervention of Senegal and Guinea and to broaden ECOMOG’s mandate beyond Sierra Leone to include Guinea-Bissau. Another effort to end the conflict through mediation was initiated in July 1998 by the Community of Portuguese-speaking countries (CPLP), leading to the conclusion of a ceasefire and Memorandum of Understanding on 26 July 1998. Portugal provided the good offices of these negotiations on board of a naval vessel called the Corte-Real.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Another round of negotiations mediated by the CPLP led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 8 August 1998.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Later that month, on 25 August, the parties met for negotiations in Cape Verde under the auspices of both CPLP and ECOWAS.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Another round of negotiations was held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, in September, where the conflict parties agreed on the need of a peacekeeping force to ensure a ceasefire.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Two round of negotiations were held in October. The first took place in Banjul, Gambia, which was mediated by the Gambian Foreign Minister Sadat Jobe.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Two round of negotiations were held in October. The second round of negotiations took place in Portugal, where Portugal mediated the first face-to-face meeting between Vieira and Mane. France and Sweden were also present at the talks in Portugal. On 21 October, the government of Guinea-Bissau announced a unilateral ceasefire. Two days later, the rebels announced their own ceasefire.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Negotiations mediated by ECOWAS – led by Presidents Abdulsalam Abubakar of Nigeria and Yahya Jammeh of Gambia, as well as Foreign Ministers from Ghana, Niger, Senegal and Togo – started again in Abuja on 31 October. During the peace talks, the mediators made it clear that if a peace agreement would be concluded, ECOMOG would ensure the implementation. The peace talks at Abuja led to the signing of the Abuja Peace Agreement on 1 November 1998.
third_party: ECOWAS; Ghana; Niger; Nigeria; Senegal; Togo

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: However, fighting erupted again along the front line in the north of Guinea-Bissau on 31 January 1999, just when around 300 ECOMOG soldiers from Benin and Niger aboard the French warship Sirrocco were about to arrive in the port of Bissau. As a response to renewed fighting, the President of Togo and then Chairman of ECOWAS, Gnassingbé Eyadéma, dispatched his Foreign Minister, Joseph Kokou Koffigoh, to present the conflict parties with a ceasefire, which Viera and Mane signed on 3 February.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Further negotiations mediated by ECOWAS were held on a number of occasions throughout February, resulting in the announcement of a government of national unity and the complete withdrawal of the Senegalese and Guinean troops. The government of national unity was officially inaugurated on 20 February, with five cabinet ministers nominated by Viera and four by Mane. As stipulated in the Abuja Agreement, the Senegalese and Guinean troops had withdrawn their forces by the end of March, while an ECOMOG force of around 700 soldiers was deployed simultaneously. The ECOMOG force had to defuse tensions between the conflict parties throughout April. With tensions increasing, fighting erupted again in late April, which led to the unconditional surrender of President Viera on 7 May.

It was not until early May 1991, that the OLF became active in negotiations for the first time, when it agreed to negotiations in London on 27 May, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would act as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneously to the negotiations, on 27 May, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year.

In early October 1992, the EPLF, one of the main rebel groups that had fought against the in 1991 ousted Derg regime, initiated talks between OLF and the newly installed EPRDF government. The talks – in which mediators from the US, UK, and Sweden actively participated – were held in Asmara on 28-29 October 1992. These Western countries had steadily increased pressure on the Ethiopian Government from early 1992 onwards to engage in peace talks. For example, in July 1992, the chairman of the US House of Representatives’ subcommittee on Africa, Mervyn Dymally, urged Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi to “continue to dialogue with the OLF.” During the October negotiations, the OLF demanded the June elections to be annulled, as well as a restructuring of the army, which was exclusively under EPRDF control. This was not acceptable for the EPRDF, who encouraged the OLF to join the Government.

In January 1994, the Carter Center launched a new mediation attempt. In early 1994, OLF representatives met with Jimmy Carter and subsequently sent him a letter, dated 4 March, agreeing to discuss in a conference or bilaterally “issues of rectification of violations of the Charter.” After having passed along this message to the Ethiopian Government, the latter replied that it was only willing to hold discussions with those who had first renounced violence, as well as that any discussions would only concern the modalities of participation in the political process as it was already structured.

In February 1995, the US Congress established a Task Force, headed by Congressman Harry Johnston, to work towards getting the Ethiopian opposition to participate in the upcoming May elections. The Task Force managed to convene a meeting in Washington between representatives of the Government of Ethiopia and the OLF, as well as some other opposition groups. The talks mainly focused on Ethiopia’s democratisation process. No agreement was reached during the negotiations.

In 1996, Germany became involved in the conflict as a third party. A delegation headed by former German Ambassador to Ethiopia, H. Winkelmann, aimed to initiate official negotiations between the conflict parties, but was unsuccessful. In February 1997, Germany managed to initiate negotiations in Bonn, where Winkelmann, served as the mediator. The Government delegation suggested the OLF to join the political process, either as a government partner or as opposition, on the precondition that the group accepted the constitution and renounced violence. Since accepting the constitution would entail accepting the territorial integrity of Ethiopia, thereby giving up the demand for an independent Oromiya, the OLF rejected this suggestion.

In spite of Eritrea hosting both the OLF and the ONLF on its territory, it initiated a mediation effort between the Ethiopian government and these two rebel groups. A round of negotiations mediated by Eritrea led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement between the government and the OLF in August 2018. Eritrean minister of information, Yemane Gebremeskel, called the agreement a “Reconciliation Agreement.”

On the night of 27 May 2001, a loose-knit group of mutinous soldiers led by André Kolingba attempted to oust the sitting president Ange-Félix Patassé in a coup. One of the reasons for the coup was resentment among the Yakoma soldiers was the perceived preferential treatment of Presidential Guard. The coup attempt was fairly limited in scope, with most of the fighting taking place within a short period of time and in a restricted geographical area. After the initial attack on the presidential residence, there was intense shelling of the capital’s south-western districts, where the rebels were hiding. A group of around 100 Libyan soldiers, as well as a group of rebel fighters of the Mouvement de Libération du Congo (MLC) (English: Movement for the Liberation of the Congo), supported the government forces in preventing the coup. On 31 May 2001, Kolingba announced that “Taking due account of the urgent and patriotic appeal from the people's representatives, I have agreed to order hostilities to cease as of this evening. I am asking the mutineers to return to their homes.” After two weeks of fighting in Bangui, the Government troops had seized control of the entire city. A manhunt against Yakuma families commenced, leading to some 80,000 civilians fleeing the capital. The UN condemned the coup, but stressed that there must not be a witch-hunt of the Yakoma tribe. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan manated former Malian President Amadou Touré as the UN peace envoy to the Central African Republic on 5 June 2001. Annan stated that in response to the violence that continues to plague the Central African Republic, following the attempted coup on 27 and 28 May 2001, he decided to “dispatch to Bangui, as his Special Envoy, General Amadou Toumani Touré of Mali, for urgent talks with President Patassé and other authorities and actors. The Special Envoy will hold discussions with his interlocutors with a view to ending the fighting that reportedly continues in parts of Bangui between forces loyal to the Government and the rebels, and restoring peaceful political dialogue within the framework of respect for the country’s democratic institutions.” UN peace envoy and former Malian President Amadou Touré subsequently mediated peace talks in Bangui in June 2001, involving the government, the opposition, and civil society.

Armed violence had stopped by November 2001, but when the unrest resurged, third party efforts were intensified. The new UN peace envoy, Lamine Cisse, a Senegalese retired army general, led this mediation effort between November and December 2001. Chadian Ambassador, Maitimo Njumbe, also played an active role. In addition, an Organization of African Unity mediation team, led by Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Mahamat Habib Doutoum, was involved in the mediation as well. However, neither the mediation effort by the UN after the coup, nor the mediation effort of the UN, Chad, and the Organization of African Unity from November onwards succeeded in initiating negotiations between the conflict parties or in concluding a peace agreement.

The new UN peace envoy, Lamine Cisse, a Senegalese retired army general, led this mediation effort between November and December 2001. Chadian Ambassador, Maitimo Njumbe, also played an active role. In addition, an Organization of African Unity mediation team, led by Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Mahamat Habib Doutoum, was involved in the mediation as well. However, neither the mediation effort by the UN after the coup, nor the mediation effort of the UN, Chad, and the Organization of African Unity from November onwards succeeded in initiating negotiations between the conflict parties or in concluding a peace agreement.

Libya, together with Chad and CEN-SAD, initiated a mediated round of negotiations in Syrte in February 2007. In addition to the UFDR, the Front démocratique du peuple centrafricain (FDPC) (English: Democratic Front of the Central African People) was also part of the negotiations. The negotiations led to the Syrte agreement on 2 February 2007.

Another round of negotiations between the Government of the Central African Republic and the UFDR led to the signing of the Birao Agreement on 13 April 2007. No third parties were involved in the negotiations leading up to the signing of this peace agreement, though the UN witnessed the signing of the peace agreement.

During the first three months of 2008, Bozize held a political dialogue, facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD). The dialogue involved included the ruling party Kwa Na Kwa, the political opposition alliance Forces vives de la nation, civil society representatives, and several rebel groups.

This paved the way for direct negotiations between the government and armed opposition groups. Between May and July 2008, Omar Bongo, President of Gabon, acted as mediator for negotiations in Libreville that were attended by the UFDR, as well as the Armée Populaire pour la Restauration de la Démocratie (APRD) and the Front Démocratique du Peuple Centrafricain (FDPC). Bongo’s mandate was based on his role as the Chairman of the ad-hoc Committee within the CEMAC on Central African issues. Michel Djotodia led the UFDR during the talks in Libreville. The government signed a ceasefire with only the APRD on 9 May 2008.

Between May and July 2008, Omar Bongo, President of Gabon, acted as mediator for negotiations in Libreville that were attended by the UFDR, as well as the Armée Populaire pour la Restauration de la Démocratie (APRD) and the Front Démocratique du Peuple Centrafricain (FDPC). Bongo’s mandate was based on his role as the Chairman of the ad-hoc Committee within the CEMAC on Central African issues. Michel Djotodia led the UFDR during the talks in Libreville.
Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of a comprehensive peace agreement on 21 June 2008, signed by all three rebel groups.

ECCAS mediator, Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, invited the conflict parties to Libreville in early 2013. This led to the signing of the Libreville Agreement on 11 January 2013. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire and defined the modalities for power sharing and a political transition. However, the agreement soon broke down. The Chadian forces deployed in CAR did not stop the Seleka fighters when they started a new offensive in March 2013. Some South Africans troops in CAR did try to stop the Seleka advance, but they failed to do so. The Seleka managed to take over control of Bangui by March 2013. It subsequently deposed Bozizé, while installing Michel Djotodia as President. Djotodia could not control the Seleka movement, with many local Seleka commanders ruling town and villages as their personal fiefdoms. Many of the Seleka engaged in the mass killing of Christians in Bangui and throughout CAR. This led to the emergence of a self-defense militia, called the anti-Balaka. From this point onwards, the armed violence in the Central African Republic was mainly between non-state armed groups. Unable to control the Seleka fighters, Djotodia disbanded the Seleka. However, this made it even harder to control the Seleka. The subsequent non-state conflict between Seleka fighters and self-defense militias called the anti-Balaka, as well as widespread attacks on Christians and Muslims by each of these armed actors, led to the deployment of a French intervention force and an African union peacekeeping missions in December 2013 and January 2014 respectively.

On January 10, 2014, a conference in N’Djamena brought about the end of the regime of Djotodia, paving the way for a political transition. Chadian President Idriss Déby convinced Djotodia to step down, after which former mayor of Bangui Catherine Samba-Panza was elected as the new president by the new transitional government. The Seleka alliance subsequently rebranded itself as ex-Seleka.  The UN Security Council authorized a UN peacekeeping operation in April 2014, with resolution 2149. The UCDP does not record any armed conflict between the Government of the Central African Republic and the ex-Seleka between 2014 and 2017, but several negotiations took place between the ex-Seleka alliance and the government. In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds – including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka – led to the idea of organizing a forum.

On the sidelines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC – as well as several other armed groups, though not the UPC led by Ali Darassa) – in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. However, clashes continued between the non-state armed groups parties.

Several of the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic participated in a mediation process led by the Kenyan government in Nairobi, with negotiations taking place in early 2015. Building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum in which the government also participated. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise was given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarrmenent, demoblizaition, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, inclcluding the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces républicaines fondamentales, Seleka rénovée, Mouvement des libérateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front démocratique pour le progrès de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unité du peuple centrafricain, Révolution et justice, and the Union des forces républicaines. Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact – or in full the Pacte républicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en République centrafricaine – which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR. In addition to the ECCAS-led mediation effort and the mediation effort as part of the Bangui Forum, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) mediated a unilateral ceasefire agreement with the FPRC in N’Djamena on 20 December 2015. Cheikh Tidiane Gadio acted as the chief mediator of the OIC. Noureddine Adam promised to refrain from seeking independence from the Central African Republic issued a unilateral ceasefire and stated that the ceasefire would make it possible to hold elections. Legislative and presidential elections were held without significant armed fighting in late 2015.
