agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic; Republican Pact

description: In February 2016, the AU mandated Mohamed El Hacen Lebatt as its special representative. Lebatt launched what was referred to as the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation. Angola, Chad, the DRC, and ECCAS supported this AU-led mediation effort. Talks mediated by Lebatt in February 2016 did not lead to an agreement.

In late 2016, Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups – including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. André de Oliveira João Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: International Conference on the Great Lakes; Angola

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant’Egidio started a mediation process mainly involving the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic. This led to an agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all “politico-military groups” into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire. On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touadéra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that peace agreement signed in Rome on 19 June. With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant’Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status.
The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia (Soviet Union) and Sudan in August 2018 from which the government had been excluded, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The APPR was signed by 14 non-state armed groups, including the UPC, and the CAR Government. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements, making the agreement essentially an elite-level pact to buy off armed group leaders.

The founding leader of CPJP is Charles Massi, who between 2005 and 2008 served as a defence minister in Bozizé’s government. In January 2010, Charles Massi was killed under uncertain conditions, after which Abdoulaye Hissene assumed leadership over the CPJP. The fighting consisted of fairly small-scale attacks in the north-eastern part of the country. In early June 2011, the government and CPJP were involved in negotiations, in which no third party was involved. The negotiations, which were held in the northern town of N’dele, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 12 June 2011. The CPJP agreed to confine their soldiers to barracks while talks on a final peace deal took place. The CPJP also agreed to immediate cessation of all hostility, the abstention from all military action and other forms of violence and to join the DDR campaign that several other opposition groups had already joined. After the signing of the ceasefire, no fighting between the Government and CPJP took place in 2011.

Nevertheless, in 2012, another round of negotiations took place. This resulted in the signing of a peace agreement in Bangui on 25 August 2012. The agreement recommitted the government and the CPJP to the Libreville Global Peace Agreement of 21 June 2008 and to the ceasefire agreement of 12 June 2011.

Prior to the elections of 2000, the Government of Ivory Coast, led by President Laurent Gbagbo, quickly drafted a law which required both parents of a presidential candidate to be born within Ivory Coast. This excluded the northern presidential candidate Alassane Ouattara, who broadly represented the predominantly Muslim north, from participating in the elections. This led to rising tensions. A mutiny broke out on 19 September 2002, which was triggered by President Gbagbo sending around 750 soldiers – who were known for their loyalty to Robert Guéi, which was Gbagbo’s main rival in the 2000 elections – into forced retirement. Many soldiers had indeed left the army, but had refused to turn in their weapons. The mutineers further organized themselves into the Mouvement patriotique de la Cote d’Ivoire (MPCI) (English: Patriotic Movement of Ivory Coast) led by Guillaume Soro. The MPCI demanded President Gbagbo to step down from power and organise elections within six months, open to all Ivoirians. Third party efforts aimed at ending the fighting between the Government and the MPCI were initiated at early stage in the conflict. On 31 September 2002, a team of diplomats from several West African nations – including Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Niger, Togo, and Guinea-Bissau – arrived in Abidjan to meet President Gbago and the armed opposition. This group of countries was known as the contact group which had been established at an ECOWAS meeting in Accra on 29 September 2002. The parties were close to concluding a ceasefire agreement in early October 2002, but President Gbagbo refused to sign a ceasefire at the last moment, as according to him this would legitimise the rebel movement and partition the country. Hence, the official signing ceremony did not take place.
third_party: ECOWAS; Ghana; Guinea-Bissau; Mali, Niger; Nigeria; Togo

description: A new attempt was made in mid-October, when Senegal’s Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio, on behalf of the ECOWAS contact group, held talks with the rebels, presenting a peace proposal from ECOWAS. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement in Abijan on 17 October 2002.

Formal peace negotiations started subsequently in Lomé, Togo, on 30 October 2002, where the Togolese President Gnassingbé Eyadéma, who held the ECOWAS Chairmanship at the time, was appointed coordinator of the mediating efforts. After two days of talks, on 1 November, a joint statement was issued. This statement was referred to as the Lomé Ceasefire Agreement, outlining a basic agenda of future discussions. The Lomé ceasefire agreement together with the Abidjan agreement provided the basis for military intervention by ECOWAS and France. In spite of these third party peacemaking efforts, negotiations stalled, as rebels continued to demand the resignation of president Gbago, which was unacceptable to the Government of the Ivory Coast. The Government, in turn, insisted on the immediate disarmament of the rebels, which MPCI refused. Furthermore, the negotiations became increasingly complicated, as two new rebel groups – the MPIGO and the MJP – appeared in the west of the country. This negatively affected the level of trust between the Government and MPCI, resulting in the breaching of the truce on several occasions. On 23 December 2002, the MPCI spokesman called for the UN and France to take over negotiations, as the rebels had lost confidence in the African mediators due to a lack of progress.

On 3 January 2003, the Ivoirian government committed to a unilateral ceasefire at the behest of France’s foreign minister. Between 15 and 24 January 2003, France mediated between the conflict parties and the Government of Ivory Coast in a southern suburbs of Paris, Marcoussis. Ten delegations and 32 representatives were present, including representatives of Gbagbo’s government, Guillaume Soro of the MPCI, representatives of western rebel groups MPIGO and MJP, as well as the major Ivorian political parties and Alassane Ouattara. During the negotiations, the mediators promised that a monitoring committee would be set up to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. This committee would include representatives of France, the EU, the AU, ECOWAS, the UN, la Francophphonie, the IMF, the World Bank, and the G8. On 23 January 2003, the parties signed the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords. The mediation mandate of France was reinforced through UN Security Council Resolution 1464 (4 February 2003), which welcomed French mediation and backed the French military intervention, referred to as Opération Licorne, with a Chapter Seven mandate.  The UN Security Council thus conferred the main political and military responsibility to France and ECOWAS, which were given an UN mandate to monitor the ceasefire and protect civilians.

To ensure the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, another round of negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS and Ghana was initiated at Accra. The President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, John Agyekum Kufuor, acted as the chief mediator at these peace talks. On 7 March 2003, the Accra II Agreement was concluded.

On 3 May 2003, the conflict parties as well as forces from the Liberian government signed a peace agreement in Abidjan with the intent of resolving remaining conflict in the western shared border region.
Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.
Another round of negotiations was mediated by the International Organization of Francophonie (OIF) between 1 and 4 October 2003.
France's Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.
ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.

On 3 January 2003, the Ivoirian government committed to a unilateral ceasefire at the behest of France’s foreign minister. Negotiations in Lomé in January 2003, mediated by ECOWAS mediator Mohamed Ibn Chambas, between the MPIGO and the MJP on the one side and the the Ivorian government on the other side led to a ceasefire agreement on 13 Janury 2003.

Between 15 and 24 January 2003, France mediated between the conflict parties and the Government of Ivory Coast in a southern suburbs of Paris, Marcoussis. Ten delegations and 32 representatives were present, including representatives of Gbagbo’s government, Guillaume Soro of the MPCI, representatives of western rebel groups MPIGO and MJP, as well as the major Ivorian political parties and Alassane Ouattara. During the negotiations, the mediators promised that a monitoring committee would be set up to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. This committee would include representatives of France, the EU, the AU, ECOWAS, the UN, la Francophphonie, the IMF, the World Bank, and the G8. On 23 January 2003, the parties signed the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords. The mediation mandate of France was reinforced through UN Security Council Resolution 1464 (4 February 2003), which welcomed French mediation and backed the French military intervention, referred to as Opération Licorne, with a Chapter Seven mandate.  The UN Security Council thus conferred the main political and military responsibility to France and ECOWAS, which were given an UN mandate to monitor the ceasefire and protect civilians.

To ensure the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, another round of negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS and Ghana was initiated at Accra. The President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, John Agyekum Kufuor, acted as the chief mediator at these peace talks. On 7 March 2003, the Accra II Agreement was concluded.

On 3 May 2003, the conflict parties as well as forces from the Liberian government would sign a peace agreement in Abidjan with the intent of resolving remaining conflict in the western shared border region.
Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.
Another round of negotiations was mediated by the International Organization of Francophonie (OIF) between 1 and 4 October 2003.
ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.
France's Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.

On 3 January 2003, the Ivoirian government committed to a unilateral ceasefire at the behest of France’s foreign minister. Negotiations in Lomé in January 2003, mediated by ECOWAS mediator Mohamed Ibn Chambas, between the MPIGO and the MJP on the one side and the the Ivorian government on the other side led to a ceasefire agreement on 13 Janury 2003.

Ten delegations and 32 representatives were present, including representatives of Gbagbo’s government, Guillaume Soro of the MPCI, representatives of western rebel groups MPIGO and MJP, as well as the major Ivorian political parties and Alassane Ouattara. During the negotiations, the mediators promised that a monitoring committee would be set up to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. This committee would include representatives of France, the EU, the AU, ECOWAS, the UN, la Francophphonie, the IMF, the World Bank, and the G8. On 23 January 2003, the parties signed the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords. The mediation mandate of France was reinforced through UN Security Council Resolution 1464 (4 February 2003), which welcomed French mediation and backed the French military intervention, referred to as Opération Licorne, with a Chapter Seven mandate. The UN Security Council thus conferred the main political and military responsibility to France and ECOWAS, which were given an UN mandate to monitor the ceasefire and protect civilians.

To ensure the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, another round of negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS and Ghana was initiated at Accra. The President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, John Agyekum Kufuor, acted as the chief mediator at these peace talks. On 7 March 2003, the Accra II Agreement was concluded.

On 3 May 2003, the conflict parties as well as forces from the Liberian government would sign a peace agreement in Abidjan with the intent of resolving remaining conflict in the western shared border region.
Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration on Commitment to Ceasefire

description: Another round of negotiations was mediated by the International Organization of Francophonie (OIF) between 1 and 4 October 2003.
ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.
France's Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.

In early 2003, the three major rebel parties of Ivory Cast – MPCI, MJP, and MPIGO – formed an alliance named the Forces Nouvelles (FN) (English: New Forces). This rebel alliance renamed itself the Forces Républicaines de Côte d’Ivoire (FRCI) (English: Forces Républicaines de Côte d’Ivoire: Republican Forces of Cote d’Ivoire) on 8 March 2011 in the context of the the presidential dispute between 2010 and 2011. In late June 2004, the Forces Nouvelles (FN) held talks with President Gabgbo to discuss the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis peace plan.

In July 2004, John Agyekum Kufuor, the President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, mediated peace talks in Accra. The presence of 17 African Heads of State and government representatives, as well as the presence of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and AU Chairman Olusegun Obasanjo, showed the international commitment to resolve the conflict. The negotiations led to the conclusion of the Accra III agreement on 30 July 2004. The agreement set a timetable for political reform and disarmament. While it was stipulated that the parties would start to disarm on 15 October, the rebels made it clear on 14 October that they refused to comply as a result of the slow implementation of agreed reforms.

On 28 October 2004, Lansana Kouyate, the Special Envoy of la Francophphonie, held talks with the leaders of the rebel movements in a bid to break a deadlock in the peace process. The discussions were held on disarmament and review of political reform. On 15 November 2004, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1572, which imposed an arms embargo, but also threatened the conflict parties with a 12-month travel ban and an asset freeze imposed on those who were attempting to obstruct the peace process. After being appointed as official mediator by the African Union in November 2004, South African President Thabo Mbeki travelled to Ivory Coast for three hours of talks with President Gbagbo in mid-November. According to Mbeki, Gbagbo was committed to full implementation to previously concluded peace agreements. In late November 2004, President Mbeki hosted the conflict parties in Pretoria to discuss the resumption of negations.

Between 2 and 6 December 2004, South African President Thabo Mbeki visited Ivory Coast to mediate between the adversaries, after which the conflict parties indicated that they were willing to resume official negotiations.

In spite of several attempts by South African President Thabo Mbeki, the adversaries refused to engage in direct negotiations during the first months of 2005. Accordingly, Mbeki shuttled between the different sides.

It was not until early April that face-to-face negotiations were held between FN leader Guillaume Soros and President Gbagbo in Pretoria. During the negotiations, South African President Thabo Mbeki threatened the conflict parties that the AU would impose sanctions, as specified in UN Security Council Resolution 1572, against those obstructing the peace process. The negotiations resulted in the Pretoria Agreement on the Peace Process in the Cote d’Ivoire on 6 April.
agreement_name: Pretoria Agreement on the Peace Process in the Cote d’Ivoire

description: The peace agreement did not include a timeframe of the issues addressed, which is why the conflict parties met again several times during the year. These meetings focused mainly on issues related to disarmament and upcoming elections. The parties met for negotiations in Bouake on 14 April 2005.

The peace agreement did not include a timeframe of the issues addressed, which is why the conflict parties met again several times during the year. These meetings focused mainly on issues related to disarmament and upcoming elections. The parties met for negotiations in Pretoria on 28 and 29 June 2005. This led to the Declaration on the Implementation of the Pretoria Agreement, which is referred to as Pretoria II.
agreement_name: Declaration on the Implementation of the Pretoria Agreement (Pretoria II)

description: The peace agreement did not include a timeframe of the issues addressed, which is why the conflict parties met again several times during the year. These meetings focused mainly on issues related to disarmament and upcoming elections. One round of negotiations took place in Yamoussoukro in early July 2005.

Negotiations appeared to be back on track in early 2006, when Prime Minister Charles Konan Banny, appointed in December 2005, managed to take major steps in addressing issues central to the implementation of the peace agreements.

Several negotiations were held during the first half of 2006, of which most focused on the issue of voter eligibility. The Chairman of the AU, President of the Republic of Congo, Denis Sassou-Nguessou, mediated three round of negotiations. The first round took place in February.

Several negotiations were held during the first half of 2006, of which most focused on the issue of voter eligibility. The Chairman of the AU, President of the Republic of Congo, Denis Sassou-Nguessou, mediated three round of negotiations. The second round took place in March.

Several negotiations were held during the first half of 2006, of which most focused on the issue of voter eligibility. The Chairman of the AU, President of the Republic of Congo, Denis Sassou-Nguessou, mediated three round of negotiations. The third round took place in June 2006.

On 5 July 2006, the conflict parties participated in consultations with UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan. Progress was made, but due to disagreements concerning voter’s eligibility, it soon became evident that the elections, scheduled to place on 31 October, would have to be postponed yet again.

At an ECOWAS summit held in Nigeria in early October 2006, a new framework for the political transition was outlined. After the meeting, the ECOWAS leaders forwarded their recommendations to the AU Peace and Security Council meeting in Addis Ababa, where the recommendations were accepted and sent to the UN Security Council meeting, which accepted the peace plan on 1 November. Rejecting the UN and its role in the conflict, Gbagbo presented a peace plan of his own as an alternative. In this plan he called for the abolishment of the buffer zone between rebels and government forces and for direct talks with the rebels. However, the insurgent movements rejected the offer of direct talks, stating that they would not sidestep the process laid out by the UN Security Council. Although Sassou-Nguessou had already assumed the role of chief mediator on a number of occasions during 2006, he officially replaced Mbeki by the end of 2006. The President of Niger and chairman of ECOWAS, Mamadou Tandja, and African Union Commission Chairman Alpha Oumar Konare, were also mandated to participate in the negotiations. Supplementing the arms embargo as laid down in UN Security Council Resolution 1572, the UN Security council adopted Resolution 1727, which called upon all of the member states to prevent the direct or indirect import of all rough diamonds from Ivory Coast to their territory, as well as imposed a travel ban and an asset freeze on those obstructing the peace process.
third_party: AU; ECOWAS; Niger; Republic of Congo

description: The rebel parties initially rejected the alternative peace plan presented by President Gbagbo in December 2006, but in January 2007 they eventually accepted to take part in the negotiations. ECOWAS, the AU, and the UN also gave their backing to proceed with Gbagbo’s peace plan. The president of Burkina Faso, Blaise Compaoré, who became the chairman of ECOWAS in January 2007, mediated the subsequent negotiations between Ivorian president Gbagbo and the three rebel movements. Mario Giro from the Community of Sant’Egidio was also involved in the mediation effort. While the mediation efforts in previous years had been characterised by external pressure and the threat of sanctions, the third parties mediating at Ouagadougou did not exert any pressure on the conflict parties. The talks led to conclusion of the Ouagadougou Political Accord on 4 March 2007.
third_party: Burkina Faso; Community of Sant' Egidio; ECOWAS

description: After the signing of the agreement, Compaoré remained involved in the peace process through participating in the monitoring mechanisms for the implementation of agreement, as well as though brokering supplementary accords to the agreement. Other Burkinabe officials, including Djibril Bassolet, Burkina Faso’s security minister, were also actively participating in the peace process. Subsequent negotiations led to four complementary agreements. The First Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement was signed on 27 March 2007.
agreement_name: First Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: After the signing of the agreement, Compaoré remained involved in the peace process through participating in the monitoring mechanisms for the implementation of agreement, as well as though brokering supplementary accords to the agreement. Other Burkinabe officials, including Djibril Bassolet, Burkina Faso’s security minister, were also actively participating in the peace process. Subsequent negotiations led to four complementary agreements. The Second Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement and the Third Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement were both signed on 28 November 2007.
agreement_name: Second Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement; Third Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: The parties reached the Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement on 22 December 2008.
agreement_name: Fourth Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: In 2004, two rebel groups took up arms against the Government of Nigeria. One of these groups was the Niger Delta People’s Volunteer Force (NDPVF), which fought for territorial independence. The NDPVF was formed by ethnic Ijaws inhabiting the oil-rich Niger Delta. This group strived for Ijaw self-determination and their right to control – or at least benefit from – the vast oil resources near their homes. On 1 October 2004, the NDPVF and the government conducted a round of negotiations which led to a ceasefire. The Niger Delta Vigilante (NDV) was also involved in these negotiations and also signed the ceasefire. NDPVF leader Moujahid Asari Dokubo and NDV leader Ateke Tom promised “the disbandment of all militias and militant groups as well as total disarmament.”
The NDPVF and the Government of Nigeria conducted a round of negotiations in Yenagoa, the capital of Bayelsa state, in December 2007. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 6 December 2007.

On 5 January 1992, Transitional Prime Minister Cheiffou called on the FLAA to disarm and enter into negotiations. On 7 January 1992, the FLAA leadership replied that they were willing to enter into negotiations, but on the condition that the army would return to the barracks and that an independent inquiry on the armed violence with international observers would be set up. The conflict parties entered pre-negotiations without the involvement of any third party in May 1992. This led to the signing of a joint communique on 12 May 1992, which committed the parties to the creation of a favourable climate for effective negotiations, beginning with a temporary ceasefire. It was also agreed that both Algeria and France would act as mediators. France subsequently helped to obtain both sides’ commitment to peace talks.
A round of preliminary talks in March 1993, mediated by France, aimed at concluding a ceasefire and establishing an agenda for negotiations led to the signing of a ceasefire on 20 March 1993.

During subsequent secret talks between the rebels and the Government of Niger in Paris in June 1993, the government and the FLAA renewed, for another three months, the ceasefire reached in March. This round of secret negotiations continued and led to the signing of the Paris Agreement on 10 June 1993. However, one day later, on 11 June 1993, the Algerian-based military command of the FLAA issued a statement that it opposed the agreement concluded by the FLAA’s political wing. The FLAA factionalized between June and September 1993 into several splinter groups as a result of disagreements about the Paris Agreement. The ceasefire was largely adhered to between June and September 1993, although FLAA splinter groups occasionally attacked government targets. France withdrew as mediator in November 1993, citing the deadlock created by the rivalry between the FLAA and several of its splinter groups.

During the first half of 1997, Chad met UFRA representatives and convinced them to join the ongoing peace process with the FDR. As a result, the UFRA participated in peace talks, mediated by Algeria, Burkina Faso, Chad, France, and Libya.
third_party: France; Algeria; Burkina Faso; Chad; Libya

description: Another round of talks in which the UFRA participated took place during the last two weeks of November. Algerian, French and Burkinabe diplomats mediated these talks. The talks led to the signing of a ceasefire accord on 29 November 1997. On 8 June 1998, the UFRA handed over their last military equipment to the military authorities.

While MNJ repeatedly asked for a dialogue with the Government of Niger, the latter refused any mediation in 2007 and 2008, describing the rebels as mere criminals and bandits. In mid-February 2009, Nigerien president Mamadou Tandja requested Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi, chairman of the AU in 2009, to help find a settlement. Muammar al-Gaddafi accepted this request and in March mediated the release of five Niger soldiers and a gendarme who had been held by the MNJ. He subsequently mediated in a number of talks between government delegations and MNJ.
On 4 April 2009, another meeting was held in Tripoli, mediated by the Libyan ambassador to Niger.
After the Tripoli meeting, al-Gaddafi met with both the Government delegation and the MNJ delegation separately.

On 3 May 2009, Nigerien President Mamadou Tandja visited northern Niger for the first time in two years. During his visit to nothern Mali in early May 2009, Nigerien President Mamadou Tandja held talks with the MNJ, mediated by al-Gaddafi. After the first meeting Tandja promised amnesty to all Tuareg rebels if they disarmed. No response to the offer was available from the rebel side.
Talks subsequently continued in Agadez in early May 2009 and it was reported that issues such as the disarmament and reintegration of Touareg fighters were discussed.

MNJ and government representatives enagaged in another round of peace talks in Niamey, the capital of Niger, in mid-May 2009. Before the launch of the talks, MNJ published a statement saying that the group would not disarm until talks were held on its political demands. The announcement went on to say that it found the government’s proposed scenario of “confining (rebel) combatants, disarming them and later granting them a general amnesty” as “incredible and unacceptable.” MNJ then went on to call for a clearly defined timetable for the negotiations. At the talks, it was reported that the parties had agreed to set up a technical committee to continue working on some of the core issues, including the rebels’ demands and how to go about disarming the rebel fighters. The negotiations between the MNJ and the government of Niger led to a ceasefire agreement on 15 May 2009.

In June 2009, a MNJ splinter group announced that it had agreed for its fighters to be disarmed. However, this deal did not involve the MNJ. New talks between the conflict parties, without the involvement of a third party, were held in Niamey in July. Following confusion in MNJ ranks in September, a number of MNJ fighters, together with MNJ leader Agaly Alambo, participated in a peace ceremony in Sabha in southern Libya, at which dozens of MNJ fighters officially lay down their arms. The ceremony was initially rejected by one faction of MNJ, but by the end of the month it appeared as if the whole group stood behind the decision to end the armed struggle. A couple of weeks later the state of emergency in northern Niger was formally withdrawn by a presidential decree.

The Front Populaire pour la Libération de l’Azaouad (FPLA) (English: Popular Liberation Front of Azawad) was a Tuareg rebel group that broke away from the Mouvement Populaire de Libération de l’Azaouad (MPLA) (English: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Azawad) after the MPLA signed the Tamanrasset Agreement in January 1991. The FPLA was intally led by Rhissa ag Sidi Mohamed. The FPLA took part in the Mouvements et Fronts Unifiés de l’Azawad (MFUA) (English: United Movements and Fronts of Azawad), a rebel umbrella organization set up to form a united front during negotiations with the government. Algeria mediated between the government and the MFUA in two rounds of negotiations in January and March 1992 respectively.

The FPLA took part in the Mouvements et Fronts Unifiés de l’Azawad (MFUA) (English: United Movements and Fronts of Azawad), a rebel umbrella organization set up to form a united front during negotiations with the government. Algeria mediated between the government and the MFUA in two rounds of negotiations in January and March 1992 respectively.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. FPLA’s representative in MFUA was Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine, who was a relative of Rhissa. Rhissa and Zeidane disagreed about whether or not to sign the National Pact when it was on the table. Rhissa continued to refuse to sign, but Zeidane travelled to Bamako to sign it on behalf of the FPLA. However, with Zeidane unable to exert influence over the fighters on the ground at this point in time, attacks on government targets continued.

The Alliance des patriotes pour un Congo libre et souverain (APCLS) (English: Alliance of the People for a Free and Sovereign Congo) is a Mai Mai militia, predominantly Hunde, active in the Masisi territory of the Nord Kivu Province in the DRC, largely in opposition to Tutsi ethnic groups. The APCLS is led by Janvier Buingo Karairi. It was founded in 2006 and as part of PARECO-Hunde, but split after the Goma Agreement signed on 23 January 2008. The relationship between the APCLS and the Government of the DRC has varied between partnership and animosity. In 2012 and 2013, the APCLS was a key supporter of the national army in repelling M23, which consisted mostly of Tutsi fighters and was supported by the Rwandan government. However, after defeating M23, the government forces began to target other non-state armed groups to regain state control. This led to clashes between government forces and the APCLS from late 2012 onwards. Local leaders approached surrounding rebel groups to meet for negotiations. On 18 December 2012 the ACPLS with the Congolese government met with other rebel groups (Mayi-Mayi, Nyatura and Raia Mutomboki) and negotiated a ceasefire, as well as an alliance between themselves.

In January 2013, attempts were made by the Government of the DRC to integrate APCLS into the national army. Government negotiators and APCLS leader Janvier Bwingo Karairi negotiated over the possible integration of APCLS forces in January 2013. Although a number of fighters from APCLS reported for integration, most rejected integration and continued to carry out attacks on civilians in parts of Masisi territory. UN Radio says discussions over integration broke down over the murder of an APCLS officer and attempts by the APCLS to attack ethnic Tutsi living in a displacement camp, who they alleged were hiding weapons.

After being dormant for some time, the APCLS made a resurgence in 2016. On 23 August 2016, APCLS and militia group Mai-Mai Nyatura concluded a peace agreement in the presence of Congolese government officials in Muhanga in which they agreed to hand over their weapons to national army on the condition that they would be provided guarantees for their security, including amnesty. Deputies from North Kiva, representing the Government of the DRC, were involved in these negotiations. The agreement was mediated by two elected officials of the Masisi, assisted by the police and the security services.

After a disputed election in 2010, with a round of elections held on 31 October 2010 and a second round of elections on 28 November 2010, a protracted political standoff between the President Gbagbo and the internationally recognised president-elect Alassane Ouattara emerged. On 4 December 2010, the Chairperson of the AU Commission, Jean Ping, requested former South African President Thabo Mbeki to travel to Abidjan to mediate a peaceful outcome of the dispute. Although Mbeki, together with the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General Choi Young-jin, talked to the disputants, Mbeki failed to resolve the crisis.

After Mbeki’s failed attempt, Kenya’s Prime Minister Raila Odinga was mandated by Ping to lead the monitoring of the situation in Ivory Coast and bolster the efforts being undertaken to end the conflict.

The Coalition Nationale pour la Souveraineté du Congo (CNSPC), also known as the Parti pour l’action et la reconstruction du Congo-Forces armées Alléluia/Yakutumba (PARC-FAAL) from 2011 to 2017 and also known as Mai Mai Yakutumba named after its military leader William Amuri Yakutumba. Created in 2007, Yakutumba capitalized upon local grievances, in particular within the Bembe community. Yakutumba managed to co-opt numerous smaller Mai-Mai groups in the Fizi region into coalitions under his de facto leadership, including the Bwasakala and Bavon Mai-Mai groups. A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held in Goma in January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abbé Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference, the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference was produced. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The conference led to the conclusion of an immediate ceasefire through the conclusion of the the Acte d’Engagement, Nord Kivu on 23 January 2008. This agreement was signed by Yakutumba, along with other Mayi Mayi movements.

In March 2012, the rebels sent a delegation to Bukavu to talk with the DRC Government, but the negotiations failed. In April 2012, a mutiny broke out among government troops in Fizi and Uvira territories, which proved to be the precursor to the M23 rebellion.

In late 2012, the Congolese government, intent on preventing the M23 from gaining allies, approached  Yakutumba again to reconcile. During negotiations in December 2012, the CNSPC leadership and the government negotiators came to an agreement that CNSPC fighters would be integrated into the national army.On 5 February 2013, Yakutumba began sending some of his troops to an integration camp in Sebele, approximately 30 kilometer south of Baraka. Around 250 troops gathered there very soon, which amounted to well over half of the estimated numbers of the CNSPC. However, in spite of the government providing equipment and money to help regroup his troops, most of Yakutumba’s men left to take up positions in Ubwari and in nearby mining areas. The Congolese army subsequently declared the process a failure and terminated the integration process.
Another round of negotiations mediated by Turkey was held in Istanbul from 16 to 19 January 2014.
The two sides met for peace talks mediated by Ethiopia in Addis Ababa in early April 2013.

The conflict parties also engaged in a round of negotiations, mediated by Turkey, in Ankara on 13 April 2013. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the Ankara Communique, which stipulated, among others, intelligence-sharing, cooperation in fighting terrorism, extremism and piracy, and in combatting the illegal dumping of poisonous materials in Somali waters. The conflict parties also committed themselves to further negotiations.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Turkey took place from 7 to 9 July 2013 in Istanbul. The talks in Istanbul did not discuss the contested issue of Somaliland’s sovereignty, but did result in an agreement allowing Somaliland to receive international aid directly from donors and to enjoy full control of its airspace.
A new round of negotiations was held in Djibouti on 21 December 2014. The conflict parties reaffirmed all the points of agreement reached in earlier negotiations.

The South Sudan Democratic Movement/Army (SSDM/A) - Cobra Faction has its roots in the SSDM/A, though it did not form as a splinter faction. The SSDM/A - Cobra Faction was established by David Yau Yau in 2013, a year after the SSDM/A forces had been integrated into the national army following mediation by the South Sudan Council of Churches. In 2011, the South Sudanese government had offered a presidential amnesty to Yau Yau and his fighters in return to their integration in the government army. However, this peace was short-lived and Yau Yau defected to Sudan in April 2012. Sudan’s National Intelligence and Security Services facilitated repeated airdrops of weapons and ammunition across different locations throughout 2012 and 2013. Yau Yau’s defection to Sudan escalated into a full-blown insurgency in 2013, with many Murle joining the rebellion in response to the government’s disarmament campaign. The government issued an ultimatum to respond to an amnesty on 5 June 2013. However, armed clashes between the conflict parties continued. Yau Yau and his Murle fighters objected to mediation by the South Sudan Council of Churches because Archbishop Daniel Deng being a Dinka Bor. In the first half of 2013, a mediation effort was conducted by a British defense contractor of AEGIS Defense Services (UK), James Ellery, hired by the South Sudanese government. This mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery’s effort, providing both logistics and security. Ellery met with Yau Yau six time at various place in Pibor county, but Yau Yau did not agree to official negotiations. Governments forces launched a military operation on 5 March in spite of efforts by the UNMISS leadership to persuade the government to refrain from such an operation. In addition, UNMISS flew Ellery to Pibor county on 13 March to get Yau Yau’s consent to a 48-hour ceasefire, but this effort failed.

The Ellery mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery’s effort, providing both logistics and security.

The Ellery mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery’s effort, providing both logistics and security.
A mediation attempt to initiate official negotiations by local Murle elites and interlocutors close to the Juba government on 19 and 20 May 2013 also failed.

A mediation team of three nationally respected church officials from Equatoria – namely Catholic bishop Paride Taban, along with Bishop Paul Benjamin Yugusuk of the Episcopal Church and Bishop Arkanjelo Wani Lemi of the African Inland Church – was initiated at a meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013. This mediation effort, dubbed the Church Leaders’ Mediation Initiative (CLMI), was supported by the Dutch NGO PAX and also received logistical support from Norwegian Chruch Aid and UNMISS. During the meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013, the bishops agreed with representatives of the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction to enter into negotiations with the government. With President Kiir’s blessing, the bishops and the Presbyterian Murle pastor Orozu Lokine subsequently met with Yau Yau in Kongor in September 2013. The onset of the civil war between the South Sudanese government and the Sudan People’s Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) strengthened the government’s commitment to a deal with Yau Yau as the government needed soldiers to fight the SPLM/A-IO, pushing the government to make concessions in favor of Yau Yau at the expense of key government actors in Jonglei state.

The peace process between the government and the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction was brought to Addis Ababa in January 2014. This mediation effort was conducted by the South Sudanese Church Leaders Mediation Initiative (CLMI). Hizkias Assefa, an Ethiopian professor and mediator, acted as the chief mediator during this peace process. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 January 2014.
Another ceasefire agreement was signed on 30 January 2014.

A peace agreement was concluded on 9 May 2014. This peace agreement, often referred to as the Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) Peace Agreement, established a special ‘Greater Pibor’ region for the Murle people in the state.
agreement_name: Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) Peace Agreement

description: On 5 June 2011, the SPLM/A-North clashed for the first time with the Government of Sudan in Kadugli and Um Durein, two towns located in South Kordofan. On 9 June 2011, the SPLM/A-North expressed that it fought to remove the central Government in Khartoum. Abdel-Aziz Al-Hilu, a leading figure in the movement and the former deputy Governor of South Kordofan, stated the SPLM/A-North waged a “battle for dignity to accomplish the fundamental change in the centre.” The conflict in South Kordofan and Blue Nile can be seen as a continuation of the civil war between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A between 1983 and 2005. While fighters from these two areas joined the SPLM/A rebellion as early as 1984. The Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) concluded in 2005 stipulated a referendum on independence for southern Sudan, but this referendum did not apply to South Kordofan and Blue Nile. This provides the background to the SPLM/A-North rebellion. After fighting had started in June, the armed conflict quickly spread to other towns and villages in South Kordofan. In September, fighting also started in the state of Blue Nile, which is located east of South Kordofan, but the fighting in South Kordofan was more intense. The SPM/A-North was supported by the Government of South Sudan. In early June, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel on Sudan (AUHIP) led by former South African president Thabo Mbeki initiated mediated negotiations to end the fighting. SPLM/A-North chairman Malik Agar negotiated for the SPLM/A-North and Ali Nafi for the Sudanese government.This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire on 16 June 2011. Although the conflict parties had signed the ceasefire agreement and were engaged in negotiations, fighting continued throughout June 2011.

Nevertheless, negotiations in Addis Ababa, mediated by Mbeki, led to the conclusion of an agreement for comprehensive political and security arrangements in the border states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan on 28 June 2011, referred to as the Addis Ababa Agreement. This agreement was signed by Presidential Bashir’s aide Nafie Ali Nafie and SPLM/A-North leader Malik Agar. In spite of the conclusion of this agreement, fighting continued. On 7 July 2011, the government backed out of the agreement with SPLM/A-North.

By the end of August 2011, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated talks between President Bashir and Agar. However, the talks did not produce any tangible results. The government announced a unilateral ceasefire for South Kordofan on 23 August 2011, but fighting continued. In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army from 2011 onwards. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SPLM/A-North are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.

In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union’s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. A first round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP took solely place between the SPLM/A-North and the Government of the Sudan in Addis Ababa on 26 July 2012. These negotiations focused on political and security issues underlying the continuing conflict in Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan States. The talks were conducted indirectly via the AUHIP, with both sides setting preconditions for engaging in direct talks. The Government of the Sudan insisted that the SPLM/A-North would disengage from South Sudan, as well made it clear that it opposed the return to the Agreement of 28 June 2011.  On 16 September 2012, the AUHIP submitted a draft proposal for a political solution based on the Agreement of 28 June 2011, reflecting views of the conflict parties and the “changed circumstances and current realities on the ground.”  Neither party accepted this agreement.
The AU mediated a round of peace talks between the SPLM-North and the Sudanese government on a political solution to the conflict from 23 to 27 April 2013, but these talks ended without agreement.

At the start of a round of negotiations on 25 February 2014, the Sudanese government accepted the draft framework agreement put forward by AUHIP to cease hostilities and deliver humanitarian aid to civilians in Sudan’s ‘Two Areas’ of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, but negotiations between the SPLM/A-N and the government were suspended on 2 March 2014 because the conflict parties disagreed on how the resolve the conflict.
The AU mediated another round of negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan on 22 April 2014, but this round of negotiations also failed.

On 7 July 2015, Secretary–General of the SPLM/A-N Yasir Arman stated that the SPLM/A-N would not continue peace negotiations from where the last round of AU-led peace talks stopped. On 3 August 2015, President Omar al-Bashir met with AU chief mediator Thabo Mbeki to discuss peace in Blue Nile and South Kordofan states. The meeting between Mbeki and al-Bashir did not lead to a new date for the resumption of negotiations on the two areas. The Government of Sudan and the SPLM-North engaged in direct negotiations mediated by the AU between 19 and 23 November 2015. This round of negotiations focused on security arrangements.

In December 2015, the Sudanese government and SPLM/A-North expressed to the AUHIP their willingness to sign a comprehensive agreement. An informal round of peace talks was subsequently held in Addis Ababa from 16 to 18 December 2015. However, this round of talks did not lead to an agreement, as the parties disagreed about whether the SPLM/A-North should be allowed to keep its troops. The conflict parties and the mediation team agreed to resume discussions in January 2016.

A government attack on the SPLM/A-North in Aroum on 23 January 2016 led SPLM/A-North officials to publicly question the government’s commitment to establishing peace. In late 2016, the AUHIP called upon the SPLM/A-North to review their positions on the talks on the Two Areas. The SPLM/A-N insisted on a provision allowing humanitarian access through Asosa in Ethiopia, but the Sudanese government rejected such a provision. In March 2017, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-North (SPLM/A-N) split into two factions, resulting in several clashes. While there were many calls to engage in negotiations throughout 2017 and 2018, the conflict parties did not engage in peace talks. The split was a result of long-simmering ethnic and political–military tensions within the SPLM/A-N in Blue Nile. While the Uduk, Berta, and Burun had made up the majority of the SPLM/A’s 10th Division during war between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government between 1983 and 2005, members of the Ingessana tribe assumed increasingly more power within the rebel group from 2012 onwards. This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the non-Ingessana tribes. Tensions were temporarily put on hold due to intense fighting between the SPLM/A-N and government forces throughout 2015-2016, but following a unilateral ceasefire issued by the Sudanese government on 18 June 2016 tensions escalated. In March 2017, SPLM/A-N deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu publicly released a resignation letter. Abdelaziz al-Hilu accused Agar of not fully representing the entire SPLM/A-N movement in the peace process led by the AU, particularly with regard to the issue of self-determination of the Nuba Mountains. Al-Hilu’s letter essentially forced the members of the SPLM/A-N to choose between himself and chairman Malik Agar of the Ingessana tribe. The Nuba Mountains Liberation Council (NMLC) subsequently passed resolutions that removed Arman as the SPLM/A-N’s lead negotiator with African Union High-Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), as well as put the NMLC in power of both South Kordofan and Blue Nile. Moreover, many senior non-Ingessana leaders began to publicly voice support for al-Hilu and the NMLC. In April 2017, almost all of the non-Ingessana Blue Nile Liberation Council (BNLC) members declared their support for the NMLC decision to dismiss Arman as the SPLM/A-N AUHIP lead negotiator. Accordingly, although the deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu broke away from the rebel group led by chairman Malik Agar, the UCDP codes the SPLM/A-N led by Malik Agar (SPLM/A-N-MA) as the splinter faction because he was endorsed by the NMLC and most of the BNLC.  Preparations for official negotiations between the SPLM/A-North and the Sudanese government continued in spite of this split. SPLM/A-North representatives met with mediators from the AUHIP in Addis Ababa in late August 2017. In late September 2017, Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) special envoy for Sudan, Lesane Johannes, discussed details for the resumption of formal peace talks between the SPLM-North and the government with Sudanese Presidential adviser Ibrahim Mahmoud. However, these pre-negotiations did not lead to formal negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan were held in 2017.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: On 30 January 2018, the SPLM/A-North announced an extension of the unilateral ceasefire at South Kordofan and Blue Nile areas for four month starting on 1 February 2018. Pre-negotiations resumed in Addis Ababa on 3 February 2018, but the talks broke down on 4 February because the government refused the SPLM/A-North’s demand for greater autonomy.

Another round of exploratory peace talks was held between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-North in Addis Ababa and Johannesburg between 19 and 30 October 2018, but both sides continued to disagree on the terms of resuming official peace talks. Nevertheless, on 3 November 2018, the Sudanese government agreed to the proposal of SPLM/A-North to appoint South Sudanese President Salva Kiir as the chief mediator of future negotiations.
AU representatives met with different factions of the SPLM/A-North in Addis Ababa on 17 and 26 November respectively to prepare for official peace talks.

Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SPLM/A-North. Both the SRF and the SPLM/A-North participated in negotiations in Juba in September 2019, which led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF, but the SPLM/A refused to sign this declaration.

A third round of negotiations in Juba took place between 10 December and 14 February 2020. This round of negotiations consisted of five separate tracks covering Darfur, the Two Areas of Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan, and central, east and north Sudan . While the SPLM/A-North led by Malik Agar signed a ceasefire with the Sudanese government during these peace talks, the SPLM/A-North refused to sign an agreement.

The Republic of South Sudan refers to the autonomous republic of South Sudan, as it existed between the referendum on independence between 9 and 15 January 2011 and South Sudan gaining independence on 9 July 2011. The status of Abyei was one of the most difficult issues to solve in the negotiations leading to the signing of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA), but the parties reached agreement about the status in 2005. The Sudanese federal Minister of Interior and the Minister of Interior of the Republic of South Sudan engaged in a round of negotiations on Abyei in January 2011, which led to the conclusion of the Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei on 17 January 2011. The agreement allowed the return of displaced people under the protection of Joint Integrated Units of north-south law enforcement and supervised by the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The agreement also stipulated the opening of corridors for cattle and regulated the carrying of arms among misseriya herdsmen.
agreement_name: Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei

description: Another round of negotiations in March 2011 led to the signing of another agreement on Abyei on 4 March 2011. This agreement – the Follow-up to the Kadugli Agreements Agreement between the Republic of the Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan on the Demarcation of the Boundary – reconfirmed the parties’ commitment to the Kadguli agreements. The agreement requested the UN to ensure implementation of the agreement. However, on 27 of April 2011, President Bashir stated that “Abyei is part of north Sudan and will remain of the north. We do not say this just here. We say it in many forums and occasions.” Bashir also threatened to wage war against the Republic of South Sudan if they attempted to annex Abyei to the South Sudan. On 1 May 2011, a heavily armed Sudanese army convoy entered Abyei in a clear breach of what was agreed upon in the CPA. SPLM/A forces subsequently ambush this convoy. This triggered renewed fighting between the Sudanese forces and the SPLM/A.
agreement_name: Follow-up to the Kadugli Agreements Agreement between the Republic of the Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan on the Demarcation of the Boundary

description: The AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP), led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, mediates a round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A in May 2011. This led to the drafting of a Joint Position Paper on Border Security, which forms the basis for a Common Border Zone and creates a Joint Political and Security Mechanism.
The AUHIP mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties on post-referendum issues on 13 June 2011.

Another round of negotiations on the status of Abyei, mediated by the AUHIP, resulted in the conclusion of the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area on 20 June 2011. The agreement stipulated a devolution of power to the Abyei Area Administration, with oversight from the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee. In addition, the agreement called for the demilitarization of the Area with the exception of the UN-authorized and Ethiopian-provided Interim Security Force for Abyei (ISFA). The parties also reaffirmed their commitment to resolve the final status of Abyei peacefully, with mediation support from the AUHIP. Although the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area stipulated, among others that both the SAF and the SPLA needed to be withdrawn from the Abyei Area, the SAF did not give up their control over Abyei.
agreement_name: Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area

description: During a round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP, on 29 June 2011, the conflict parties formally signed an agreement that drew on the Joint Position Paper on Border Security. South Sudan gained its independence on 9 July 2011. All peace efforts after this date are coded as negotiations between Sudan and South Sudan.

Fighting soon erupted again. South Sudan became independent on 9 July 2011. This was the result of a referendum held six months earlier, in which an overwhelming majority of the South Sudanese population voted for independence. The Forces of George Athor subsequently renamed themselves into the South Sudan Democratic Movement/Army (SSDM/A). The new regime in Juba was mainly challenged by the SSDM/A led by George Athor in the Jonglei province. A round of negotiations between George Athor and South Sudanese President Salva Kiir on 20 November in Kenya, mediated by the South Sudan Council of Churches, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. In spite of this agreement, Athor stepped up the SSDM/A’s armed attacks on government targets in early December 2011. Athor was killed on 19 December 2011, reportedly while entering South Sudan from Uganda. Peter Kuol Chol Awan became the new leader of the SSDM/A.

Awan entered secret negotiations in January 2012. This resulted in the signing of a peace agreement on 27 February 2012, after which Awan travelled to Juba and surrendered to the SPLA. However, Johnson Olony, the leader of the SSDM/A-Upper Nile faction, rejected the agreement and kept fighting the Government of South Sudan.

The SSDM/A led by Olony accepted a ceasefire and an amnesty by the government following mediation by the Shilluk reth (King) in June 2013. Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013.
Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013.

Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Major General Johnson Olony into the government forces. The SSDM/A remained loyal to the government until early 2015, when they defected to the SPLM/A-IO.

South Sudan became independent on 9 July 2011. This was the result of a referendum held six months earlier, in which an overwhelming majority of the South Sudanese population voted for independence. Following South Sudan’s independence, President Salva Kiir offered an amnesty to various armed groups fighting in the south, including the SSLM/A. This led to a round of secret negotiations between the new South Sudanese government and the SSLM/A in late July 2011. On 3 August 2011, SSLM/A spokersperson Bol Gatkouth announced: “We are declaring a ceasefire and we are also accepting the amnesty offered by the president as the basis of talks with the government of South Sudan.”

When it became clear that few Nuer fighters would join his rebellion and that overthrowing the state government of Tabang Deng in Unity province seemed unlikely, Peter Gadet, until then the leader of SSLM/A, negotiated his way back in and joined the Government of South Sudan. Following negotiations in early January 2012, President Kiir issued a decree on 6 January 2012, reinstating Peter Gadet to his position in Sudan People’s Liberation Army (SPLA). The SPLA functions as the government forces of South Sudan. On 15 February 2012, the registration of the SSLM/A into the SPLA was completed.

Yet, other parts of the SSLM/A led by Bapiny Monytuiel continued their rebellion with the support from Khartoum. The SSLM/A led by Bapiny Monytuiel signed an agreement with the government in April 2013.

Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Lieutenant General Bapiny Monytuil of the SSLM/A into the government army. The leadership council of the SSLM/A issued a statement on 27 November 2013 expressing support for the President’s announcement.

In 2011, popular protests against the regime of incumbent leader Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi in Libya quickly evolved into an armed uprising led by the National Transitional Council (NTC). UN Security Council Resolution 1973 established a no-fly zone, which came into effect on 17 March 2011. At the 265th meeting of the AU Peace and Security Council, held in Addis Ababa on 10 March 2011, the AU established a High Level ad hoc Committee on Libya. The Committee consisted of the AU Commission Chairperson, Jean Ping, as well as five countries represented by their respective presidents: South Africa (Jacob Zuma), Mauritania (Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz), Mali (then under Amadou Toumani Toure), Congo Brazzavile (Denis Sassou Nguesso) and Uganda (Yoweri Museveni). The Committee was mandated to “(i) to engage with all the parties in Libya and continuously assess the evolution of the situation on the ground; (ii) to facilitate an all-inclusive dialogue between the Libyan parties on the appropriate reforms to be carried out; and (iii) to engage AU’s partners, in particular the League of Arab States (LAS), the Organisation of the Islamic Conference (OIC), the European Union (EU) and the United Nations, to facilitate coordination of efforts and seek their support for the early resolution of the crisis.”  On 17 March 2011, a week after the creation of the AU High Level ad hoc Committee on Libya, the United Nations Security Council gave the go-ahead for military intervention into Libya. The Libyan government announced a ceasefire the next day in response to the international intervention. The Libyan government would later recommit to a unilateral ceasefire on 20 and 25 March 2011, but government forces continued to conduct offensive operations. On 28 March 2011, the government also declared a cessation of hostilities in response to fighting in Misrata with NTC, but this ceasefire did not lead to any changes on the ground. Jacob Zuma headed an AU mission to Tripoli on 10 April 2011 to talk to President Gaddafi and present him with a peace plan. The next day, the AU mission consulted with the NTC leadership in Benghazi. Since the AU peace proposal did not include Gaddafi’s departure, the NTC rejected the peace plan and rejected to participate in direct peace talks to discuss the proposal.
third_party: AU; Congo Brazzavile; Mali; Mauritania; Uganda; South Africa

description: The AU convened an extraordinary meeting on 25 May 2011, at which the leaders called for a ceasefire followed by mediation. Five days later, South African President Zuma flew to Tripoli to consult with al-Gaddafi, but the Libyan leader refused to step down from power.

In June 2011, the Russian chess master and chairman of the international chess federation, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, was sent on several official missions to Libya by Russia. He met with both President Gaddafi and with the rebels, but did not manage to conclude an agreement or initiate official negotiations.
Russia’s Special Envoy Mikhail Margelov tried to initiate talks a week after Ilymzihinov’s visit, but did not manage to talk to al-Gaddafi.
Meanwhile, on 7 July 2011, a Chinese representative Chen Xiaodong met with NTC in Benghazi to discuss the conclusion of a ceasefire.

Another round of negotiations in the week of 16 July 2011 was conducted in Tunisia between the Libyan government and the United States, but these talks proved unsuccessful as the latter demanded al-Gaddafi’s resignation and the former rejected this.

In August 2011, the Libyan capital Tripoli came under control of the NTC. In parallel to fighting in Bani Walid and Sirte, the NTC proposed a ceasefire during negotiations with Gaddafi’s represenatives in early September. However, Gaddafi’s forces continued to fight. One month later, in October 2011, Gaddafi was found and excuted in Sirte.

On 24 November 2012, the International Conference for the Great Lakes Region led by Uganda mediated a ceasefire between the two parties. Following M23 taking control of Goma, the Ugandan military, which was in communication with the M23 rebels, announced that the M23 leadership had agreed to a plan drawn up by regional heads of state for the rebels to leave Goma within 48 hours, with no conditions. However, the M23 leader in December 2012, Jean Marie Runiga, subsequently told reporters in Goma that his forces would only withdraw if President Kabila would hold national talks, release political prisoners, and dissolve the electoral commission, a body widely accused of delivering Kabila a second term in a flawed 2011 election. These demands were refused by the Congolese government. Nevertheless, on 1 December 2012, the M23 rebels left Goma. Later in December 2012, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR), with the support of other international and regional partners, was successful in facilitating the opening of a dialogue between the DRC and M23.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: Holding ICGLR Presidency, Uganda facilitated negotiations between the Government of the DRC and M23 in Kampala between 9 and 21 December. The Ugandan Defence Minister, Crispus Kiyonga, acted as mediator during the talks. This round of negotiations would prove to be the first in a series of negotiations mediated by Uganda in which the ICGLR provided for the overall institutional framing for the peace process. On 20 December 2012, the peace talks stalled after the Government rejected M23’s demand for a ceasefire before continuing negotiations. The round ended with only rules of procedure and a provisional agenda agreed. The first round of talks did not lead to any agreement and were postponed until 4 January 2013. In addition, in December 2012, as a result of the UN expert report, M23 was listed for sanctions and a number of M23 leaders subjected to individual sanctions, including travel bans and asset freezes.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: Scheduled for 4 January 2013, formal peace talks mediated by Uganda did not resume because of a disagreement on the issue of the conclusion of a formal ceasefire, which the Congolese government had rejected. On 8 January 2013, at the start of a second round of peace negotiations, M23 declared a unilateral ceasefire. On 16 January 2013, the Government and M23 formally adopted the agenda of the talks and a framework agreement was signed. On 18 January 2013, the DRC government rejected the groups’ “unconstitutional” demands such as the formation of a transitional government, for the results of elections in 2011 to be scrapped, for the resignation of all provincial governors, provincial parliament and senate members, and for the introduction of a federal system of government. On 21 January 2013, both delegations completed their respective evaluations of the implementation of the 23 March 2009 agreement. A document was produced by the conflict parties in February 2013 which evaluated the agreement between the Government of the DRC and the CNDP concluded on 23 March 2009./ This document concluded that twenty-three of the thirty-five points of the agreement had not been implemented as they should have been implemented and that twelve points had not been implemented at all. On 28  March 2013, the United Nations Security Council authorized the deployment of an intervention brigade in its resolution 2098 within MONUSCO to carry out targeted offensive operations, with or without the Congolese national army, against armed groups such as M23 that threaten peace in eastern DRC.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: On 20 May 2013, M23 attacked government forces in an effort to block the deployment of the intervention brigade. On 23 May, M23 declared a unilateral ceasefire and again on 30 August 2013. On 5 September 2013, the ICGLR demanded that negotiations between the Congolese government and M23 resume within three days and conclude within 14 days, at most. Talks resumed in Kampala on 10 September 2013.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: The Kampala talks broke down again on 21 October 2013. However, soon after these talks, the M23 leadership called upon their field commanders to lay down arms and discuss political solutions to the conflict. On 5 November, the M23 leadership called for a ceasefire, but government forces launched an assault on M23 rebel position in the east of the country the next day.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: The following day, on 6 November 2013, M23 issued a document in which it stated that it had “decided from this day to end its rebellion and instead to pursue its goals through purely political means.” On 7 November 2013, Sultani Makenga, the leader of M23, surrendered with around 1,500 M23 fighters in Mgahinga National Park, Uganda. They were subsequently held in Kisoro. On 11 November 2013, the conflict parties negotiated with the aim to sign a political agreement to put an end to the conflict, but Kinshasa refused to sign a peace agreement following the military victory and preferred to issue a declaration. Kinshasa rejected a general amnesty for pardons on an individual basis. Only M23 fighters that were not guilty of war crimes could rejoin the Congolese Army or police.Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni subsequently mediated between the Government of the DRC and the M23 rebels. This mediation effort led to three separate declarations, of which neither carried both parties’ signature. These three declarations were combined in an overall declaration – referred to as the Nairobi Declaration – signed in Nairobi by Yoweri Museveni, President of Uganda and chair of ICGLR, and Joyce Banda, the President of Malawi and Chair of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) on 12 December 2013. The three separate documents pertained to M23’s commitment to end the rebellion to become a political party; a partial amnesty for M23 members for the rebellion, but not for international war crimes; and demobilization of former M23 members.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region; Uganda

description: Algeria opened an unofficial process, bringing together the conflict parties several times during the year.
The CMA met in Algiers with Malian Foreign Minister Soumeylou Boubeye Maiga on 2 February 2012, but this did not lead to an agreement.

On 4 December 2012, CMA and Ansar Dine again met for a round of talks with Compaoré in Ouagadougou. The conflict parties agreed during this round of negotiations to end hostilities with the government.

In late 2012, Islamist groups started moving south towards Bamako. This promted the Government of Mali to request French military support. On 11 January 2013, France launched Operation Serval. The peace process between the Government of Mali and the CMA continued in spite of this intervention, with a round of negotiations taking place in Bamako on 13 February 2013.

Another round of mediated talks mediated by Blaise Compaoré was held in Ouagadougou between 17 and 19 June 2013 and brought together CMA and Ansar Dine representatives. This round of negotiations focused on establishing an agenda for peace talks and led to the Ouagadougou Accord on 18 June 2013, which was a preliminary agreement that stipulated an immediate ceasefire, as well as commits the conflict parties to create the conditions for holding presidential elections and outlined the principles for future inclusive peace talks.

Between February and June 2014, consultations were held in Algeria, intended to bring together the many disparate groupings of the North under one unified front. MINUSMA facilitated three short workshops with representatives of the Government of Mali, local authorities, armed groups and civil society in Algiers between 3 February and early March 2014. The conflict parties reaffirmed their willingness during these workshops to take part in an inclusive dialogue to reach a comprehensive settlement of the armed conflict. These workshops also resulted the signing of a technical document on 18 February by all present. This document outlined the steps that needed to be taken to further the cantonment process. UN Security Council Resolution 2100 (2013), a February visit by its members, as well as the Ouagadougou Agreement informed the agreement’s timeframe for the cantonment process.
On 18 May 2014, a MINUSMA delegation led by mediator Major General Jean Bosco Kazura attempted to mediate a ceasefire between CMA and the government in response to a recent episode of fighting.

UN envoy Albert Koenders and AU chairman President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz of Mauritania managed to mediate a ceasefire between the rebels and government – the Accord de cessez-le-feu – in another round of negotiations in Kidal on 23 May 2014. This agreement committed the Government of Mali and the CMA to immediately cease hostilities throughout Mali, as well as reconfirmed the preliminary agreement of Ouagadougou that had been signed on 18 June 2013.

On 9 June 2014, the CMA signed the Algiers Declaration in Algiers, stating their interest in collaborating with the government in a peace process. On 16 June 2014, a high-level consultation on Mali attended by government representatives from the Sahel region mandated Algeria as the official mediator between the Bamako government and the armed opposition groups in northern Mali. Concerted efforts by Algeria, the UN, the AU, ECOWAS, and other regional governments besides Algeria subsequently led to the launch of formal peace negotiations between the armed groups and the Government of Mali. The first round of official negotiations in what came to be know as the Algiers peace process between the Government of Mali and CMA took place from 14 to 24 July 2014 in Algiers. The talks were supported by a mediation team led by Algeria – comprising the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the OIC, the EU, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, and Chad. This round of negotiations focused on the security situation in northern Mali and the formulation of a road map for negotiations. The first round of negotiations led to the signing of the Feuille de route des negotiations dans le cadre du processus d’Alger, which includes a ceasefire and a road map for negotiations in the context of the Algiers peace process. The road map reaffirmed the need to respect Mali’s territorial integrity and secularism. The road map also provided a framework for future negotiations. Negotiations would focus on four distinct thematic areas: political and institutional issues; defence and security issues; economic development, social, and cultural issues; and reconciliation, justice and humanitarian issues. In the subsequent rounds of negotiations, the parties negotiated on the basis of this road map.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN
agreement_name: Feuille de route des negotiations dans le cadre du processus d’Alger

description: A second round of negotiations mediated by Algeria and the wider mediation team took place in Algiers between 1 September and 23 September 2014.
