The mediation team shuttled between government representatives and the CMA negotiation team during this round of negotiations. Both the conflict parties agreed on the territorial integrity of Mali, but the government delegation was only willing to consider “enhanced regionalization”, while the CMA called for the establishment of a federal system in Mali.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN

description: On 18 October 2014, the mediation team and government representatives from the region enagaged in another round of negotiations with a high-level meeting to review and validate a document that had been drafted based on discussions during the second round of negotiations, entitled Elements for a Peace and Reconciliation Agreement in Mali. The third round of negotiations in Algiers was held between 21 and 23 October 2014. The conflict parties discussed the draft document of principles during this round of talks.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN

description: The fourth round of negotiations was held between 4 and 27 November 2014. The mediation team met separately with the parties to discuss the draft document of principles. From 22 to 24 November 2014, the mediation team organized another round of interactive dialogues between the government delegation and the CMA negotiators. On 26 November 2014, the mediation team presented the parties with a slightly revised text that included three annexes and was renamed the Draft Peace and Reconciliation Agreement in Mali. On 27 November 2014, the negotiation teams returned to Mali for consultation with their respective constituencies, with the understanding that their senior leaders would reconvene in Algiers in January 2015.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN

description: The fifth round of peace talks, which was supposed to start in January 2015, was stalled due to military clashes. On 9 February, CMA and the government agreed to a ceasefire as they prepared for this round.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN

description: Negotiations eventually were held between 11 February and 1 March 2015 in Algiers. This round of talks led to drafting of a peace agreement, but the CMA negotiation team requested additional time to consult with its constituency before signing the agreement.
third_party: Algeria; AU; Burkina Faso; Chad; ECOWAS; EU; Mauritania; Niger; OIC; UN

description: Algerian Minister of Foreign Affairs Ramtane Lamamra subsequently shuttled between the Government of Mali and the CMA from 31 March to 5 April 2015.

A government delegation met with the CMA negotiation team in Algiers on 6 April, but this meeting mediated by Algerian Minister of Foreign Affairs Ramtane Lamamra did not lead to any tangible results.

Between 14 and 19 April, the CMA delegation in Algiers maintained that it would sign the draft peace agreement if the mediator could guarantee that some outstanding issues would be addressed during the implementation proccess.

The Government of Mali and the CMA subsequently met in Algiers on 30 May 2015 for a new round of negotiations, while fighting continued in the north despite the previously concluded ceasefire. This round ended with the conflict parties signing the Relevé de Conclusions des Consultations Préparatoires a la mise en œuvre de l’Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d’Alger on 5 June, which stipulated the the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arangemnts to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire, the Arrangement sécuritaire pour une cessation des hostilités.
agreement_name: Relevé de Conclusions des Consultations Préparatoires a la mise en œuvre de l’Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d’Alger; Ceasefire (Arrangement sécuritaire pour une cessation des hostilités)

description: This paved the way for the CMA finally signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d’Alger, also reffered to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d’Alger (Bamako Agreement)

description: A monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) – to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agrement. The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015.

Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) – was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as as representation and responsibility sharing.
The monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) -  also met in August 2015.

The monitoring committee's – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) -  efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and the other non-state signatory to the agreement, Platform, were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February, but no progress was made. While the Government presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the Ménaka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivités territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.

Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary General, together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs’ summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.

Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
Another meeting of the monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) - on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November.

At another meeting of the monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) - on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement.
On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA.

Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 – which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA – the mediatiors tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the monitoring committee – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA). While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January in Bamako without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.

A conference for national harmony, the conférence d’entente nationale, was held in Bamako from 27 March to 2 April 2017. This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace proccess.
In addition, Algeria opened an unofficial process, bringing together the conflict parties several times during the year.

Together with the separatist Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad), Ansar Dine (English: Defenders of the Faith) launched a lightning offensive in Northern Mali. Ansar Dine fought for the imposition of Sharia law. However, tactical alliance between the MNLA and Ansar Dine soon broke down and Ansar Dine evicted the MNLA from the towns in the region. By late 2012, most MNLA fighters were based in the countryside, attempting to regroup. In early 2012, ECOWAS appointed Blaise Compaoré, president of Burkina Faso, as chief mediator in the Mali crisis in order to find a diplomatic solution to the conflict between the Government of Mali on the one side and Ansar Dine and the MNLA on the other side. The first round of negotiations mediated by Blaise Compaoré was held in Ouagadougou between 17 and 19 June 2012 and brought together MNLA and Ansar Dine representatives. Blaise Compaoré, acting as ECOWAS mediator, met with Ansar Dine in an attempt to get the group end its relationship with Al-Qaeda.

On 11 December, MNLA and Ansar Dine again met for a second round of talks with Compaoré in Ouagadougou, where they agreed to end hostilities with the government. The peace process involving Ansar Dine initiated in 2012 came to an abrupt end when the Islamist groups started moving south, possibly towards Bamako.

In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. The SRF was supported by the Government of South Sudan.  In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union’s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Government of Sudan and the SRF. Indirect negotiations between the SRF and the Government of Sudan were mediated the AUHIP. These negotiations led to the signing of on an agreement to allow humanitarian assistance in rebel-controlled areas of South Kordofan and Blue Nile on 4 August 2012. Yet, the agreement did not address the conflict issues.

On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan’s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks.  Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF. The joint AU-UN Special Envoy, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, met with the SRF leadership in Kampala on 12 February 2014 to discuss the possibility of formal negotiations. To prepare for the national dialogue, the leaders of the SRF and the Umma Party, a Sudanese opposition party, decided to form an alliance at a meeting in Paris on 8 August 2014. They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue.

On 1 September 2014, leaders of the SRF met with the chairman of the AU High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), Thabo Mbeki, in Addis Ababa to discuss the format of future negotiations. On the basis of this discussion, the African Union’s Peace and Security Council issued Communique 456 on 15 September 2014, which stipulated that government’s talks with the Darfuris and SPLM-North should be conducted in a synchronized manner, referred to as the “one process, two tracks” approach. This effectively focused the negotiations on reaching a ceasefire in both Darfur and the two areas, while simultaneously implementing the national dialogue that al-Bashir had announced in January 2014. The alliance between the SRF and the Umma Party forged in Paris in August was reiterated and extended to include other traditional political party leaders and civil society representatives on 3 December 2014, with the signing of the Sudan Call.

A round of AUHIP-mediated negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government started in Addis Abba on 12 November 2014. This round of negotiations consisted of two track. The SLM/A-MM and the JEM negotiated with the government on a ceasefire in Darfur (the SLM/A-AW boycotted this round of talks with the government), while the SPLM/A-North negotiated on a ceasefire in the two areas. This round of negotiations ended with the AU mediation team announcing on 9 December 2014 that the government delegation and the SPLM-North failed to agree on a ceasefire. The reason for this deadlock was that the SPLM/A-North had insisted on a comprehensive solution for Sudan entirely, while Khartoum insisted on a cessation of hostilities for the Blue Nile and South Kordofan only. What is more, the Sudanese government had already initiated what it referred to as a deceive summer campaign in South Kordofan on 1 December 2014.

The government’s military, summer campaign in South Kordofan continued until mid-January 2015 and was extended to Blue Nile in February 2015. In addition, the Sudanese government refused to attend a preparatory meeting for the national dialogue that the AUHIP had wanted to facilitate in Addis Ababa on 29 and 30 March 2015. This effectively ended the SRF’s participation in the national dialogue. On 24 August 2015, the Sudanese government announced a two-month ceasefire with the SRF, which could be extended if progress is made in negotiations.  The ceasefire applied to both Darfur and the Blue Nile and South Kordofan. The SRF agreed to the ceasefire and also indicated it was ready resume negotiations with the government without further delay. On 14 September 2015, the SRF leadership announced that it was ready to sign a six-month cessation of hostilities agreement with the Sudanese government. The SRF further called on the government to “engage in a comprehensive dialogue.” In January 2016, the SRF leadership met with the Qatari deputy prime minister in Paris to discuss the possibility of official peace negotiations
In addition, informal negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government were held in Berlin between 22 and 24 January 2016.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF took place in leadership in Addis Ababa between 19 and 21 March. Based on this round of talks, the AU mediators drew up a roadmap agreement for the conflict parties’ consideration. The Sudanese government signed the roadmap agreement on 21 March 2016, but the SRF refused to sign the roadmap. Subsequent third party efforts were aimed at making the SRF accept the roadmap.

On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement.

The conflict parties started another round of AU-mediated negotiations in mid-August 2016. These negotiations were supposed to focus on implementing the roadmap agreement, but the AUHIP declared the collapse of Darfur and Two Areas Ceasefire talks on 15 August 2016, blaming the JEM and the SLM/A-MM for introducing new demands on issues that had previously been agreed and which contradicted the roadmap agreement. The mediation team therefore postponed the negotiations indefinitely.

Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the SRF in Addis Abba in early August 2016 made some progress. On 8 August 2016, the SRF accepted and signed the roadmap agreement put forward by the AU on 21 March 2016. The roadmap stipulates a ceasefire, as well as outlined a framework for negotiations on the conflicts in Darfur and the two areas of Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile.

Several rounds of informal negotiations were held in Berlin throughout 2018. The German Foreign Ministry and the Berghof Foundation acted as mediators at these exploratory talks. These negotiations were aimed at initiating formal negotiations between the SRF alliance and the Sudanese government. Representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, representing the SRF, and the Sudanese government conducted pre-negotiations in Berlin on 16 and 17 April 2018. The Joint Special Representative for Darfur and representatives of Norway, the UK, and the US also particpated in these pre-negotiations.
third_party: Germany; Berghof Foundation; Norway; UK; US

description: Another such round of negotiations was held in Berlin on 28 June 2018, this time with involvement from the SPLM/A-North as well. Both of these informal negotiations failed to reach agreement on official negotiations.
third_party: Germany; Berghof Foundation; Norway; UK; US

description: Another round of negotiations in Berlin on 6 and 7 December 2018, attended by the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, representing the SRF, and the Sudanese government, led to the signing of a pre-negotiation agreement, committing the parties to resume official negotiations.
third_party: Germany; Berghof Foundation; Norway; UK; US

description: Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SRF. Negotiations in Juba in September 2019 led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF.

It was not until 2013 that the conflict escalated. On 23 March 2013, a group of Kata Katanga fighters marched up to Lubumbashi and raised the old flag of independent Katanga on the statue of Moise Tshombe in the main square of the city. Following clashes with security forces, the group fled to a UN compound where they surrendered. Having given up on their fight at the MONUSCO base, the rebels handed in their weapons to peacekeepers and agreed to take part in mediation talks with the local authorities. Following negotiations mediated by MONUSCO between the provincial authorities and the Kata Katanga fighters on 23 and 24 March 2013, the latter were transported by the Congolese authorities to Kinshasa on two flights.

After negotiations between Gédéon Kuyungu and the governor of Congo’s Haute-Katanga, Jean-Claude Kazembe, in September and October 2016, Kyungu himself and several hundred rebels surrendered their weapons in a ceremony in Lubumbashi on 12 October 2016.  When surrendering, Kyungu stated “I come to answer the call of the Head of State who wants peace.” He added that he was willing to face justice with regard to prosecution.

The armed conflict between Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army - In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) and the Government of South Sudan started in mid-December 2013, when two different factions within the Presidential guard clashed in Juba. One faction was loyal to President Salva Kiir, while the other faction was loyal to the former vice-president Riek Machar. Machar had been ousted from the government in July 2013. In mid-December, President Kiir accused Riek Machar of conducting a coup d’état, but this accusation later proved to be unsubstantiated. The accusation is widely seen as a pretext for crack down on Machar and pushing all Nuer troops out of Juba, after which Nuer civilians were targeted. Armed clashes between the conflict parties quickly spread to other areas, in particular to Bor, Malakal, and Bentiu. In response to the armed conflict, Salva Kiir also detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals, accusing them of conspiring with Riek Machar to overthrow the government. The political prisoners were all senior SPLM/A party members who had begun to openly criticize the president in 2013. This group has commonly been referred to as the “former detainees” after the first seven were released in January 2013 and the remaining four were released in in May 2014. As soon as the war broke out, Uganda intervened in the civil war in support of the South Sudanese government, while Sudan supported the SPLM/A-IO with weapons and ammunition. A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: On 26 December, a second IGAD delegation – led by the President of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, and the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Dessalegn – visited Juba for peace talks with the President of South Sudan, members of the Cabinet, and the detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals. The IGAD delegation also tried to further probe into the root causes of the conflict and discuss how best to address it. IGAD held an extraordinary summit in Nairobi on 27 December 2013, where three special envoys – Ambassador Seyoum Mesfin of Ethiopia, General Lazaro Sumbeiywo of Kenya, and General Mohamed Ahmed Mustapha al-Dabi of the Sudan – were appointed to support a resolution of the crisis.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: IGAD began to mediate direct  negotiations between the conflict parties in early 2014. Seyoum Mesfin, who had been the Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1991 until September 2010, was the chief mediator of the peace process. A first round of negotiations took place in Addis Ababa between 2 and 23 January 2014. These negotiations mainly focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire, as well as on the release of some political prisoners taken by the government. The mediation team led by Mesfin considered a ceasefire unlikely to hold unless underlying political grievances were addressed, but they deemed that a reduction in violence was necessary to create the space for substantial negotiations. Hence, the negotiations first focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 23 January 2014, which took effect the next day.  The ceasefire committed the conflict parties to end offensive operations, freeze their forces in place, and refrain from attacks against civilians. The ceasefire also established a monitoring and verification mechanism.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: On 12 January 2015, the conflict parties signed another ceasefire in the IGAD-led mediation process, as well committed themselves to accelerate efforts to reach an agreement based on the formation of a transitional government.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: Negotiations in Arusha  between 9 to 19 January 2015 brought together President Salva Kiir representing the SPLM/A-In Government, Rick Riek Machar representing the SPLM/A-In Opposition, and Deng Alor Kuol representing the SPLM/A-Former Detainees. John Samuel Malecela, the Vice Chairman of Tanzania’s ruling party the Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), and Abdulrahman Kinana, the CCM General-Secretary, acted as the chief mediators at this round of negotiations in Arusha. The negotiations led to the signing of the Agreement on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (Arusha Agreement) on 21 January 2015.

The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO met in Addis Ababa on 27 and 28 January 2015 for two days of  IGAD-mediated negotiations prior to the IGAD Head of States Summit on 29 January.  These negotiations focused on power-sharing. The IGAD mediation team proposed to make Riek Machar vice-president again, but keeping James Wani Igga as a second vice-president. Politicians from Equatoria expressed opposition to this proposal, asserting that Igga should hold a more senior position to Riek Machar in a future power-sharing agreement.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: The conflict parties signed another ceasefire on 1 February 2015.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: Another round of IGAD-led negotiations in Addis Abba started on 23 February 2015. Prior to the start of this round of negotiations, both the AU and IGAD threatened sanctions against South Sudan if a comprehensive power sharing deal is not reached by 5 March. One major disagreement during the negotiations was that the SPLM/A-IO demanded the creation of two separate armies in the country during the transitional period, with the SPLM/A-IO fighters being officially recognized as a separate army. The negotiations broke down on 6 March 2015.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: On 27 June 2015, President Salva Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Riek Machar conducted a consultative meeting in Nairobi under the auspices of President Kenyatta of Kenya to review elements of the proposed peace agreement.

The IGAD mediation effort resumed in June, but was officially reconfigured as “IGAD Plus” in June 2015, expanding the mediation team to also include representatives from five African Union member states, the UN, the Troika (US, UK, and Norway), the EU, and China. A new round of negotiations was initiated in Addis Ababa on 9 June 2015. This round of negotiations ended on 25 June, with agreement that the IGAD mediation would circulate a “compromise agreement” in July, which was the product of negotiations and consultations since January 2014.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: The mediation team indeed circulated the draft of this agreement after another round of negotiations in Addis Ababa from 21 to 23 July 2015. The third parties subsequently put a lot of pressure on the conflict parties to accept this agreement.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: At a new round of negotiations that had started with a summit in Addis Ababa on 27 July chaired by President Barack Obama, it was decided that the conflict parties would have until 17 August 2015 to sign a final peace agreement. Several amendments were subsequently negotiated on the basis of the draft agreement. For instance, the conflict parties agreed that the deadline for the complete integration of the SPLM/A-IO forces into the national army would be within 30 months of signing of the agreement, instead of the 18 months proposed by the mediators.

Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Bostwana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan

description: Another round of IGAD-led negotiations led to the signing of the Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement on 3 November 2015. This Agreement concerns the details on the implementation of the Transitional Government of National Unity (TGONU) and the Transitional National Assembly (TNA), as well as the adoption of the transitional constitution. The agreement also specified that the SPLM/A-IO was allowed to deploy 1,410 security personel in Juba and the government 3,420 security personnel.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement

description: The ARCSS included a political power-sharing provision. To this purpose, Machar returned to Juba in April 2016. However, problems with the implementation of the ARCSS were already apparent prior to Machar’s return. Kiir had cast aside the power-sharing formula of the ARCSS in October 2015 through creating 28 states instead of ten states. In addition, in violation to the agreement, Chief of Staff Paul Malong had secretly brought a Dinka militia to Juba. With tensions increasing, fighting between the conflict parties eventually resumed in July 2016. This effectively suspended the peace process. Following the clashes, President Kiir issued a decree on an immediate ceasefire in the country on 11 July 2016. Yet, fighting continued. Riek Machar subsequently fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo while under attack of ground forces and helicopter gunships. Taban Deng Gai sought the support of some disgruntled SPLM/A-IO generals, after which Kiir appointed Taban Deng Gai as the vice president, replacing Machar. Riek Machar was later put under house arrest in South Africa. However, most of the SPLM/A-IO remained loyal to Machar. JMEC chairman Festus Mogae reported in October 2016 that “near-daily violations” of the ceasefire by both parties, warning that these could “trigger an uncontrolled escalation of violence.”

Building on the Arusha Agreement that had been concluded in January 2015, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni mediated a round of negotiations between the three factions with the SPLM/A in July 2017. This round of negotiations involving the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees led to the signing of the Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM on 27 July 2017. This agreement established a working group to revitalize and operationalize the implementation of the Arusha Agreement, trying to reunify the SPLM/A. In addition. IGAD tried “revitalize” the peace process from mid-2017 onwards.  The IGAD leaders endorsed a plan to kick-start the peace process at the 31st Extra-ordinary Summit of IGAD Assembly of Heads of State on 12 June 2017. IGAD announced on 1  October 2017 that it would resume the formal peace process to bring peace to South Sudan.
agreement_name: Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM

description: In addition, Egypt and Uganda had mediated a round of negotiations in Cairo in November 2017 aimed at reunifying the SPLM/A. On 16 November 2017, representatives of the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees signed the Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM).
agreement_name: Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)

description: The revitalization forum, aimed at restarting peace talks, began in Addis Ababa on 18 December. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access on 21 December 2017.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access

description: Building on the conclusion of the Cairo agreement, another round of negotiations involving the three factions within the SPLM/A was held in Entebbe in December 2017. These negotiations led to the conclusion of the Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix on 15 December 2017.
agreement_name: Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix

description: On 2 January 2018, the Troika – comprising of the US, the UK, and Norway – called on the conflict parties to end their military operations and threatened to impose sanctions on those who would not comply with this call. The IGAD-led mediation process continued in 2018. The second round of the IGAD revitalization forum was held in Addis Ababa between 5 and 16 February 2018, but no agreement was reached
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: A round of proximity talks  was held between the conflict parties in Addis Ababa on 11 and 12 May 2018.  This round of indirect talks was followed by the resumption of the revitalization forum in Addis Ababa from 17 to 23 May 2018. The South Sudan Council of Churches supported this IGAD-led round of negotiations through facilitating dialogue sessions to bridge their differences on the outstanding governance and security issues identified as critical to revitalize the Agreement.  The conflict parties recommitted to the implementation of the cessation of hostilities agreement, but little substantial progress was made. Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially led the effort the revitalize the peace process following his election in April 2018.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: The conflict parties engaged in shuttle negotiations in Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 June 2018, but Abiy Ahmed mediated a face-to-face meeting between President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar on the final day of this round of negotiations. This was the first meeting of Kiir and Machar since the resumption of hostilities in July 2016. The following day, on 21 June 2018, the IGAD Assembly of Heads of State and Government mandated Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir to mediate the negotiations. President al-Bashir was supported by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: Face-to-face talks between President Kiir and Machar resumed in Khartoum on 25 June and concluded with the Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan on 27 June. This agreement was also signed by the representatives of the South Sudan Opposition Alliance, the “Former Detainees”, and the other political parties. In the Declaration, the signatories announced a permanent ceasefire, set objectives for transitional security arrangements and signatories to reach an agreement on the IGAD revised bridging proposal, improve infrastructure and basic services in South Sudan and restore oil fields in Unity. The agreement also stipulates a comprehensive ceasefire. This agreement commits the conflict parties to a permanent ceasefire and to finalize a deal on the pending issues in the governance chapter of the 2015 peace agreement. stipulated a “revised bridging proposal” that listed the details of a pre-transitional period. The agreement also includes provisions with regard to the oil, elections, and reconstruction. The agreement thus was meant to pave the way for the formation of an inclusive transitional cabinet. The agreement also called upon the AU and IGAD to deploy protection forces and ceasefire monitors to observe the ceasefire implementation. In addition, the conflict parties agreed to open the humanitarian corridors, release detainees, withdraw troops and militarily disengage.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan

description: On 6 July 2018,  following a round of negotiations mediated by  Sudan and Uganda in Khartoum, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements, which included additional provisions on the ceasefire and the Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR) process.
agreement_name: Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements

description: Another meeting  between  Kiir and Machar, mediated by Sudan and Uganda, took place in Entebbe on 7 July 2018.

The conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance on 5 August 2018. This agreement supplemented and/or amended previously agreed provisions on political power-sharing through specifying who will hold the key government ministries and positions.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance

description: Building on progress made through the signing of the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance, another round of negotiations was held in Khartoum  between  13 and 19 August 2018. These talks mainly focused on the status and incorporation of the documents agreed upon in Addis Ababa and in Khartoum in the preceding months. On 18 August 2018, the mediators circulated a draft revitalized text of the peace agreement to the parties for comment before adjourning for the Eid holidays.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: Another round of negotiations in Khartoum started on 25 August 2018 and led to the signing of a draft revitalized peace agreement between 28 and 30 August.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: The conflict parties signed a final agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS). While the Troika had been involved in most of the IGAD-led negotiations in 2018, they were excluded from the final rounds of negotiations. The Troika therefore refused to co-sign the R-ARCSS. The agreement outlined a revised comprehensive framework for the transition from conflict. The agreement stipulated the reinstatement of Machar as First Vice President and the establishment of a transitional government in May 2019. In addition, in line with the agreement, Kiir ordered the release of all prisoners of war and detainees in September 2018. Kiir and Machar jointly attended peace celebrations in the capital Juba on October 31 2018, together with the presidents of Sudan, Uganda, Somalia, and Ethiopia, as well as Egypt’s prime minister. Nevertheless, fighting between government forces and the SPLM/A-IO continued throughout the year, though at a lower intensity.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan
agreement_name: Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan

description: The R-ARCSS stipulated that Salva Kiir and Riek Machar had to form a unity government by May 2019. On 2 May 2019, IGAD mediated a round of negotiations in Addis Ababa where the conflict parties and the IGAD mediation team agreed to extend the deadline to 12 November 2019. The conflict parties indicated that this extension was needed to complete the necessary transitional security arrangements, including protection for senior government officials, to form the transitional Government. However, follow-up mediation was also needed to address more substantial issues. The International Crisis Group reported on the need for follow-up mediation on the R-ARCSS, stating that “The accord, brokered by Sudan’s Omar al-Bashir and Uganda’s Yoweri Museveni, is not a finished product and requires revision” and that “Additional political deals are necessary on two crucial matters – unifying a national army and resolving bitter disagreements over local boundaries and administration inside South Sudan. Absent such deals, the Kiir-Machar truce may fail its first major test in May 2019, when the two South Sudanese leaders are scheduled to form a unity government.” On 18 October, in a communiqué, the Peace and Security Council of the AU called for the parties’ adherence to the deadline of 12 November. During its visit to South Sudan on 20 October 2019, the UN Security Council also called for adhering to the deadline, but also stressed the need to address outstanding issues. While the Government of South Sudan intended to form the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity on 12 November, the SPLM/A-IO called for an extension.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

description: President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019.

Another face-to-face meeting between Kiir and Machar, which also involved other signatories of the R-ARCSS, took place on 9 November 2019. These talks were mediated by IGAD. The talks led to the endorsement of the plan to extend the deadline with 100 days in order to facilitate the resolution of the outstanding issues.
third_party: IGAD; Kenya; Ethiopia; Eritrea; Uganda; Sudan

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Following the defeat of the old regime, the General National Congress (GNC) assumed power in Libyan on 8 August 2012. The formation of the GNC was opposed by several armed actors, including the Libyan National Army (LNA) and Zintan Military Council (ZMC). In June 2014, the country held general elections in which a new legislative assembly was elected: the House of Representatives (HOR). However, the passover of authority never took place as the GNC contested the elections’ legitimacy and the HOR was pushed out of Tripoli by pro-GNC factions in August 2014.  Around the time the HOR was pushed out of Tripoli, it was solely a political actor. Yet, the HOR officially aligned itself with the LNA and the ZMC on 15 October 2014. Both these groups were opposing the GNC. In addition to the ZMC and LNA, several other militias fought the GNC in support of the HOR’s claim to legitimacy. The UCDP refers to this alliance of militas as the “Forces of the House of Representatives” even though these forces did not use this name to refer to themselves. In addition, it is important to note that the HOR was Libya’s internationally recognized government until the spring of 2016. However, since the UCDP coding criteria stipulate that the party in control of a state’s capital is considered the government actor, the UCDP codes the HOR as a non-state armed group opsing the GNC government. In November 2014, the Constitutional Circuit of the Libyan Supreme Court ruled that the recent elections were illegitimate, which emboldened the GNC to hold on power. The conflict parties agreed to a temporary humanitarian ceasefire on 19 November 2014.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: After two unsuccessful attempts to initiate negotiations in the autum of 2014, the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) managed to initiate negotiations in Geneva in late January 2015. UN Specical-Representative Bernadino Leon acted as the chief mediator at these talks. The negotiations were aimed at concluding a Libyan Political Agreement, which would establish a new governmental structure. The first round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 14-15 January 2015. Following these talks, the GNC government declared a unilateral ceasefire on 18 January 2015, which was reciprocated by the Forces of the HOR.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The second round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 26-27 January 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another track of negotiations with consultation from the UN Special Representative was being led by Algeria and Tunisia. Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi and Sheikh Rached Ghannouchi met with the conflict parties for negotiations in Algiers in March, which led to a framework for the negotiations on 19 March 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL mediated another round of negotiations on 8 June 2015. On 11 July 2015, following mediation by the UN, a framework called the Libyan Political Agreement was signed by most of the relevant political actors, except the GNC. The framework agreement focused on the basic terms for the Libyan state-building process and outlined the steps to get to a Government of National Accord (GNA). Progress was made in the following months.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: During negotiations mediated by the UN, the parties agreed to annexes of the accord on 21 September 2015.
agreement_name: Annexes to the Libyan Political Agreement

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another round of UN-mediated negotiations in Sikhat, Morocco, focused on reaching agreement on the membership of the proposed Presidency Council on 7 October.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UN-mediated negotiations in Skhirat in December led to the signing of the Libyan Political Agreement on 17 December 2015. This comprehensive peace agreement created a Presidency Council with Fayiz al-Serraj as Prime Minister. The HOR lost its status as the internationally recognized government following the creation of the GNA.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 2 January 2016, the Presidency Council convened its first meeting in Tunis. This same month it released a proposal for a Government of National Accord (GNA) for the HOR to accept, which the HOR did on 25 January. However, there was a faction of HOR that rejected the GNA. Those HOR members that endorsed the agreement attempted to meet with the breakaway group on 18, 19 and 21 April, but they were unsuccessful. It was not until 30 March 2016 that the Presidency Council of the GNA was officially set-up in Tripoli. Following the formation of the GNA, efforts continued to obtain unified and full support from the HOR for the GNA. UN-mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA were held in Tunis between 16 and 18 July 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Following the formation of the Government of National Accord (GNA), efforts continued to obtain unified and full support from the HOR for the GNA. Prime Minister Fayiz al-Serraj convened with members of the HOR on 22 August 2016 to discuss a new proposal, but this proposal was rejected. In response, the new Libyan government publicly stated that it intended to function with or without HOR support.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Following the formation of the Government of National Accord (GNA), efforts continued to obtain unified and full support from the HOR for the GNA. UN-mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA were held in Tunis on 5 and 6 September 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Following the formation of the Government of National Accord (GNA), efforts continued to obtain unified and full support from the HOR for the GNA. The UN also mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA in Malta on 10 and 11 November 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL continued its active role in supporting the peace process, but Egypt took over as a key mediator in late 2016. In December 2016, Egypt hosted negotiations between GNA and HOR representatives in Cairo, although these negotiations would later in the month shift to focusing on the forces of General Haftar and his rivals in the West and South of the country.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: A consultation meeting regarding implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement and to get the HOR on board was held in Ghadames on 17 January 2017. No third party was involved in this meeting.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another consultation meeting was held in Tunis between 22 - 24 January 2017. These meetings led to the signing of the Hammamet Agreement on 24 January 2017. This agreement addresses structural issues of the Presidency Council and other governmental bodies, as well as the implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement by the HOR.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Prime Minister Fayiz al-Serraj and General Khalifa Haftar, leader of the Libyan National Army, engaged in negotiations in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) from 2 to 3 May to discuss an end to armed fighting.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The HOR created a committee of 24 representatives on 24 April to implement the Hammamet Agreement, while the government created a comittee of 13 representative to this purpose on 9 May 2017. The comittees met for negotiations, mediated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, in The Hague on 23 May 2017.  On 29 May, France unilaterally held a summit with Serraj, Haftar, Saleh and Khaled Mishri of HOR. This produced a plan for 2018 elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another round of negotiations involving the HOR and government committees tasked to implement the Hammamet Agreement took place in The Hague on 7 July 2017.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: France mediated between Serraj and Haftar in Paris in July 2017, which led to a ceasefire on 25 July 2017. This ceasefire was sporadically violated throughout the year.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The UN Special Representative introduced an Action Plan in Tunis in September 2017 that focused on institutional development and elections. The HOR and government committees met again in Tunis on 26 September 2017. This meeting was mediated by UNSMIL and led agreement on the restructuring of the Presidency Council and other institutions. A formal proposal was released on 10 November 2017.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL mediated a round of negotiations between Serraj and Haftar, as well as several members of the High Council of State, in Paris on 29 May 2018. This led to an agreement on holding elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 12 to 13 November 2018, a peace conference was hosted by Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte in Palermo in order to discuss elections and stabilization in Libya. Representatives from HOR and GNA as well as 38 UN-members states were in attendance, producing a document summarizing their efforts on the final day of the conference.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Along with the US, France, and the UAE, the UN mediated between Haftar and Serraj for a peace talk in Abu-Dhabi. This meeting was held near the end of February 2019. While the parties verbally agreed to uniting the government and preparing for elections, no formal agreement came out of this effort. The UN prepared a National Conference to further the political dialogue, but this conference never materialized because of renewed attacks led by Haftar.

The Sudanese Awakening Revolutionary Council (SARC) was established on 4 January 2014. The group was led by Musa Hilal, a chief of the Arab Mahamid tribe and former leader of the Janjaweed that conducted a massive counterinsurgency campaign against rebel groups in Darfur. In January 2014, Hilal defected from the Sudanese government. On 17 March 2014, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal. In late March 2014, Chad hosted peace talks between the conflict parties in the Chadian border town of Um Jaras, but this did not lead to an agreement. By late 2014, Hilal was running his own administration in North Darfur, with his troops controlling Saraf Umra town, Kutum town, Kabkabiya town, and the El Waha area. To this purpose, Hilal set up a council composed of native leaders to perform administrative and judicial functions in these areas. A tax system with various fees for vehicles travelling in their areas of control was also set up. SARC also profited from artisan gold mining in Jabal Amer.

In response to armed clashes between the government forces and the SARC, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal on 12 January 2015, which led to the conclusion of an agreement and the reintegration of SARC fighters into the Border Guard. SARC even supported the Sudanese government during the elections that were held in this year.
In April 2018, Omda Hasoun Mangali negotiated with the Sudanese government on behalf of SARC to release Musa Hilal, but Mangali was kidnapped by unknown gunmen while in Khartoum for negotiations.

Kamuina Nsapu is the hereditary title for the chief in the Bajila Kasanga groupement. The chief over this groupement traditionally has influence over many other neighboring areas bordering Angola. After the death of the chief in 2011, the government of DRC refused to recognize the traditional appointment of Jean-Pierre Mpandi as Kamuina Nsapu due to his affiliation with groups opposed to the Kabila regime. Mpandi responded by calling the Congolese government an occupation government. On 3 April 2016, Mpandi’s home was searched, in his absence, for weapons. This incident reportedly exacerbated his animosity against the authorities. In April 2016, the Congolese government replaced Mpandi with his brother. Around this time, the first reports of an armed group called Kamuina Nsapu appeared in an effort to destabilize the government. On July 25 2016, a delegation was sent to Kamuina Nsapu to negotiate with Mpandi. This delegation was led by provincial minister of the interior, Simon Pierre Tshibuyi Kayembe. Tshibuyi’s report emphasized that Mpandi was upset that the provincial authorities had not acted on his request for official recognition of his customary title, and rejected the notion that he was forming a militia.

Since Mpandi’s death, the group has intensified attacks on state institutions. On 27 January 2017, the rebels protested a visit from Prime Minister Samy Badibanga and sought the removal of governor Alex Kande. In addition, the demands shifted to national issues in late February 2017, namely the incumbent Joseph Kabila stepping down as president. On 12 March 2017, the Interior Minister Emmanuel Ramazani Shadari, whose delegation included opposition members of parliament, held talks with the Kamuina Nsapu’s family.  A peace agreement between Mpandi’s family and the government was signed. On 16 March, the parliamentarians published welcome recommendations, including the appointment of a new provincial administration and measures to manage conflicts with the customary authorities. On 17 March 2017, the government announced a less far-reaching compromise, including the burial of the Kamuina Nsapu, measures on detainees and an agreement on the procedure to select Jacques Kabeya Ntumba as the new chief. In January 2019, following the election of Felix Tshisekedi, a group of Kamuina Nsapu leaders along with 100 soldiers surrendered to the Congolese government. Although more than a thousand surrendered, some proved dissatisfied with the Tshisekedi government and fighting in the area was reignited.

On 8 August 2017, Mpandi and his forces attacked the police buildings in Tshimbulu. On 10 August 2017, another delegation arrived in Kananga, this time composed from the national association of customary chiefs, but this round of negotiations also failed. Immediately following this negotiation, a prominent Congolese politician in the Kasai region Évariste Boshab gave Mpandi an ultimatum: surrender or face a government attack. On 12 August 2016, Jean-Pierre Mpandi was killed by government soldiers. The governor publicly announced Mpandi’s death and his body was brought to Kananga.

From 18 to 21 September, the Congolese government led a peace conference in Kananga with 800 government officials, traditional leaders from Kamuina Nspau and representatives from the region. By the end of the conference, a peace agreement was signed.

Khalifa al-Ghawi once led the Libyan Government as Prime Minister under the National Salvation Government (NSG). NSG took over in March 2014 from the General National Congress (GNC), which had initially led the country in the aftermath of Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi’s death. However, the Sikhrat Agreement in December 2015 established the Government of National Accord (GNA), which al-Ghawi and his supporters staunchly opposed. His forces unsuccessfully attacked Tripoli multiple times over the years. After clashes during the first half of March 2016, the conflict parties entered into negotiations. This led to an agreement on 16 March 2016 that stipulated that Khalifa’s forces along with other opposition groups would withdraw from Tripoli.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia (Soviet Union) and Sudan in August 2018 from which the government had been excluded, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The APPR was signed by 14 non-state armed groups, including the UPC, and the CAR Government. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements, making the agreement essentially an elite-level pact to buy off armed group leaders.
agreement_name: Accord politique la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: Switzerland and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) conducted pre-negotiations between the conflict parties in Saint-Luc, a small village in the canton of Valais, on 25 and 27 June 2019. These negotiations were aimed at initiating formal negotiations. However, the mediation process ended in failure due to distrust from certain factions within the secessionist movement.
A round of negotiations was held in Geneva in early July 2019.

Another round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 20 July 2019. The Swiss Process, as it was later referred to, did not result in any formal agreement or end the conflict. The effort was ended in December that year.

From 30 September to 4 October 2019, the Cameroonian government hosted the Major National Dialogue in Yaounde. This was intended to unite the country and bring an end to the crisis of Ambazonia. A majority of insurgents refused to participate, with the exception of a faction from Fako.
